PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform the Senate that the Government Whip, Senator Robertson, will be absent this week on parliamentary business in Tasmania. Senator Jones will act as Government Whip until Senator Robertson returns.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled should delay the Bill and ask:
That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine-
(a) the implications of the U.N. Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Covenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the U.N. Convention.
The Terms of Reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested orgainsations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Rae (from 14 citizens) and Watson (from 49 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Cadet Corps
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humbled petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Cadet Corps has great value in the development of youth in the schools of Australia.
That the reorganisation of the Australian Cadet Corps will disperse accumulated expertise and interest of those involved, and in some cases negate the efforts of many people over many years.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will reconsider its decision and that the Government will not reorganise the Australian Cadet Corps.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows-
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Post-School Education Sector
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the post-school education sector has been neglected in recent years . Therefore we call on the members of the Senate to endorse:
(1) Increases in TEAS to at least the level of the poverty line. All people should be guaranteed a living wage.
(2) Increased funding for campus based childcare.
(3) The abolition of the overseas student visa charge which is grossly discriminatory.
(4) Increased funding for student housing.
(5) Increased funding for libraries to ensure facilities are adequate.
(6) The establishment or supplementation of campus based student loan funds which are interest free and short-term.
(7) Increasing the level and number of postgraduate awards.
(8) Extending services to part-time, mature age and external students to open access to education.
(9) Increasing student representation at all levels.
(10) Innovation in curriculum to ensure curriculum is relevant and critical.
(11) Increasing education funding to improve existing facilities.
(12) Funding quality student health services which help contribute to the successful completion of courses.
(13) Expanding enrolments to open access to education.
(14) Compensating institutions for the costs of amalgamation.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
The Senate will support the above claims.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique in- herent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every child in Australia is entitled to government financial support for their education whether they attend government schools or non-government schools .

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that urgent consideration be given to a favourable decision for the continuation of Federal Government per capita grants payable in respect of all children in non-government schools at a rate calculated as a percentage of Government standard costs at a level not less than that prevailing in 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Youth Forum: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

Since 1979 over 3,000 young people have participated in Youth Forum Projects. Youth Forum has the structure and network necessary to provide young people in New South Wales with the skills, information and opportunity to define and solve some of their own problems.
Apart from an International Year of the Child grant of $15,000 in 1979, Youth Forum has received no government funding, rather it has utilised a total of $320 ,000, raised from the private sector.
Youth Forum is in danger of closing in early October if government funding is not secured, and valuable youth skills and resources will be lost to the community.

Youth Forum is an existing project which is a perfect vehicle through which the Federal Government can pursue the objectives of international youth year peace participation and development-in 1985. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should financially support Youth Forum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local governments in Australia shows that:
General revenue grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83.
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent.
The increase in grants to State governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent.
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g. Community Employment Program.
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to local government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 28 citizens), Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 28 citizens ), and Hill (from eight citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 440 citizens), Childs (from 220 citizens), Robertson ( from 20 citizens), and Sibraa (from 112 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Federal Government Subsidy to Residential Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned students and staff of Newcastle University respectfully showeth that we are concerned at the consequences for residential students at this University of the reduction by 25 per cent in the current Federal Government subsidy to residential colleges.

The one residence at Newcastle University accommodates students from all over N .S.W. who wish to undertake their studies here. The reduction in subsidy will have the effect of forcing a number of students to postpone or terminate their studies.
Therefore we call on the members of the Senate to take action to ensure that the full subsidy (pre 1983-1984 Budget) is reinstated.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will support the above claims.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Visa Charges: Overseas Students
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia and overseas students studying at Australian Educational Institutions, respectfully showeth that the imposition of increased overseas student visa charges will ensure that access to Australian education will only be available to those overseas students from wealthy backgrounds.

Therefore, we call on the members of the Senate to endorse: An immediate freeze in the increases in visa charges and to reconsider this issue in the light of adequate access to Australian education being made available to overseas students.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that, the Senate will support the above claim.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to a number of claims which he has made about the limited market for Australian uranium, claims which he repeated on radio this morning. I refer also to a report in the Age of last Friday which purports to quote Mr A. J. Grey as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: The Federal Government policy on uranium has placed in jeopardy potential sales from the Jabiluka project totalling tens of thousands of tonnes . . .

I ask the Minister whether, if Pancontinental Mining Ltd or, indeed, any other company with rights to mine uranium, can get contracts to sell that uranium at a satisfactory price, Government policy as it has now been decided allows such companies to get export licences.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the final part of the question is clearly no. If Senator Chaney read the Cabinet recommendation, which has now been made public and which was endorsed yesterday by the parliamentary Labor Party, he would know that no new mines, other than Roxby Downs, would be allowed to proceed. With respect to the earlier part of his question, that is as to the degree to which there is room in the market place for new mines, I have said before and I say again that in my judgment the existing mines, plus Olympic Dam, or Roxby Downs- if a commercial decision is made to proceed with production-can meet the likely commercial demand for Australian uranium into the late 1990s.

—I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's judgment in these matters, but if as a matter of fact companies are able to write contracts at satisfactory prices and the Minister's judgment is thereby proved to be wrong, will export licences be available to those companies?

—The answer is still no and is quite clear in the decision announced yesterday. With respect to the broader implications of Senator Chaney' s question, apart from the question of contracts, the Jabiluka prospect has yet to comply with the foreign investment requirements of either the present Government or the previous Government. On those grounds, in addition to yesterday's decision, applications would have to be rejected. With respect to the decisions made by private enterprise, I note for the record that there are literally dozens, if not hundreds, of precedents for governments making decisions and implementing policies which pre-empt decisions that might otherwise be made by private enterprise. I refer, for example, to the existence of import quotas, hen licences and milk quotas. Even in the free enterprise State of Queensland, I notice that although everybody is perfectly free to grow sugar cane on unassigned land if they should wish to do so, it is then commandeered by the Sugar Marketing Board at a price of $1 a tonne. So even in the free enterprise State of Queensland drastic government intervention, interfering with commercial decisions by producers or potential producers, exists and has existed for approximately 60 years. That is only the tip of the iceberg.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to criticisms by the Queensland Premier of the Commonwealth Government's decision on uranium mining insofar as that decision may affect the proposed uranium project in North Queensland of the French company Minatome Australia Pty Ltd? Can the Minister say how the Government's decision will affect the future of that project at Ben Lomond?

—My attention has been drawn to this matter. It has also been drawn to the fact that, on 27 April 1981, Mr Lendich, who was the Charters Towers mining warden, recommended that the application of Minatome for a mining lease for the Ben Lomond deposit be rejected. My attention has also been drawn to the fact that on 7 December of that year Mr Bob Katter junior, who is now a Minister in the Queensland Government, wrote to the Queensland Premier expressing concern at the local environmental effects of the Ben Lomond proposal. He asked the Premier to ensure that any State Government decision on Ben Lomond not be made behind closed doors. Mr Katter is also reported to have said: 'I will ask the Minister in Parliament this week to give assurances that the leases will not be granted until the application has come back to the warden's court'. The application has not come back to the warden's court, as the warden had originally suggested. So, in short, it is obvious that there are clear differences of opinion, even within the now single party Government of Queensland, on the question of Ben Lomond. There is also the matter of the proposed mining venture not complying with the foreign equity requirements for uranium mines of either the previous or present Commonwealth Government.

—My question is to the Attorney-General. I refer him to a report in the Australian newspaper last week in which it was stated that a Mr Peter Niarros, a boilermaker at Mount Newman, was receiving bomb threats and was to be dismissed following his refusal to pay $20 to a union strike fund. In view of this blatant violation of Mr Niarros's human rights, will the Attorney refer his case urgently to the Human Rights Commission for immediate investigation and action? In view of the Attorney's much flaunted belief in human rights, will be give an unequivocal assurance that the human rights legislation will extend to those unions which have shown on many occasions that they will not hesitate to use standover tactics, including bomb threats and abusive phone calls, to violate the human rights and liberties of those people in our community who will not bow to their demands?
—Without pausing on the irony of a question about human rights emanating from the Queensland benches, I simply say--
—What are you trying to say?

—I would have quite a lot more to say if I spoke about human rights in the honourable senator's context. I have no knowledge of the particular case to which the honourable senator refers. I will look into the matter to see what course of action, if any, might be appropriate in relation to it. As to the content of the proposed Bill of Rights legislation, I shall just have to ask the honourable senator once again to curb her impatience, because all will be revealed in due course.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has he now seen the published advertisement from about 150 medical practitioners in Tasmania which he referred to prospectively last Wednesday at Question Time? The advertisement claims that the signatories declare:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we are totally committed to the provision of private medical and hospital care for all patients who wish it.

Is it true, firstly, that about half the signatories are specialists, and how often is it a question of a patient's wishes for treatment when there is a referral to a specialist? Do the doctors anywhere in that advertisement talk about the provision of care for all who need it, or do they mean that they are committed to providing expensive private care for patients who may wish it but not need it? Secondly, the advertisement says that the signatories reject the Medicare scheme. Can the Minister tell us whether the signatories think it means that if they reject Medicare their patients will not be able to claim Medicare benefits? Is there any way in which doctors can reject the benefits of the scheme on behalf of their patients? Finally, now that the names of those doctors in Tasmania rejecting Medicare are known, do the patients of these practitioners have any worries about consulting these particular practitioners again?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen the advertisement which was published in the Mercury. I note that the wording of the advertisement has been amended from that which was sent to the various practitioners who were asked to contribute $20 each to put the advertisement in the newspaper. As Senator Coates said, upwards of half the people who signed the advertisement were specialists. Those who signed it apparently have some objection to receiving public funds and having any public interference in health care. I find it surprising, therefore, on looking through the list of names, that it includes one gentleman who is a professor at the university. That gentleman receives a considerable sum of money each year by way of salary from public funds as a professor at the university. I notice also that several other practitioners on the list are, in fact, Commonwealth medical officers. They receive those positions by applying for them . They are perfectly happy to receive funds from the public purse to carry out those positions.
—So what?
—The honourable senator's spouse is one of those. Let us not get too sensitive about it. Let the honourable senator declare her interest when she wants to make a comment about this sort of thing.
—There are a lot of bickies in the barrel.

—As my colleague said, there are a lot of bickies in that barrel; they have a lot to protect. I also note the comments of the people who signed this advertisement in that they are totally committed to the provision of private medical and hospital care for all patients who wish it. Like Senator Coates, I would feel happier if they were concerned about the provision of medical care to those who need it. The simple fact about Medicare is that those who wish to insure for private medical care can still continue to do so. Many will be able to do so at less cost than before. If these doctors were fair dinkum they could go into entirely private practice. They could see only patients who were willing to pay cash and who were willing not to claim from Medicare. They are not willing to do that. What they are willing to do is to make a lot of noise, to refuse to bulk bill and to penalise disadvantaged patients, but I predict that most of them will still take their funds from the pensioner medical service. They will still take their funds from the repatriation service. The professor concerned will still take his considerable salary from the university, a salary which comes out of taxpayers' funds. Those doctors will still continue to take advantage of the subsidies that are paid to private hospitals to treat private patients, but they will still continue to make a lot of noise. As my colleague the Minister for Health said, they will make a lot of noise but they will interrupt that noise occasionally by putting their snouts in the trough of public funding. I consider these people to be dishonest. I point out that the vast majority of medical practitioners in Tasmania did not sign this advertisement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Resources and Energy of the answer he gave with respect to Pancontinental Mining Ltd and its possible entitlement to export uranium. As I recall, he told me that the company had not complied with the foreign investment requirement with respect to the mining and export of uranium. I refer the Minister to the 1981-82 annual report of the then Department of Trade and Resources which stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The Treasurer has approved the foreign investment arrangements for the project- -
That is, the Jabiluka project-

subject to a number of conditions, accepted by the project partners, which will ensure that the Government's policy of a new minimum of 75 per cent Australian equity and Australian control in new uranium projects will be met by the time commercial production commences.

I ask the Minister: Does he still say that the company is not able to proceed because it does not have further approval? Further, will he stop creating smoke- screens in trying to disguise the policy of his Government? If companies such as Pancontinental, Minatome Australia Pty Ltd and Western Mining Corporation Ltd do comply with all the requirements-environmental, price and so on-can they get export permits for the uranium that they are able to sell at acceptable prices on the world market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement from the Treasurer that Senator Chaney has just read said that, subject to certain things happening, the guidelines will have been complied with. Those things have not happened. The fact remains, as I said earlier, that the foreign equity requirements of both the previous and the present Government with respect to that project have not been met. The Treasurer said that if those requirements are met, then yes, the foreign investment, foreign equity or Australian equity requirements will have been met, which seems to me to be rather tortuous tautology. The fact that the foreign investment requirements have not been met was, of course, only incidental to the quite firm and unequivocal answer which I gave to Senator Chaney, and that is that under the recommendation of Cabinet, endorsed yesterday by the parliamentary Labor Party, no new mines other than Roxby Downs will be allowed to proceed. The reason for that-not the entire reason, but the chief reason-is that, in the judgment of the Government, for the next 15 years and possibly to the end of this century, existing mines plus Roxby Downs, if it proceeds, will fill the room which is likely to be available in the world market place for uranium delivered from Australia.
—That is the chief reason?

—That is the chief reason, but it is not the only one. There are other considerations and I suggest that the Opposition should reflect upon these . If we accept that judgment about commercial demand that has been made by the Government-and, granted, it is a judgment, and I remind the Senate that most of the judgments about commercial demand which have been made in the past have been shown subsequently to be over-optimistic or too optimistic, not pessimistic-that there is only room for that quantity of uranium to be delivered from Australia in that time frame, it follows axiomatically that Roxby Downs and Pancontinental are competitive, if not mutually exclusive, and without the sale of the uranium component of its total product I think it could be quite safely asserted that the Roxby Downs mine would not be viable.

ANSWER.PARA: If the Opposition is suggesting-and this is the clear implication of Senator Chaney's question-that Jabiluka or Yeelirrie, if one likes to throw that in, ought to be allowed to proceed and sell anything up to 3,000 tonnes of yellowcake, the probable consequence of that is that the Roxby Downs project would be finished for the foreseeable future. If that is what the Opposition wants to do, to kill off Roxby Downs, it should stand up and say so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let a hundred minds blossom.

—Yes, let a hundred minds blosssom and a hundred schools of thought contend. The employment benefits and the total product benefits of the Roxby Downs mine are very much greater than the same potential benefits from a mine at Jabiluka or Yeelirrie. That is a factor which I suggest any responsible government concerned about the extremely high level of unemployment which exists now and which on any reasonable estimate will persist at a high level for some considerable time ought to take into account.

ANSWER.PARA: It is possible-indeed, it is more than possible; it seems highly probable-that the amount of economic rent in some of those other mines might be greater than the economic rent, if any, which is likely to be generated by Roxby Downs. However, the total value of the product, the amount of employment generated and the boost to economic activity in total from Roxby Downs is very much greater than it would be from any alternative mine supplying the same quantity of uranium, for the simple fact that the preliminary mining proposal put forward for Roxby Downs is one to produce 3,000 tonnes of yellowcake and 150,000 tonnes of copper as well as gold and silver.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs who, I am sure, will agree that Australia, as a rich Western country, provides services and benefits to its ex-service clients which, though unquestionably well deserved, are generous by international standards. This is especially the case if the comparison is made with Third World countries with a large number of war veterans, including disabled war veterans. I ask the Minister: What action is he taking or considering taking in order to assist such countries in meeting their obligations to their war veterans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I completely agree with what the honourable senator has said, that Australia can and does provide for its repatriation clients services and benefits which are probably second to none in the world, certainly well beyond those provided to veterans in Third World countries. I fully recognise also that in this area Australia has an obligation to provide assistance, where it can, to meet the requirements of veteran communities of Third World countries. To that extent, my Department has a particular role to play in respect of disabilities. As a result, we have been requested and have agreed to arrange for three people employed by the Veterans' General Hospital in Bangkok-a doctor, a physiotherapist and an artificial limb technician-to come to Australia for a training program at the Sydney Rehabilitation Artificial Limb and Appliance Centre and the Repatriation General Hospital at Concord. The program will start in February next year and run for approximately three to six months, according to the progress of training. It will concentrate on stump management and artificial limb manufacture.

ANSWER.PARA: Currently, I am examining the possibility of a similar training program for workers from Burma, in respect of which we have been advised that there is a need for such training to cope with the large numbers of soldiers who suffered amputations as a result of booby traps set in that country where, as honourable senators would be aware, a war of sorts has been going on for most of the post World War II period. The Government has every intention of assisting in this training process and, depending upon the success which I believe will be realised in respect of Bangkok, we will extend that program to other Third World countries in our region.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General. I refer to the announcement he made yesterday about the establishment of a National Crimes Authority and ask him: Have all the States made firm commitments to participate in the proposed authority? If not, how many and which States have so far not made such commitment?

—At a round table meeting of State Attorneys-General and Police Ministers on 9 September, a general consensus was reached around the basic elements of the model which has now found its way into legislative form and which will be introduced this week. It is a consensus on the basis that the proposals were regarded by those present as appropriate to take back to their respective Cabinets for formal endorsement. That process is not yet complete, but there are no governments which have rejected in any way the substance of that agreement reached at the meeting on 9 September. I do anticipate that co- operation, albeit with varying degrees of enthusiasm in one or two cases, will in fact be forthcoming. Beyond that I do not think it is appropriate for me to comment at this stage before the round of further consultations and discussions with the States is complete.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs aware of an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 7 November 1983 by Father John Fleming headed 'Parents have the right to choose'? In that article Father Fleming claims :

QUESTION.PARA: The Schools Commission itself has been reconstituted to give effects to the views of Senator Susan Ryan who is known to be unsympathetic to the non- government school system.

He claims further that the Federal Government has moved to reduce financial assistance to private schools and to divert funds back towards the government schools, a point, he claims, that is overlooked by Catholic education officers who think poorer Catholic schools will benefit. Will the Minister put to rest these mischievous and misrepresentative claims and once again put this Government's education policy on record?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether I can put these mischievous and ill-informed criticisms to rest because there are certainly a lot of them around, but I point out to the writer of that article that there are no facts at all with which to substantiate his criticism of me and, by implication, of the Government as being unsympathetic to non-government schools. I simply point again to the increases in recurrent funding for non-government schools, which were of the order of 3 per cent for most such schools-those in category 3-a one per cent real increase for category 2 schools and indexation based on consumer price index increases for the rest of the non-government school sector, with the exception of 41 schools which have a very high level of private income and whose recurrent grants were very modestly reduced. This Government in its first Budget provided a total of $540.6m in recurrent grants alone for the non-government school sector. When we add to that the funds we have spent on special programs for schools operating in that sector the total is $626.9m. I remind the Senate that a total of 2,205 non-government schools receive recurrent grants from this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of other funding decisions have been very helpful and supportive of the non-government school sector. They include the re-introduction of retrospective cost supplementation, which may sound like a technical term but is of great benefit to the non-government school sector, particularly in terms of planning for the future development of schools and for unexpected or unbudgeted- for increases in costs. We have also increased, for secondary children in private schools, the amount of funding by $0.6m in 1984. Disadvantaged schools received an extra $0.3m in 1984. Another very important aspect of the education budget which has affected non-government schools is that we are permitting a 70 per cent forward commitment of capital funds for that sector, which again will assist enormously in the planning of new schools. Again, to assist in the planning and development of new non-government schools, we have budgeted to maintain in real terms 1983 per capita establishment grants for new non- government schools. Non-government schools receiving capital grants since March 1983 number 229. Non-government schools receiving library grants since March 1983 number 121. Since March of this year a total of 46 new non-government schools have been approved by this Government for recurrent funding.

I could go on but I think this series of decisions demonstrates the Government' s commitment to the non-government schools sector-demonstrates that we are prepared to make additional funding available even at a time of economic hardship and stringency, when a number of public sector programs have had to be reduced, or not increased to the extent that this Government would like to see happen. We have made administrative and planning decisions which will assist in the stable and rational use of resources in the non-government sector. Of course , pupils in schools in that sector will all be able to benefit from a number of initiatives which have been undertaken by the Schools Commission. I do not know whether that series of decisions, repeated yet again for the benefit of the Senate, will put to rest the criticisms which have come from certain sources of this Government's approach to the non-government sector. But I suggest that, in light of the realities and the facts of the administrative and funding decisions that we have made, any criticisms or suggestions that this Government or I as the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs in this Government are anything other than supportive of the non-government school sector are entirely without justification.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy whether he is aware of a report in this morning's Australian Broadcasting Corporation's news bulletin that a United States federal grand jury has brought down an indictment against the operators of the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor, saying that, among other things, it falsified reports on the rate of radioactive leaks in the five months prior to the near melt-down of that reactor. Is the Minister aware of a report in the Guardian of 6 November 1983 which states that the rate of leukemia in British children resident near the Windscale nuclear reactor is 10 times above the national average and that plutonium dust from the reactor had been found in people's homes up to 40 miles away in Scotland? Did the Government and Caucus give thorough consideration to the lasting damage to the health of individuals that comes from the nuclear industry when they endorsed the massive expansion of the uranium industry yesterday? Is the Government satisfied that aiding and abetting the nuclear industry and the massive health risks associated with it are worth the short term monetary gain we get in return?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid I have not heard the ABC news report to which Senator Chipp referred. I think he described it as an indictment which, if my understanding of legal jargon is correct, is not a conviction.
—It is a grand jury indictment.
—It is laying the charge.

—Yes, it is not a conviction. I was made aware, I think yesterday, of the claim about Windscale, but at this stage I do not have any definitive comment to make on that. If I have received any definitive information, I have not seen it. The latter part of Senator Chipp's question was whether the Government gave consideration to these matters and the real or alleged dangers associated with the nuclear fuel cycle at various stages. Yes, the Government did give consideration to those matters and the Government is concerned about all those questions. As I said publicly in the Senate last week, I believe every responsible and sane person ought to be concerned about at least the potential dangers of the nuclear fuel cycle. But I suggest that Senator Chipp has taken a quantum leap in assuming that those dangers will be removed or lessened by the total withdrawal of Australia as a source of uranium supply. Granted, there are different interpretations and views of the likely effect on the dangers of the operation of the nuclear fuel cycle, of the storage of the wastes produced by it and the prospect of nuclear war. There are differing interpretations as to the effect of Australia's withdrawal as a uranium supplier on those very real dangers, which I think every sane and responsible person recognises.

ANSWER.PARA: I could not say what particular factors influenced the judgment of every member of the Government or of every member of the parliamentary Australian Labor Party . But the judgment made by the majority of the parliamentary Labor Party I believe reflects the view that the most likely consequences of Australia's immediate and unconditional withdrawal as a supplier of uranium would be as follows: First, that the price of uranium on world markets would marginally increase, but that would not deter anybody who is really determined to make an atomic weapon from doing so; secondly, that potential customers who might otherwise have sourced their requirements from Australia would be more likely or even certain to attempt to source them from countries which will apply few, if any, restrictions or safeguards on the way in which the uranium may be used. Therefore the likely consequence of a complete and unconditional withdrawal of Australia's uranium supply would be marginally to increase the risks associated with the operation of a nuclear fuel cycle, the storage of dangerous waste and the prospect of nuclear war. Admittedly, that is a judgment which everyone may not share, but I believe that the majority of the parliamentary Labor Party concurred with that judgment and that it was a major factor influencing the decision which was made yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Telecom Australia recently announced the letting of contracts for the purchase of 33,000 tonnes of paper for the printing of its 73 different telephone directories in 1984. The contracts have been placed with Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd of Tasmania, Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd of Tasmania and Tasman Pulp and Paper Co. Ltd of New Zealand. In view of the high unemployment in Tasmania, why were some contracts given to New Zealand?

—The Minister for Communications has furnished me with an answer relating to this question of which Senator Hearn had given him notice. I am advised that orders have been placed with the three lowest tenderers and allocated having regard to minimum production requirements and tender rankings. Under the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade treaty, New Zealand content is treated as Australian content. Each tenderer advised Telecom that it would have sufficient capacity to meet the total order. The order allocation, however, also took into account the different types of paper required by Telecom and the need for security of supply, the latter being achieved by spreading the order over the three companies involved. I should point out that Telecom follows established Commonwealth public tendering processes and, where appropriate, other government policies such as closer economic relations, preference and off-sets, and must, under its legislation, achieve value for money. Telecom cannot just allocate orders on an employment in Tasmania basis, and that is the basis on which the tenders were spread, as indicated in the early part of the answer to the question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Leader of the Goverment in the Senate. Is the Minister able to advise the Senate of the effect on the average cost of a new house of the building industry agreement? As this claim has been supported by the Government, is the Minister further able to advise the Senate of the effect on the consumer price index if this additional up to $20 a week were to flow on to analagous work groups as advocated by the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Dolan?

—I am asked whether I have any information about the average cost of a house if the so-called building industry agreement is approved by the conciliation and arbitration system and implemented. No, I do not have any information about the average effect on a house if that agreement were implemented. I do have information which I can obtain for the honourable senator and give her in great detail about what it costs to purchase a house under the present Government compared with what it cost under the Fraser Government. For example, because of this Government's policies, the average mortgage repayments at present are something in the order of $22 per month less than they were under the previous Government.
—What about the wage pause?
—We will hear about the wage pause from people such as Senator Boswell for the next 100 years, I suppose.
—Oh, you will accept responsibility for any rise in interest rates, will you?

—Of course. We have to. I also know that the building industry, and particularly the housing industry, is in better shape than it has been for years. The Government is very optimistic about the future of that industry, as it is entitled to be on the basis of the figures. I am not a mathematician who can calculate average effects of a hypothetical wage increase.
—Twenty dollars a week is the figure and that must have some effect.

—Perhaps Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle should have bided her time in patience to see whether this hypothetical wage increase about which she asked me, in fact, comes to pass. The second question she asked me is what the effect will be on the consumer price index if a $20 a week wage increase not yet granted flows to all other industries. It is quite clear that, whatever happens in the building industry agreement, as far as this Government is concerned it will not flow to all other industries, That question is based on a sort of double-barrelled hypothesis-rather like copulating soldier beetles moving around together. The fact of the matter is that none of these things is likely to happen and they are purely hypothetical questions. I suggest that if those questions become a reality Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle should address the question to me again. As far as the Government is concerned there is no intention that anything which flows out of the building industry agreement will flow to other industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I ask a short supplementary question. I ask the Minister: When supporting the agreement before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, did the Government have any information as to the effect that the increase to the building industry would have on building costs? Was the support of the Government simply a support for the claim itself without any information being given to the Commission on its implications?

—The support of the Government for the building industry agreement, insofar as this Government did support it, was given in order that an industry which has been plagued by industrial unrest for the last five years should have two years of industrial peace. It was supported by the employers and by everybody involved in that industry. It is a matter for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to determine. The Government's support, insofar as it was support from the Government, was also conditional, as I indicated in the earlier answer to the question, upon certain undertakings being given that there be no flow-on of the effects of this agreement to other industries. In those circumstances, I am certainly not in a position to answer the question as it is put.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Minister seen a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald which states that excessive delays are taking place at the Sydney Passport Office by people lodging applications, mainly because of the enforcement of stricter passport control procedures? I ask the Minister: What steps can be taken by the Government to shorten these delays? Will the Government encourage passport applicants to lodge their applications at a post office rather than going to the Sydney Passport Office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report in today's Sydney Morning Herald concerning delays in passport issue at the Sydney Passport Office. It is the case that this Office receives the largest number of passport applications in Australia-over 600 every working day. The article relates to a Monday lunchtime, which, I am advised by the Department of Foreign Affairs, is by far the busiest period as one would expect for all passport offices. While the Office attempts to maintain maximum staffing at this time, staff absences and lunch breaks do mean that it is not possible to man all the interview counters in operation for this period. The usual waiting period in the Sydney office, I am advised, does not exceed 30 minutes. Applications lodged in person are processed in seven working days. If an applicant specifies a need for an urgent passport issue, provision is made to ensure that such a request is met.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been the case since 1 October that Australian passport applications may be lodged, as Senator Sibraa said, at official post offices. This facility is now receiving wide coverage in the daily Press and in travel industry publications which is, in many ways, equally important. There are over 1,400 official post offices throughout Australia. It is clear that the use of this facility will obviate the present pressures faced by passport offices. The Government commends the use of this procedure to passport applicants and hopes, as always, that people take some notice of that commendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. It relates to the Government's espousal of increased participation in higher education as a policy strategy. I ask the Minister: Why will funding restraints make it necessary for universities to offer from 1984, that is, Labor's first year of funding, far fewer first year places-in some cases up to 25 per cent fewer places-than in 1983 which, of course, was the last year of Liberal-National Party Government funding? Because the restrictions could be eased if adequate funds were available, I ask the Minister: Will the Government ensure that funds are sufficient to enable first-year acceptances for 1984 to be at least equal to those of the 1983 level?
—I do not know where Senator Peter Baume has figures suggesting that there will be 25 per cent fewer places offered in 1984.
—It is correct.

—Certainly I have had no such advice from the Tertiary Education Commission, whose job it is to discuss with the various tertiary education institutions throughout Australia how many places they are able to offer. It is the Government's intention-indeed, funds have been made available to this end- that considerably more places be available during 1984. I can only comment that some institutions in areas which are over-supplied with tertiary places, such as some parts of larger cities, may reduce the number of places that they are offering; but, if that were the case, I would expect that many more places would be offered in, for example, the outer western suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne, regional institutions throughout country areas of Australia, and so on. But that sort of adjustment, of course, is a matter for the Tertiary Education Commission to work out, through the Universities Council with the various institutions. It is the intention of the Government that there be more tertiary places available in 1984. It is my expectation that that will be the case, and I have certainly had no advice to the contrary from the Commission.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Minister assuring the Senate that enough funds will be available to ensure, across the system, that at least as many first-year places will be available in 1984 as were available in 1983?
—Funds have already been made available and allocated in the Budget to that effect.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It follows a question asked by Senator Richardson on 22 September relating to increased Indonesian activity in East Timor. Given that figures reporting on the situation put the number of Fretilin members at about 100, will the Minister advise on what direct action has been or will be taken by Australia to do more than express concern at the most recent reports that 10,000 armed Indonesians have been used to repress the activities of the East Timorese people in their own country?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and seek a very early reply.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy . Now that the Government has finally adopted its discriminatory uranium policy favouring the Bannon Labor Government in South Australia, what is the Commonwealth's attitude to the question of compensation for companies which have invested many millions of dollars in exploration and development of prospects, particularly the Koongarra and Jabiluka deposits in the Northern Territory? Has the Government considered the question of compensation for the Aboriginal communities which stood to benefit from royalties flowing from the development of these two deposits, and, if so, what is its attitude? Has the Government had any estimate made of the total losses likely to be incurred by Northern Territory development companies and Aboriginal communities in the Territory? Does the Minister agree with the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy estimate that earnings from existing Territory uranium mines-that is Jabiluka and Koongarra-could be about $9 billion by the year 2000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to do a quick mental calculation on the last part of the question-'$9 billion by the year 2000'.
—That is right.

—Yes, that is about correct if present levels of production and prices were maintained. The loaded terms in which Senator Kilgariff put the earlier part of the question were quite wrong. He spoke of a 'decision favouring the Bannon Labor Government and penalising the Northern Territory' or words to that effect. That, of course, is sheer nonsense. The decision made by the Government was a responsible decision made in the best interests of Australia. We were confronted with a choice of making it possible for the Roxby Downs project to be economically viable or for some alternative uranium prospect of similar output-that is, 3,000 tonnes of uranium oxide per year-to be so. I remind Senator Kilgariff that other prospects in Australia besides Jabiluka have the potential to produce that level of yellowcake, Yeelirrie in Western Australia for one. The Government was faced with the fact that Roxby Downs was certainly competitive with, and possibly mutually exclusive to, any of those other prospects. Yes, it made a decision in favour of Roxby Downs because, as I stated earlier, the total value of product from that mine, given that it is to be primarily a copper mine, is very much greater than it would be from any alternative mine producing the same amount of uranium oxide. Therefore, the total employment generated from that project would be very much greater.

ANSWER.PARA: For those reasons-I notice Senator Chaney looking interested again; I acknowledge to him that that was not the only reason, but I believe it was the major reason for the Government's decision-the Government made a responsible economic decision in the interests of Australia that preference should be given to the Roxby Downs project. I note in closing a point which I should perhaps have made earlier: The concept of sequential development-in other words, an order of priority determined by governments-is not new and was explicitly recommended by the Fox inquiry. I stand open to correction on this, but I thought that, at least at one stage, that principle had been endorsed by the then Liberal-National Party Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Social Security been drawn to a recent article published in the Canberra Times which claimed that the Australian Federal Police is losing experienced investigators to the Department of Social Security and other departments? I ask the Minister: First, is it true that the Department of Social Security has been seeking to employ and is employing experienced officers of the Australian Federal Police? Secondly, is it also true that the Department is using these new employees to help with fraud investigations? Thirdly, has the money offered by the Department to the investigators been far greater than the amount received by the same investigators when previously employed by the Federal Police?

—Yes, my attention was drawn to the statement by Mr Benson, the Secretary of the Australian Capital Territory branch of the Australian Federal Police. No, the statement is not accurate. My Department has not taken any direct action to recruit Australian Federal Police officers. No Australian Federal Police officers have, in fact, been recruited by the Department in recent times. The Department uses computing, statistical and other methods such as visits to claimants by field officers to investigate and identify incorrect social security payments. The most senior investigatory position in the Department currently attracts a salary of $22,000 per annum, whereas I noted that the statement claimed that the Department was offering people salaries of more than $30,000 per annum. Field officer positions recently advertised in Queensland and Victoria offered a salary of $17,500 per annum. These field officers do not carry out the sorts of investigations that were mentioned in the article. Those cases that are not suitable for investigation by the Department, such as cheque offences, for which referral to the Australian Federal Police is necessary without exception in line with Department of Finance directions, major frauds and claims made in multiple names are referred to the Australian Federal Police and are not investigated internally by the Department. There is a series of errors in the statement. It is certainly not correct as far as the Department of Social Security is concerned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. On 22 September, I asked the Minister:

QUESTION.PARA: Are the Treasurer and the Minister aware that considerable success in controlling the white collar crime of arson has been achieved in the United States following the enactment of an arson reporting immunity Bill? In view of this success will the Minister hold talks with the States and the insurance industry in order that similar legislation may be implemented in Australia to assist in combating this serious and fast growing crime?

As I have not yet received a response to that question in respect of which I had an undertaking from the Minister that he would have a reply produced, can he advise whether the matter has been discussed and what is the answer?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid I cannot so advise. I can only apologise to Senator Archer for the delay in providing a response to the question which he asked on 22 September. I will endeavour to do what I can to procure an answer.

—My question, addressed to the Attorney-General, relates to the recent High Court of Australia decision granting the status of a religion to Scientology. Does this judgment extend the ability of individuals or groups to claim religious status as a means of avoiding payment of rates and/or taxes or as a means of circumventing legislation which would otherwise limit their activities? Does the Government intend to take any action to prevent individuals or groups avoiding their responsibilities in this way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whatever one thinks about Scientology, the High Court decision provides a useful and in many ways long overdue clarification as to what constitutes a religion in this country. While the judges were not unanimous in their view, it is clear from the judgments that a religion is not to be confined to the major denominations or to a belief in the existence of a supreme being. At the same time, it is clear from the judgment that bodies which are no more than hoaxes or parodies of religion will not be regarded as religious bodies.
—How do you determine that?

—I appreciate that it will be a close thing in many instances. What exemptions from taxes should be granted to religious bodies is a matter for decision by governments, both Federal and State. The Commonwealth has no plans of which I am aware to reconsider any of its laws in the light of this High Court decision but this may be something to which we will need to pay continuing attention in the light of any response the decision generates. Let me make one further point clear, lest there be misunderstanding about the implications of the decision. The fact that a body has religious status in the sense that it would be recognised as a religion by the High Court on the criteria just enunciated does not make it exempt in any way from the ordinary laws of the land. Justices Mason and Brennan made the point quite clearly in the following terms:

ANSWER.PARA: Conduct in which a person engaged in giving effect to his faith in the supernatural is religious but is excluded from the area of legal immunity marked out by the concept of religion if it offends against the ordinary laws-that is, if it offends against laws which do not discriminate against religion generally or against particular religions or against conduct of a kind which is characteristic only of a religion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Victorian football should qualify.

—Victorian football would have some chance on these criteria but I am not sure whether it involves a commitment to a supernatural being, thing or principle. Maybe it involves a supernatural thing. Clearly we are in the realm of high order metaphysics with this particular judgment and I commend the reading of it to honourable senators. It is highly entertaining in many ways.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has not the Government's apparent foreign policy of 'friends to all and commitments to none' had a backlash from our Association of South East Nations neighbours, Commonwealth countries and significant trade partners? Has such an academic and indifferent approach to the feelings of our treaty countries not resulted in our loss of a significant amount of goodwill and maybe a loss of trading opportunities?

—To the extent that the honourable senator's question seems to amount to some kind of suggestion that ASEAN foreign ministers have suspended ASEAN-Australia dialogue and to the extent that he has based that suggestion on Press reports, it should be said, and said immediately, that those Press reports are incorrect. In practice, the ASEAN-Australian Forum is only one aspect of our dialogue in our relationship with ASEAN, others being the ASEAN, plus foreign ministers, meetings, the ASEAN-Australia consultative meetings and-this is particularly important in the context of the trade relations to which the honourable senator referred-the ASEAN-Australia economic co-operation program. To the extent that there are more specific matters that arise from the honourable senator's question which deserve further reply from either the Minister for Foreign Affairs or the Minister for Trade, I will refer the question to them to see what they might be interested in saying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Earlier in Question Time today, the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, named my spouse as one of the signatories to an advertisement which appeared in a Tasmanian newspaper. During his tirade he mentioned not only my spouse but also Professor Correy, or a professor-there was only one professor, a Professor Correy- who signed the advertisement. Senator Grimes said that the people who signed the advertisement were interested only in penalising the disadvantaged. It is on those grounds that I rise to refute the statement.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I believe that to make a personal explanation at the end of Question Time involves a matter of a personal misrepresentation. Last week the good senator claimed that her spouse had been misrepresented. Now it seems that she is talking about another group of individuals in the community who, she claims, have been misrepresented. I wonder whether we will have the situation where, at the end of every Question Time, honourable senators will seek leave to make a statement of this type. If that is the case, the Government will have to reconsider whether it will give leave with such liberty as it has in the past. Last week the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, sought to claim that someone who had not been a member of parliament for many years was misrepresented. If we like, we can go on like this all day. In the past a personal explanation has been made about a personal misrepresentation.

—Mr President, I rise on the point of order. As a matter of strict correctness, one could properly say that a personal explanation has to relate to the honourable senator claiming to have been misrepresented. Mr President, I draw your attention to the practice which is, it appears to me, growing in the Senate of raising in answers to questions or in debate the associations which honourable senators have with other people, whether they be through marriage or whatever, and the rolling up of general sorts of sneering references to people who have some form of association with senators and members seeking, in the process, to disparage a senator or member.
—Guilt by association.

—An interjection from behind me states that it is a form of guilt by association. Indeed, I think that is what it is. I believe the desire on the part of honourable senators to explain references which have been made to individuals who are personally associated with them-in this case a double association was raised in the answer-arises from that practice which I think is highly undesirable. I would have thought that where an individual is associated with an honourable senator in some way in the course of comment in the Senate and criticism is made of that person as an associate of the honourable senator, then it would be in order for that point to be clarified. To adopt an unduly restrictive ruling in that matter would, I think, be most unfortunate. I agree with the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, that in the end the remedy will come in a refusal to grant leave for honourable senators to make personal explanations. I understand that that is the ultimate check that would be made on any abuse of the personal explanation procedure. I think that in those cases where there is a rolling up of some third party with the name of the honourable senator who seeks to make a personal explanation, some latitude would be desirable.

—Senator Walters claims to have been misrepresented. It was obvious to the Chair when she started to make her remarks that she would have sought leave to make a personal explanation. I then invited her to seek leave to make a personal explanation and leave was given by the Senate. I remind Senator Walters that whilst she is entitled to make a personal explanation, she is not entitled to engage in debate in doing so. I now invite her to complete her personal explanation without debating the matter.

—Thank you, Mr President. As I said, I have risen because of Senator Grimes's statement that the people who signed the petition are interested only in penalising the disadvantaged. I am very proud of my husband. I am very proud of the reputation which he has in my State. I do not think there is anything that Senator Grimes could do in any way to besmirch my husband's reputation. He spent years and years working in an honorary capacity at the Royal Hobart Hospital. He gave one and a half days of his time every week in an honorary capacity-and when I say that I mean completely honorary capacity-until 1972 or 1973, I think, when the position was finally done away with. I do not expect Senator Grimes to understand what is behind the thinking of people like my husband who are willing to give of their time without any payment whatsoever to care for people. I do not expect Senator Grimes to understand that. However, I refute the suggestion that people, including my husband, who signed the petition are interested only in penalising the disadvantaged. These people have worked for nothing, year after year, looking after people who are disadvantaged.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Grimes also mentioned Professor Correy. Professor Correy, likewise, gave 20 years of his time in an honourary capacity-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest to Senator Walters that she is now starting to debate the explanation.
—Could I speak to that point, please, Mr President?
—Order! Senator Walters, I invite you to make a personal explanation and in doing so you are entitled to make that personal explanation in respect of yourself.
—Thank you, Mr President. Professor Correy is a very close colleague of my husband and a very close friend of mine.
—I suggest to the honourable senator that if she wishes to make remarks of this nature she do so during the adjournment debate this evening.
—Mr President, could I seek leave to make a very short statement ?

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much. I thank Senator Button for granting me leave.
—It was Senator Grimes.
—I thank Senator Grimes.
—I grant it on the basis of a special relationship with Professor Correy.

—I will not answer that or it might appear in Hansard. Similarly , Professor Correy worked for 20 years in an honorary capacity at the Royal Hobart Hospital. He has now reached the height of his profession as Professor of Obstetrics and Gynaecology at the University of Tasmania. He is a member of the National Health and Medical Research Council and is the second President of the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists and consequently is held in very high regard by all Tasmanians and by all his colleagues, obviously with the exception of Senator Grimes. He has chosen to take a salaried position as professor. As such, it is true-and this applies to the other people whom Senator Grimes tried to write down-that he accepts a salary from the Government. But he believes in free enterprise. He does not believe in the nationalisation of doctors. It is for that reason that Professor Correy signed that declaration. His statistical research on infant death and mother mortality has been taken as a model throughout the whole of Australia. He has done more work in the medical sphere for this country than Senator Grimes will do in a lifetime in this Parliament. It ill becomes Senator Grimes to make statements such as he made, particularly in relation to these two fine men, but also, indeed, in relation to any of the other people who signed that petition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Walters has tried to make out of the answer to the question a personal attack by me denigrating the professional esteem of the two doctors she mentioned. As it happens, I have been closely associated with one of those doctors for 20 years. As for the other doctor, as Senator Walters may well know, I have no argument with his professional capacity. In fact, he delivered my son. I think I know both of them pretty well. I do not know Senator Walters's spouse as well as she does but I certainly know Professor Correy very well. What I do know and respect is their professional ability. Where our differences lie is in our politics. I do not necessarily respect or agree with their politics.

SPEECH.PARA: When those two doctors and the other doctors signed the advertisement they signed, they signed it in a political capacity. They claimed that what this Government was doing was nationalising medicine. It clearly is not. They claimed that what this Government was doing was preventing them from delivering private medical practice to their patients, which it clearly is not. In making those political statements, in getting into the political kitchen, they have to accept the fact that there will be a bit of heat and that they will get a reply. They got a reply. I wish Senator Walters would recognise that. When she tries to paint anything I said as denigrating them professionally, I think she is the one who is playing that party political game.

In finishing this explanation I say what I said before. When one of the other signatories to that letter, as a member of a medical organisation, signed an advertisement in the 1980 elections urging people to vote against the Australian Labor Party I got stuck into him too. He rang me, and he accepted that he was playing politics and that he had to cop it back. All that is published I say is that if any of those people wish to sign an advertisement denigrating this Government or this Party they will get a reply from me-I believe that they know that they will get a reply from me-of that type. It is reasonable for me to point out that people such as that, who apparently denigrate government interference in medicine and government participation in the delivery of medical supplies and at the same time accept considerable incomes from the same public purse, are being inconsistent. That is all I said and that is all I will say in the future. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The study was initiated by the previous Government and undertaken by the Department of Resources and Energy under the direction of an independent steering committee. Detailed information was supplied by eleven consultants in thirteen reports. Discussions were held with water authorities in all states and some 140 submissions were received in response to a public invitation. The report indicates that, in general terms. Australia has sufficient surface and underground water resources to meet anticipated needs to the year 2000, and while regional or local shortages already occur and will continue, these can be overcome by long-term planning and increased expenditure. The study identifies eight major issues facing the water industry over the next two decades. They are : Protection and improvement of water quality; more efficient use of currently available water supplies; the conservation of existing water supplies by more appropriate allocation and financial policies; co-ordinated management and use of water and land resources; adequate provision for in-stream uses; improvements in data collection and analysis and information dissemination; provision of adequate funding for water resources purposes, including research; continuing Commonwealth Government involvement.

The Government's 1983 election policy included a commitment to determine national water resource priorities on the basis of this report. Discussions have already been held with the States in the Australian Water Resources Council on the main issues raised in the report, and their views will be taken into account by the Government in formulating its response to the report.

The report draws attention to the general neglect of water supplies for country towns, many of which are quantitatively and qualitatively inadequate, the latter sometimes to the point of being a health hazard. The Government shares this concern. $20 million has been appropriated in the 1983 Budget for the twin purposes of stimulating employment and arresting previous neglect of water supplies to country towns. The provision of water supplies is however primarily a State Government responsibility.

It also notes that traditional pricing and other policies have favoured irrigators-who use 74% of all water-to the detriment of country town residents. Moreover pricing policies have encouraged irrigation practices which are economically wasteful and sometimes environmentally damaging. The report is explicitly critical of these policies and recommends changes (see 6.26, 6.27 and 6.30). The government notes with satisfaction that some State Governments have made policy changes in accord with these recommendations.
Many generations of Australians have imbibed the conventional wisdom that irrigation will drought-proof the country. This belief is explicitly refuted by the report:

'Irrigation development of itself does not mitigate the effects of drought. It may even exacerbate the effects of drought if heavily stocked irrigation properties are subject to water supply restrictions. Fodder produced under irrigation is mainly for on-farm use, and sales of fodder are insignificant in the context of demand under drought conditions.'
Finally, it is recommended that in irrigation development, priority be given to the completion of projects already under construction.

The appropriation of $46 million in this year's Budget marks the completion of the previous Government's national water resources program. The 'Water 2000' report will provide the basis for new water resource policies and programs to ensure a more effective allocation of funds to meet clearly defined objectives to deal with issues raised in this report of particular concern to the Commonwealth. In this context, I refer to arrangements for establishing an interim council to examine the case for an institute of freshwater studies, and discussions now in progress with the states on a new Commonwealth/States water resources assessment program.

Copies of the thirteen reports prepared by consultants will be lodged with the parliamentary library and libraries throughout Australia which provide a particular focus on water resources. Copies of the report now being tabled are available through commercial outlets of the Australian Government Publishing Service in the capital cities, and there is also a limited number of the consulant's reports available through these outlets.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The 209th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts is an examination of reports of the Auditor-General 1980-81.
