SPEECH.PARA: Public hearings on 20 May 1982 occurred in respect of the Department of Finance in relation to expenditure in excess of warrants of the Governor-General and closing of accounts at year end, including moneys unbanked, and in respect of the Department of Social Security in relation to the national benefits system and assistance for homeless persons.

PROCTEXT.PARA: EXPENDITURE IN EXCESS OF THE GOVERNOR-GENERAL'S WARRANT

The Auditor-General noted that payments in 1980-81 from the Commonwealth public account, charged to the Consolidated Revenue Fund under a special appropriation provided by the States Grants (Tertiary Assistance) Act 1978, had exceeded by $5 ,100,372, the amount specified in the warrants of the Governor-General. Although expenditure in excess of appropriation was not involved, a further warrant should have been obtained from the Governor-General before moneys were withdrawn from the Commonwealth Public Account for the purposes of the appropriation.
CLOSING OF ACCOUNTS AT YEAR END

A major objective of the Department of Finance accounting system is the production of accurate financial statements pursuant to sections 49 and 50 of the Audit Act 1901. In this context the closing of accounts at year end is an important process. An important audit objective of the closing of accounts procedures is to provide assurance that the receipts and payments of the financial year are reflected in the annual financial statements. In this regard the Auditor-General considered that the incidence and variety of deficiencies disclosed in 1980-81 suggest that adherence to the closing of accounts directions is inadequate in some departments.
NATIONAL BENEFITS SYSTEM

The Auditor-General's 1980-81 report referred to an in-depth audit of the national benefits system undertaken during the period from October 1980 to January 1981. As a result of the investigations, the Auditor-General reported that he considered that the development of the national benefits system was not adequately controlled and, to some extent, did not proceed in accordance with generally accepted practice. The Committee considers that the NBS project was inadequately controlled and recommends that the Department should in future ensure that adequate records are kept to ensure proper asessment of the cost- effectiveness of such projects. The Committee also recommends that the management and implementation of large automatic data processing projects such as the NBS be under the overall control of one individual senior officer, to be designated as the project manager, with sufficient delegated authority to ensure the project's success; in addition, that for all future pilot projects the Department develop an integrated pre-implementation testing procedure covering ADP system logic, support machinery and staff training. The Committee will continue to monitor the overall operational effectiveness of the national benefits system.
ASSISTANCE FOR HOMELESS PERSONS

In his report of 30 March 1981 the Auditor-General referred to an in-depth audit of capital assistance grants, under the Homeless Persons Assistance Act 1974, to two organisations for the construction of homeless persons centres. The assertion was made that one of these projects appeared to represent significantly less value for money as a homeless persons centre than the other. Identified as the most significant contributing factor to this situation was the failure of the Department of Social Security to promulgate standards and guidelines for use by organisations in establishing and constructing such projects with capital assistance provided under the Act. Subsequent matters raised by the Auditor-General were mainly related to the future administration of the homeless persons assistance program.

It was suggested by some that costs per bed could measure the value for money of homeless persons projects. The Committee considered that a direct comparison of average costs per bed is not an entirely valid guide to 'value for money' for homeless persons centres. The Committee concludes that emphasis on a cost per head basis ignores the other important functions that are provided by homeless persons projects and suggests that for cost comparison purposes, where multipurpose complexes are involved, a formula be developed on the basis of weighted averages between overnight accommodation and other facilities, and services provided. The Committee approves of detailed departmental standards and guidelines which organisations and their architects are required to observe when planning, designing and constructing homeless persons facilities, as a guide to the nature and extent of Commonwealth financial assistance.

The Committee recommends that detailed departmental standards and guidelines be incorporated, along with physical building standards and guidelines, into a comprehensive program manual. The Committee does not suggest that there should be complete standardisation in the facilities or design of homeless persons centres but rather that the Department draw on experience with both homeless persons and nursing home programs to develop a program manual. The Committee considers that a program manual would be of immeasurable assistance and guidance both to organisations embarking on homeless persons projects and to the departmental staff evaluating and administering the program, without sacrificing the necessary degree of flexibility required for the successful development and administration of community welfare projects. The Committee also recommends that the Department of Housing and Construction provide a design service to organisations embarking on a homeless persons project. The design services would include evaluation of the architectural design plan in terms of compliance with the program manual. I commend the report to honourable senators.

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 to enable the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to give effect to principles agreed between the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments relating to the day to day management of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Honourable senators will be aware that comprehensive protection of the Great Barrier Reef has long been our policy. It was a Labor Government which put in place the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act in 1975. Since coming to power in March this year, the Government has given life to the provisions of that Act. Zoning plans for the Cairns and Cormorant Pass sections of the marine park were tabled in May 1983 and I expect them to come into operation later this month. In August three further sections of the marine park were proclaimed, with proclamations for two further sections coming into effect on 30 October 1983. The addition of these sections means that this Government has increased from 14 per cent to 98.5 per cent the portion of the Great Barrier Reef Region included in the marine park. Approximately 344,000 square kilometres of the region is now marine park. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park is by far the world's largest marine park.

In addition to proclaiming areas of the marine park, the Government introduced in September 1983 regulations to prohibit oil drilling in those small parts of the Great Barrier Reef region not included in the marine park. Recovery of minerals, including oil drilling, is prohibited in the marine park by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act. In 1981 the Great Barrier Reef was inscribed on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation World Heritage List, thereby bringing international recognition to the importance and uniqueness of this vast complex of coral reefs and their associated life forms. While these initiatives are vital to the protection of the Great Barrier Reef, a significant action the Government must take to guarantee the Reef's protection is to strengthen the management arrangements with the Queensland Government. It is with this intention in mind that this Bill has been introduced in Parliament.

The basis of agreement between the Queensland and Commonwealth Governments for day to day management of the marine park provides for the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service to undertake management of the marine park subject to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. The Commonwealth is to fund 100 per cent of an initial capital works program for each section of the marine park , with all other capital and recurrent costs of management of the marine park being shared equally between the two governments. With regard to Queensland national and marine parks within the outer boundaries of the marine park, Queensland is to fund 100 per cent of the costs of the capital works with the recurrent costs for management being shared equally between the two governments. The agreement also provides for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to administer funds from both Governments for these purposes.

Under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act as currently drafted, the Marine Park Authority cannot administer funds for the purposes described in the basis of agreement. This Bill will enable the Marine Park Authority to fully implement the agreed management and cost-sharing arrangements. In addition, clause 3 (b) of the Bill ensures that the Marine Park Authority will be able to contribute to complementary management of Queensland national and marine parks adjacent to or near the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and other areas judged to be intimately associated with the marine park. Such areas are inseparable from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. The additional cost to the Commonwealth from this extension is estimated to be $200,000 per annum.

The Bill also contains minor amendments with regard to tabling and disallowance of zoning plans. Clause 4 of the Bill provides for two amendments to section 33 of the principal Act. The first is to ensure that zoning plans are tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the plans have been accepted by the Minister. This amendment, while not precluding early tabling of zoning plans, will guarantee there are no undue delays. The second of the amendments in section 33 is to reduce the disallowance period for zoning plans from 20 to 15 sitting days. This amendment brings section 33 into line with tabling provisions in other legislation and provides for adequate time for the Parliament to consider zoning plans while enabling the plans to come into operation earlier.

Some eight years ago, the then Minister for the Environment, Dr Cass, introduced the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Bill. The first section of the marine park, the Capricornia section, was proclaimed in 1979, followed by the Cairns and Cormorant Pass sections in 1981. Proclamations were announced on 31 August 1983 of three further sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, namely the far northern, central and southern sections. These three sections of the Marine Park cover that area of the region north of the Cairns sections and the main reef structures south of the Cairns section not covered by the Capricornia section. The Townsville and inshore southern sections of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park were declared by proclamation of the Governor-General on 30 October 1983. These declarations now complete the establishment of Australia's Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. The two new sections cover an area of approximately 68,000 square kilometres and include waters inshore of the central, southern and Capricornia sections, between the Cairns section in the north and the Great Barrier Reef region boundary in the south.

The criteria used to determine the inclusion of areas in these sections were as follows: Areas where there are significant fringing or inshore reefs or areas of coral growth; areas adjacent to land areas which are subject to conservational management, such as national parks; critical habitats of endangered species, such as major dugong feeding areas and turtle nesting areas; areas which are important to the conservation of species of the Great Barrier Reef region, such as breeding or nursery areas of fish, or of prawns and other invertebrates; and heavily-used tourist areas associated with the natural resources of the Great Barrier Reef region.

Existing or potential port areas and areas adjacent to significant agricultural , industrial or urbanised areas were excluded from the Marine Park. Unless there are overriding conservational reasons, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority did not seek the inclusion of port areas in the Marine Park because the involvement of the authority in port administration would not be practicable and the use of the western boundary of the Great Barrier Reef region as a boundary for the entire length of the Queensland mainland could have placed unnecessary restrictions on Queensland local authorities and involve the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in minor administrative matters. The total prohibition of other activities, such as the commercial extraction of sand or gravel from close to the shore, may not be warranted on ecological grounds. Common sense dictates that this would be an excessive Commonwealth Government restriction on normal state activities.

Some concern has been expressed that parts of the Great Barrier Reef region left out of the marine park may be unprotected. A major fear was that drilling for oil could occur in these areas. To ensure that this does not happen, by regulations effective as of 1 September 1983, we have prohibited oil drilling in these areas. Should there be any proposals for developments in these excluded areas in the future which might adversely affect the Great Barrier Reef or the marine park, we will act quickly under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 to ensure control of the proposed development.

The Great Barrier Reef region has been acknowledged by the Commonwealth Government as a priority research area. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has responsibilities for carrying out or arranging for research relevant to the marine park, for co-ordinating research in the region and for reporting the findings to both the Australian and Queensland governments, through the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council. The Authority also participates in the Australian Marine Research in Progress program and conducts programs which complement research by other organisations and individuals. The Authority will be funding about 60 research and monitoring projects in 1983-84, costing about $360,000.

The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 requires the Authority to prepare zoning plans for areas that have been declared to be parts of the marine park and to recommend regulations that should be made under the Act. On 26 May zoning plans were tabled for the Cairns and Cormorant Pass sections of the marine park- an area of some 35,000 square kilometres. These zoning plans are to come into operation on 7 November 1983. The existing regulations applying to the Capricornia section are to be repealed and replaced by general regulations applying to all the zoned sections of the marine park.

The Authority began on 1 September 1983 a public participation program seeking representations regarding the zoning for the far northern section-approximately 80,000 square kilometres or 24 per cent of the reef region. I urge all interested individuals or organisations to respond to this invitation. As soon as is practicable, the Authority will be developing zoning plans for the areas south of the Cairns section. As part of Authority policy to review zoning plans every five years, the zoning plan for the Capricornia section will be reassessed in 1986. The zoning and management plans developed by the Authority are derived from the belief that opportunity for human enjoyment and use of the reef should be maximised, consistent with the conservation of the natural qualities of the reef which give it its unique value. The marine park is also an excellent example of Commonwealth-State co-operation. The officers of the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service carry out management policy for the Authority and a number of Queensland agencies contribute in the development of policies for the region.

Tourism is a significant growth sector in our economy. The Great Barrier Reef region and adjacent mainland centres currently attract approxiamtely two million visitor trips per annum, with 150,000 of these to the island resorts. Recently, there have been a number of expressions of interest by companies and individuals in establishing additional tourist facilities directly on the Great Barrier Reef , providing tourists with alternative access to the reef. The Government is aware of these proposed developments and recognises the need to facilitate access to the reef. Accordingly, this is a matter being examined by the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council.

An extensive commercial fishery, largely for prawns, is dependent on the living resources of the reef region as is the recreational fishing, mainly for reef fish and mackerel. The commercial fisheries catch in the Great Barrier Reef region in 1979-80 was estimated to be in the order of $30m for approximately 8.5 million kilograms of product. The recreational catch in the same year was estimated to be of the order of seven million kilograms of product. To impart knowledge of the reef and to create a caring attitude to this unique natural wonder are among the challenges of the program of management. A balance must be struck between the various interest groups which make proposals concerning the use of the reef, and conservation of the reef's natural qualities. The underlying philosophy is management by education. It is recognised that there must be rules and regulations, and penalties for breaches, but ultimately the success of the park will depend on people accepting the need for management and co-operating by regulating their own activities themselves.

The Authority places great emphasis on establishing and maintaining liaison with the many and diverse user groups that depend on the resources of the Great Barrier Reef. Intensive public participation programs have been conducted in connection with the zoning of each section of the marine park. The Authority recognises that regular users of the reef have a wealth of information which can supplement that of scientists and managers. Daily aerial surveillance of the Great Barrier Reef is conducted in order to protect the reef from illegal activities and marine pollution.

The Great Barrier Reef is accorded a well deserved place as one of the great wonders of the world. It is the largest and most complex expanse of living coral reefs on earth. Encompassing many unique forms of marine life, over 1,500 species of fish and more than 400 species of coral, the reef has for ages been a rich part of the environmental heritage of all Australians including the Aboriginal peoples who have fished its bounty for thousands of years. Australia' s Great Barrier Reef Marine Park is truly an outstanding achievement in the world-wide attempt to establish a balance between our use of natural resources and the conservation of the environment upon which our very existence and the quality of that existence depend.

In concluding, I wish to emphasise that while the Government has made the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park a reality, the tremendous task of managing the marine park lies before us. The provisions of this Bill will give strength to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority with regard to complementary management arrangements with Queensland and streamline procedures for bringing into force zoning plans for the marine park. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

It is therefore possible for an overseas visitor to enrol in a fund on arriving in Australia, and after serving the required waiting period, obtain benefits from the fund. SPEECH.PARA: Under the Medicare program, visitors to Australia will be eligible for Medicare benefits if they are permitted to be in Australia for more than six months. This is because separate statistics are not maintained for these clams at the various stages of processing. Claims received from Tasmania are counted on receipt and allocated batch numbers which identify their State of origin. All batches of claims, that is Victorian and Tasmanian, are then processed in order of the date of batching. Claims which are rejected and need to be re-examined are dealt with in the processing run order.

However, the bans on the dispatch of cheques to doctors in private hospitals in Victoria and Tasmania were lifted on 3 November 1983. All cheques held up as a result of the work bans have now been posted.
Senator Teague raised some questions in relation to the Medicare levy. The office of the Commissioner of Taxation has provided the following information:

In debate on the Appropriation Bill No. 1 on 3 November, Senator Teague asked whether there was an anomaly in the operation of the Medicare levy in its application to the case of Defence Force personnel and their families. Senator Teague cited for comparison the cases of a serviceman with a working wife and another whose wife has no separate income. He suggested that it was anomalous for the serviceman to be required to pay half levy in respect of his spouse and the dependent children in each of those cases when in the former case the working wife was also required to pay Medicare levy on her own taxable income.

By way of explanatory comment, the general operation of the levy in the two circumstances identified by Senator Teague is accurately described. A serviceman who qualifies for free medical care under Defence Force medical arrangements but whose dependants are not covered by those arrangements is required to pay levy at half rates. It is also true that such a serviceman's wife who has a separate taxable income will also pay levy at the normal rate of that income, subject to the application of the family income threshold and the upper ceiling as appropriate to the case.

Leaving aside any reductions or effective exemptions through the operation of the threshold and ceiling, the Medicare levy rate is, in its general operation, set at a flat one per cent of a person's taxable income. In a one-income family, that one per cent is paid by the income recipient: in a two-income family both income recipients pay one per cent of their respective taxable incomes. Essentially then, the initial calculation of levy paid by each individual taxpayer is made without regard to family circumstances-those circumstances being relevant only in application of the thresholds and ceiling.

Seen in the context of the general operation of the levy, the fact that a Defence serviceman with one or more dependants, including a working spouse, is required to pay half levy compares favourably with the position that both income recipients in a two-income family not covered by free medical arrangements are required to pay the full levy.

Senator Walters sought details in relation to the increase in staff numbers from 1982-83 to 1983-84 for the Department in the categories of permanent staff, temporary staff and part time staff. The number of permanent, temporary and part time staff employed by the Department of Health on 30 June 1983 was 4,343 permanent, 407 temporary and 72 part time respectively. At 30 September 1983 the corresponding figures were 4,341 permanent staff, 476 temporary staff and 110 part time staff. These numbers represent officers actually working and do not include those on long term leave, sick leave, long service leave and the like. The increase in the numbers of temporary and part time staff was mainly the result of general increases in recruitment and the employment of staff to assist in the processing of the backlog of bulk-billed medical benefit claims.

Senator Peter Baume sought information as to the current situation in regard to the pharmaceutical cyclophosphamide, which has been removed from the pharmaceutical benefits list. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has removed cyclophosphamide tablets and injections from the list. This action results from a failure to resolve a pricing disagreement with the manufacturer. The firm concerned, Bristol-Myers Co. Pty Ltd, the Australian subsidiary of a large international company, unilaterally implemented large increases for the prices to chemists of the range of cyclophosphamide preparations. The Government is not able to control manufacturers' prices for pharmaceutical benefits and, when faced with unilateral price action on the part of firms, has the option of either paying the increased prices or removing the items from the list. If the other firms with pharmaceutical benefits system-listing drugs were similarly to increase their prices, the additional cost to the Government would be over $400m a year. The current PBS drug price arrangements rely for their success on co- operation between the Government and the pharmaceutical manufacturers. In this case the co-operation of the firm concerned was not forthcoming. It has not been prepared to compromise on the prices it charges for these preparations. If the firm were to revert to acceptable prices the Government would be happy to return promptly the products to the benefits list. The Government is sympathetic to those patients affected and the Minister for Health is examining changes to the PBS drug pricing arrangements which could minimise the adverse financial effects of this situation on patients. In the meantime, there is no provision in the National Health Act for financial assistance or part subsidy to persons meeting the cost of drugs such as cyclophosphamide which are not on the benefits list. In the meantime the Minister suggests that as most cyclophosphamide used in Australia is supplied through public hospitals, patients may be able to arrange for their supplies from those sources. The Minister will be writing shortly providing more detailed information as to arrangements made in that area.

I suggest to the Government and to Senator Walsh that there is no need to await some brilliant new tax to follow that principle. It would be quite open to him to adjust the present systems of imposts and levies upon, say, the coal industry, if the Government wished such rational economic principles to apply. It is important that we examine very carefully any propositions that might be put forward against the realities within which any policy would have to operate. We have to remember for a start that it is unlikely that the tax can be imposed on a single homogenous product. We have to remember that this tax will be imposed on companies. It will have to be imposed on companies which are operating in a variety of commercial arrangements, sometimes as sole traders, sometimes as joint venturers and perhaps, occasionally, in partnership. We have to remember that any tax, when applied, will have to fit within the very complicated Commonwealth-State arrangements which we have in a federal Australia.

There was a hint-perhaps more than a hint-in a recent response from Senator Walsh, that perhaps the Government has really given up on the proposition of a resource rent tax imposed and administered by the Commonwealth in relation to commodities other than oil. TALK.START.PARA: —I have some notes on it.

In each of the latter two cases, as I understand it, the arrangements were made by the former Liberal State Governments. The caution is that in each of the examples that I have mentioned one has not a general tax regime which the industry can look at and say: 'That is the regime under which we will have to invest'. I do not think that is an insurmountable obstacle because a properly functioning Commonwealth Grants Commission, at least at the time a review is made, ought to be capable of taking into account structural changes in the taxation system which affect the revenue capacity of the Commonwealth vis a vis the States and the relative revenue raising capacities between the States.

In saying that I note with regret that, in my view anyway, the Commonwealth Grants Commission has not always properly addressed itself to that question. Indeed, in a report issued in, I think, June 1981 the Grants Commission, in my view, seriously misunderstood the concept of taxing effort in that it concluded that because Queensland was making a greater taxing effort than other States, particularly with coal, in imposing both high royalty charges and rail freight charges in excess of the actual cost of supply, it therefore ought to be rewarded by higher Commonwealth grants. The effect of the taxing arrangements there was to ensure that at certain points in the production scale a loss was incurred when one moved from one level of production to another because a change in the rate of levy was imposed.

There was general agreement that the black hole situation was illogical and needed to be removed. Under Senator Sir John Carrick work was being done, as I understand it, between the Department and industry to achieve a more sensible arrangement. But the fact is that the more sensible arrangement which was brought in by the present Government was an arrangement which also raised considerable additional revenue and, with respect to the Bass Strait producers, as I understand it, involved fairly considerable imposts. I guess that they recovered some of those imposts for at least the time being in overturning the pipeline arrangements in Victoria. I seek some assurance from the Minister that, in making rearrangements, he will adhere to the views on replacement tax which he has expressed in the Senate and elsewhere and not use the resource rent tax, if it is introduced, on even off-shore oil as a means of, in fact, considerably increasing the impost which the Government places on the industry. In other words, it is one thing to produce a more rational, more logical and more economically efficient system but it is another thing, under that guise, simply to impose large additional imposts on an industry which is already very heavily taxed. I seek an assurance from the Minister for Resources ane Energy that the making of changes will not be simply a cover for very significant traditional revenue raising. I was also interested in the Minister's comment that present State charges are usually in excess of the rent which is accruing to-

TALK.START.PARA: —Right now.

—Senator Walsh says 'right now'. I understand the Minister's interjection because, of course, we are at a time of low profitability. Therefore, on the theory he is advancing obviously much less economic rent is available. I am curious about his remark because it suggests to me that the Minister does have in mind some fairly definite figures as to at what interest rate investment would be attracted; in other words, the point of entry to the resource rent tax. It is in fact that sort of information which I think will need to be exposed by the Minister if we are to get rational and informed public debate about what the Government might have in mind. I would be interested to know whether, in any assessment the Minister has made of the imposts which are made upon State charges, any precise figuring is involved or whether he is simply making a broad statement which is based on the fact that at a time of low commodity prices and, of course, steeply rising costs within Australia, including some government imposed cost rises, he is aware of the fact that the profitability of most sections of the industry is pitifully low. SPEECH.PARA: Another point the Minister made was that it is not important which agent imposes the tax but rather it is the taxing system which is important. He said that a lot of the arguments in this area are specious. That seems to me to make as generous a theoretical assumption as the theoretical assumption that underlies the Government's whole approach to this resource rent tax. The Minister said quite explicitly that he was approaching the matter on the assumption that one had a Commonwealth Grants Commission which was properly functioning. I would appreciate any advice the Minister can give us as to whether the Government has in mind changing the operations of the Grants Commission and, in particular, whether the Government has in mind, if it does get a properly functioning Grants Commission, making automatic the application of Grants Commission findings. I think Senator Walsh will be aware of the very great political difficulties which accrue when there are substantial shifts in taxing arrangements, no matter how well justified those shifts might be in terms of economic theory. The fact is that there are rates of change which are very hard to impose above a certain rate for sheer practical reasons-systems are in place, administrative arrangements are in place and costs are in place. It does seem to be one of the defects of the Commonwealth Public Service, if I may say so, particularly in the Department of the Treasury, that there is often a failure to take into account simple practical reality-what is on the ground and what is functioning-in the belief that great shifts can be made on the basis of some macroeconomic theory without regard to reality on the ground. I would say that the Minister's suggestion that a lot of the argument is specious is in fact a suggestion which is based on a view as to how the system can operate and will operate under his Government. That argument is in itself specious. I would appreciate his comment on that point.

I return to the resource rent tax more generally and the proposition that the Government will impose a resource rent tax in the area of oil or, at a minimum, in the area of off-shore oil production. I put it to the Committee that one needs to bear in mind the practical realities which face us in the market place and the effect that that proposal can have on exploration. I am conscious of the fact that I make these comments in the context of probably three or four months of the best news that the exploration industry has had since 1978. We have had the Jabiru find and a series of lesser very positive results from the exploration activity that has been going on in the last couple of years.

The fact of the matter is that Australia is not seen as an intensely prospective target. The fact of the matter is that the new oil policy, on all the evidence I have been able to obtain, is an important element in maintaining incentive to bring people to Australia and to keep them here putting their money into the very expensive business of exploring, particularly off-shore. Quite clearly, if a resource rent tax on oil is introduced, even on offshore oil, that will of itself reduce the average return which can be expected from investment in oil exploration in Australia. There is no other mathematical possibility. If we lop off more of the peaks then we lower the average rate of return. This must affect incentive. It must affect the figuring of those who have to work out where they are going to put their money in an industry which more often produces a zero result than a major profit. It was put to me very well the other day by an oil explorer who said: 'One of the major problems this industry has is that there is too much oil in Fortescue'. Of course, all that he was saying was that the existence of Fortescue, that very large pool of oil, which will, of course be very profitable to those who have it once it is extracted and sold, is, of course, a great temptation to the Government. It is the desire to get some greater slice of that, beyond 46c in the dollar which accrues in the way of normal income tax, that is, I am sure, at the heart of this push for a resource rent tax on oil. I put it to the Minister that whilst, from a revenue gathering point of view, that is a very tempting target it does need to be remembered that from the point of view of justifying the very large expenditure which is involved in oil exploration, it is the possibility of the occasional very good result which keeps explorers in the field.

I express concern about the extent to which the Government is taking into account the need to maintain a high level of interest in oil exploration in Australia. I think we run a very great risk of responding too much to the fact that in 1983 there is something of an oil glut around the world, there is an excess of petrol and there is a sense that the importance of the oil search has levelled off. That, of course, will be added to by the very hopeful news which has come from Jabiru over the last month or two. I want to say very seriously to the Minister in this Committee debate that one can respond too much to the immediate situation. I think that it is in the longer term interests of Australia that we should not take action which will discourage oil exploration in what is not a particularly prospective continent.

The last point I want to make at this time is that I ask the Minister for some response on the point that resource rent tax does promote inefficiency in one important respect. If a resource rent tax is imposed on a highly profitable project the fact is that the managers of that project will, to some extent at least, lose incentive in maintaining a high level of efficiency and a high level of cost consciousness.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall work seriatim through the points raised by Senator Chaney. —Well, I am really asking for a clearer statement. You can put aside the loaded word and substitute some other word. I really want to know the facts.

—It is important to put on record the fact that discussions are proceeding right now-I do not know about 'right now', but discussions have been held between the Commonwealth Government and the New South Wales Government to see whether agreement can be reached on a superior system of taxation for Broken Hill, because it is acknowledged by the producers and by both governments that the existing tax arrangements are impeding the development of a new ore body. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney also referred to the apparent change from a confrontationist approach by the Australian Labor Party to the States a couple of years ago on this question to one of agreement. I believe that he is correct in reaching that conclusion, although I should add that the Commonwealth would probably review its attitude if, for example, we had reached agreement with six States on a particular taxation change and only one State, or even conceivably one Territory , were precluding the application of what everybody else had agreed to do. The Commonwealth might then have to consider more coercive action, which would probably have to be indirect but, nevetheless, coercive against the one State which was out of step.

It is correct, as Senator Chaney has siad, that the new system introduced was not entirely revenue neutral. There was a marginal gain to Commonwealth revenue vis-a-vis the system which it had replaced. TALK.START.PARA: —Different producers are affected, perhaps.

—As I said, I am not sure how one measured up against the other. This takes us to a much more important point. The Bass Strait producers had revised and significantly increased their estimate of production from the excise -free Fortescue field. The Government's view was that it would have been a serious breach of what had been bipartisan policy for almost eight years to impose a levy on the Fortescue field. There was, however, no moral problem for the Labor Party in imposing a rent tax on Fortescue, because it has been explicit Labor Party policy ever since 1977 that there would be a rent tax and that the distinction between new and old oil would disappear. In that context, and also in the context of a desperate need for revenue, the Government made a decision not to attempt to impose a rent tax or excise on Fortescue, even at the increased level of production. It made a judgment to extract, through the new levy arrangements somewhat more revenue from existing fields, than would have been extracted under the old arrangements. On balance, I do not believe that the producers have done too badly out of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney asked for an assurance that if or when the rent tax on oil is introduced-I acknowledge that the Labor Party in isolation does not have the numbers in this House to pass legislation on this question, which is why I say if or when such a tax is introduced-the same thing will not happen; that is, that it will not be used to camouflage what is, in fact, an increase in total taxation. While revenue will increase to the extent that it will apply to both old and new oil-I cannot give any binding assurances on the question-the general intention of the Government is that although the base of the tax will be broadened by the inclusion of new oil, its depth will probably be shallower. How those two factors would trade off in terms of total revenue is a matter on which I do not believe I can give any assurance.

Senator Chaney took up my comment that by the time the States had finished imposing their taxes and charges-in some cases charges well in excess of cost-on the mining industry or sections of it, there was no economic rent left to tax, and asked how I had arrived at that conclusion. The figures I now cite are not precise, because I do not have the precise figures in front of me, but a survey conducted by the Australian Coal Association-indeed, I think it commissioned Coopers and Lybrand to do the survey about the end of 1982-concluded that roughly one-third of coal mines were showing a negative rate of return on capital, about one-third were showing a return of something like 3 per cent, and the remaining third were operating reasonably profitably. I do not think that the report cited a maximum rate of return for any mine included in the survey. Quite clearly, there is no economic rent in a mine or a project that is showing a negative return on funds and no economic rent in a project that is showing only 3 per cent return on funds. That was substantially the basis for my statement that there is little or no economic rent at present, once the States have finished imposing their charges.

I will cite one more specific example, again from memory, but I am pretty confident that the figure is correct. Mt Isa Mines Ltd had a return on funds in its last financial year-I am not sure whether that was calendar year 1982 but it was the last financial year for which an annual report was available-of 1.4 per cent. Again, it is quite clear that with that sort of return on funds there is no economic rent being retained by the company. It does not necessarily mean that there was no economic rent to start with, but that by the time the States had finished imposing their charges there was certainly no economic rent left in the hands of the company.

Senator Chaney took up the question of the Commonwealth Grants Commission and my reference to its proper functioning. I meant by that a grants commission which was applying properly the concept of taxation effort. I defined that as a tax which affects individuals rather than corporations, which has the side effect of undermining the Commonwealth corporate taxation base and which applies the principle of equalisation. There is a great deal of room for judgment, admittedly, in the the concept of equalisation. I believe that the conclusion of the Grants Commission report of 1981, regarding the taxing effort made by the Queensland Government, to which I have previously referred, was conceptually wrong.

Senator Chaney asked whether this Government would automatically accept Grants Commission reports. I think that the answer to that would have to be no, because I do not believe that if a grants commission comes up with a conclusion based on that sort of reasoning it ought to be accepted by a government. He made the point, correctly of course, that Grants Commission recommendations have been varied in the past by governments for political or other reasons. He put that in the context of its being a negative act. That may not have been his intention, but that is the way it came through to me. I do not think it need necessarily be regarded as a negative, because although political intervention, or variation of a recommendation of the Commission, can take place for cynical or unsavoury reasons, it can also be designed to correct errors that may have been made by the Commission. One such political intervention which could conceivably be made should be one that took account of structural changes in the taxation bases of the States and/or the Commonwealth.

We recognise that the treatment of exploration for oil is particularly important, in that most exploration activity is non-productive. For that which is successful in finding substantial fields of free-flowing oil, profitability of the project from that point on is not in doubt because there is a secure market at high prices. Senator Chaney stated quite correctly-indeed, it is no more than a mathematical truism-that if the peaks of potential or actual profitability are lopped off by a rent tax, the average level of profitability falls. That, of course, is correct in isolation, but it need not be treated in isolation. Senator Chaney also argued that this would then have an adverse effect on exploration effort. If that were the only change made, his conclusion would probably be correct. But the Government proposes-I acknowledge that we have not yet reached a conclusion about the details-to include in the rent tax base in some way an allowance for expenditure on the exploration of barren ground. If we succeed in doing that, it will at least partially and maybe even entirely offset the deterrent effect on exploration to which the honourable senator has referred. I also note in passing that plenty of people, including at least one foreign company, are currently exploring for oil although they know that they face a resources rent tax. Senator Chaney also suggested that the Government is pushing the rent tax policy because it provides a mechanism for imposing a tax on excise-free Fortescue oil. It will certainly have that effect, but that is not the intention. It has been clear Labor party policy since 1977 that such a tax should apply. That pre-dates the discovery of Fortescue.

The question of managerial efficiency being affected at very high marginal tax rates is acknowledged. Obviously, if the marginal tax rate is 100 per cent, to company managers or owners it is indifferent whether expenditure is incurred in tax deductible ways or not. Therefore, the maximum marginal tax rate obviously has to be something less than 100 per cent. The point at which that deterrant effect to efficient management actually becomes a serious problem is a matter for judgment and argument. I make the point, however, that in the absence of a rent tax a similar effect can take place and, indeed, I believe has taken place. When the lowest cost coal mines were operating at extremely profitable levels, tonnage was more important to the total income of the companies concerned than was cost per tonne. Under those circumstances, there is likely to be a greater managerial concentration on maintaining output than on resisting cost increases. There was one case where, in present value dollars, there was a $150 a week one- off increase in wages which flowed on to the industry generally. I acknowledge quite freely, as I have in private correspondence recently to the company concerned, that that is not the only such example of a huge one-off increase in wages. Indeed, the next time it happened was in New South Wales and the increase was granted by a government authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not quite finished with the matters raised by Senator Chaney. I think I am quite entitled to say that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is certainly not a disinterested party in this debate about the resources rent tax. In the 1977 Budget, if I remember correctly, the previous Government said that it was contemplating a rent tax on oil or petroleum in general. In 1978 it announced that it had decided not to proceed with a rent tax on petroleum. By that time the Australian Labor party had stated as a firm policy intention that it would apply a rent tax which would apply to both old and new oil. So arguably there was a short period between, at the most, September 1975 and July of 1977 when there was a genuine expectation that neither party would impose anything but corporate tax and, for off-shore areas, the existing royalty on new oil discoveries. That ceased to apply in 1977.

A more important point is that at the time the new oil policy became a bipartisan policy the administered price of Australian oil was something like $6 a barrel, if I remember correctly. In 1978, by administrative decision, the then Government lifted the price of Australian oil to full import parity, which I think was about $14 a barrel, although not all of that price increase accrued to the producers. A progressively larger proportion of that increase did accrue to the producers. That also was a pretty profound change in the ground rules about which I do not recall hearing any complaint from the oil producers. Not surprisingly, complaints about changing the ground rules are somewhat selective. There are no complaints about changes in the ground rules when they favour producers; there are complaints about alleged changes when they disadvantage producers relative to what applied before.

I refer to Senator Rae's question about Minatome Australia Pty Ltd. He is not here at the moment, but I guess I am probably as big an offender as anyone here in regard to this matter. People tend to refer to that company name as a sort of shorthand expression for the organisation involved in the Ben Lomond project. Senator Sir John Carrick referred to the speech which I gave to the Committee for Economic Development of Australia last Friday and the reference to the cyclical component of the deficit. The speech really reported on the fact that some calculations which have been made of the cyclical component of the deficit have attempted to measure the difference between what the deficit would be with a notional unemployment rate of 6 per cent and no other changes, and what it would be with an actual unemployment level of 10 per cent plus. He asked whether the Government regarded 6 per cent unemployment as normal. I certainly do not. I would be extremely suprised if anybody in the government regarded it as normal of if they did not have as a policy objective ultimately getting unemployment down to below 6 per cent. But any realist must accept that for the next couple of years anyway it is unlikely to fall below 6 per cent. It is highly unlikely that the sorts of growth rates which would have to be achieved to get unemployment down to that level can in fact be achieved in a couple of years, particularly when one considers possible changes in the work force participation rate. For unemployment to fall to 6 per cent within a couple of years, growth rates of 7 per cent to 8 per cent would probably have to be achieved in both of those years. I do not remember when a growth rate of that order was last achieved in Australia. One would probably have to go back to the 1960s. It may well be that it has never been achieved. Certainly over the last decade only in one calendar year or one financial year-it does make a difference, but I am not sure whether it was a calendar year or a financial year-has a growth rate of even 5 per cent actually been achieved.

Senator Sir John Carrick referred also to the 1945 White Paper on full employment which set as a policy target the achievement of unemployment of between 4 per cent and 5 per cent. That is an observation which has been made commonly enough before. People's perceptions of what is achievable are heavily influenced by their recent experience. In 1945, after the very recent experience of the Great Depression, an unemployment target rate of 4 per cent to 5 per cent was probably regarded as extremely ambitious. It may be that for similar reasons , having experienced unemployment in excess of 5 per cent, if not of 6 per cent, for almost all of the last seven or eight years, some people may have come to regard 6 per cent unemployment as normal. I think that the real point of Senator Sir John Carrick's question was: Is it the extent of the Government's ambition to reduce unemployment growth to 6 per cent? The answer to that is no.

The honourable senator referred also to the size of the deficit. Again, in the context of the CEDA speech, the point I was making there-it is a point which I have made before in this chamber-was that throughout the last decade half a dozen countries have maintained low rates of unemployment and ipso facto rates of economic growth high enough to maintain those rates of low unemployment in spite of increasing productivity of labour and in some cases increases in population and, for almost all of that same period, low rates of inflation. The Budget deficits recorded by those countries varied enormously. For example, Japan ran a Budget deficit of the order of 5 per cent or 6 per cent of gross domestic product for three or four years in succession. Yet, with the exception of the inflation burst of 1974 or thereabouts, in every other respect it had a very credible economic record, one which was certainly vastly superior to that which was achieved by Australia. The common denominator in those half a dozen countries was the existence of an effective prices and incomes policy. That is just a piece of history from which people can draw different conclusions. It seems to me that the most rational conclusion to draw from that-the conclusion which this Government has drawn-is that a prices and incomes policy is the peg upon which an effective economic policy should be hung. That is the policy of the Government.

Senator Sir John Carrick also raised the question of the export of crude oil from Bass Strait. Effectively he asked: Why has the Government allowed it? As Senator Sir John Carrick is obviously aware, there is a difference between total self-sufficiency and what I have been terming technical self-sufficiency, that is, for technical reasons, to supply the whole range of end products of petroleum it is necessary to import-we can quibble about the exact figure- something like 30 per cent of our total crude oil requirements. When we talk about self-sufficiency we are really talking about 70 per cent of total consumption of oil products in Australia.

Currently we have production potential in excess of that technical self- sufficiency. The indications are that that could persist for some years to come. The final outcome will depend on further assessment of and exploration in the Timor Sea area. I do not want to overstate the fact that the prospect of the degree of surplus capacity could both increase and be maintained for a longer period. But one thing we do know is that there is production potential surplus to the effective demand from the domestic market right now and some reasonable expectation that that will continue and may even increase. In other words, we are facing a situation in which at the margin there will be no sale for Australian crude unless it can be exported. Firstly, the Government would be confronted with the problem of allocating to producers and potential producers who would be allowed to supply the domestic market and, secondly, it would have a pretty devastating effect on exploration activity, especially if it were perceived that an excess capacity would continue for some time. For example, outside the Cooper Basin area, for which a market for additional gas discoveries is foreseeable, nobody would seriously look for gas in Australia because the market is saturated for a couple of decades hence. Perhaps there are some minor exceptions to that, such as the area around Darwin, but in general outside the Cooper Basin area nobody seriously explores for gas because they cannot see a market for it unless it is in sufficient quantity to be exported. It was principally for that reason that the Government made the decision to allow the export of Australian crude production surplus to the requirements of local refineries.

One more point which I think is worth making is that prior to having made that decision the Government-I was not reticent about the Government's motives in this-had twisted the arms of Australian refiners to induce them to take up a greater proportion of domestic oil production to replace some of what they were then importing. We did that principally for revenue reasons. There was a potential loss of revenue to the Commonwealth of $400m or thereabouts. As far as I know there was no serious criticism of the Government for doing that. Conceptually there is no difference between twisting refiners' arms to make them take up a greater proprotion of Australian crude or of allowing Australian producers to export. I know that Senator Sir John Carrick has not put this argument. Some people put the argument that under no circumstances should we be exporting Australian crude because it is a commodity which will be under supplied in the long term. If that argument were carried to its logical conclusion we would deliberately shut in Bass Strait production and would have to import greater quantities. All things considered, the Government made the judgments that it has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pursue this matter for a moment. I refer to what the Minister described as technical self- sufficiency. As I understood him, he said that regarding oil products Australia has a technical self-sufficiency rate of 70 per cent and that the other 30 per cent was in the nature of grades of oil that we have to import because the nature of Australian crudes is not such that it would satisfy that demand. Is the Minister saying that since the Australian crudes are at the lighter end of the barrel-I understand that they are at the lighter and the middle distillate end-we require an import of foreign crudes of the order of 30 per cent to meet the middle and heavier ends of the barrel? Is he saying also that a significant part of the 30 per cent that is imported is not in fact similar in terms of grade or quality to Bass Strait crude? If his logic follows that we will not use more than 70 per cent of our crude and therefore we have the choice of either leaving it in the ground or exporting it-the projection that I last saw was that by 1987 or thereabouts Australia might be, in the very short term, as much as 77 per cent self-sufficient, with that figure falling away in a year or two after that towards 70 per cent-is he saying that there is a possibility that in the future there will be frequent and larger exports of indigenous crude from Australia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Sir John Carrick raised the matter of the 30 per cent or thereabouts of crude which is imported. I am sure that Senator Sir John Carrick is pretty familiar with these things but he apparently wants them put on the record. One traditionally refined product has been imported to northern Australia and that continues. The Government has made no attempt to stop that. Senator Sir John Carrick may want to argue that we could have banned the imported refined product to northern ports and insisted that the product come from Australian refineries. That is an option that the Government could have taken but decided not to for a number of reasons, one of which is that the cost which somebody would have had to bear would almost certainly have been considerably higher in those northern ports.

SPEECH.PARA: He asked whether any of the oil which is being imported is similar to Bass Strait oil. I cannot give an absolutely definitive answer to that. I think possibly there are times when it does happen because purchasing decisions are made by something like five, six or seven different companies which make commercial judgments from time to time for a variety of different reasons. It may well be that the occasional cargo of, for example, light Indonesian crude similar to Australian crude comes into Australia. The companies might have some reason, which is not easily apparent, for doing that. However, they are minor exceptions. I believe that the general proposition that there is a technical need to import about 30 per cent of our crude holds up. One qualification can be added to that. It would be possible substantially to decrease the percentage of our oil supplies which are imported if a higher proportion of topped crudes were imported instead of full crudes, regardless of their source.

The proposition which was put to me and which I accepted, was that Australian refineries with the exception of one would require substantial technical adjustments which would have involved significant expense and probably a time lag. That is, I suppose, an option that is available to a government in the future if we achieve 77 per cent of total self-sufficiency, as Senator Sir John Carrick suggested, in 1987. I do not have any problem accepting that as a possibility. Therefore, in the technical sense and given a considerable surplus of local production, a government has available to it an option of by some means or other discouraging the import of whole crude and replacing it with topped crude which produces relatively much higher proportions of lubricating oil, bitumen and heavy products and much lower proportions of petrol and distillate which can be produced in high proportions from Australian crude. However, no decision has been made to do that. The decision was made some months ago not to try to push refiners in that direction in any direct way and it has not been contemplated at this stage that they be pushed that way in the future. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to that, perhaps the Minister would be good enough in due course-obviously not now-to look at the question of 70 per cent of technical self-sufficiency and supply the Committee and me with a comparison between the 30 per cent imported in normal times and not in fortuitous shipments and the percentage of those imports that is in fact comparable in terms of the fraction with Australian indigenous crude. The answer to this question is not for now. However, perhaps it could be supplied in due course because it will take some compiling. I think it is very important that we understand this matter. My point, of course, is this: Australia is always in a difficult situation with regard to foreign exchange and it would be a good thing if we could save our oil. I presume that if we sell it abroad we would earn some foreign exchange. However, equally, if we can use it ourselves or keep it in the ground it must make better sense in the long term.

—I am not certain whether the information Senator Sir John Carrick seeks can be supplied. I would expect the country of origin to be available to the Department of Trade. However, we may, to some extent, be relying on company information. I will endeavour to get the information that the honourable senator is seeking.

—I seek clarification of several matters in respect of which the Minister has responded. Secondly, the Minister suggested that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd may not really be against a resource rental tax although there may be certain opposition by that company's vested interests. Can he explain just what he meant by that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

The point I was making , perhaps not as clearly as it should have been made, was that the ground rules about the price of oil were very substantially changed by the previous government in 1977 and again in 1978 in a way that provided a windfall gain to the Australian producers. I am not aware of any of the Australian producers complaining about that change to the ground rules. But some of the Australian producers, and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is the major company that I have in mind, have complained about what they regard as changes to the ground rules through the application of a rent tax which incorporates new oil. The net gain to the company would be somewhat less than the gross gain, but the gross gain to the company of that excise free status would be $350m to $400m. Finally-Senator Sir John Carrick has been reading my recent speeches so he would be familiar with this-as far back as 1971 the former Chairman of Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd, Sir Maurice Mawby, drew attention to the damage which was being inflicted on the extractive industries by charges based on production. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of matters I wish to raise with the Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh), one of which arose out of a comment he made, or one of which was anticipated by a comment he made in answer a few minutes ago, when he referred to the problem which faces explorers; that is, that there is really no point in discovering a deposit of gas in most parts of Australia because there is a glut in most of Australia.
—They might find it when they are looking for oil.

—Quite. The fellow who made the comment about one of the problems of the industry being that in fact there was too much oil in Fortescue said: ' and the second problem for the industry is that there is too much gas being found'. The difficulty that explorers face, and I think this is a severe practical difficulty which needs attention by government, is the lack, in most parts of Australia, of a suitable holding tenement. In at least one State I think there is an arrangement whereby somebody who finds a resource which cannot be developed because of the immediate market position is able to get a tenement which relieves such a person of the requirement that there be immediate development or further extensive exploration. I ask the Minister whether this problem has received any consideration from him or from his Department and whether any action has been taken to encourage the States to develop some form of holding tenement which, whilst avoiding the possibility of useful resources being locked up and held for reasons purely internal to a company, acknowledges the reality which was referred to by the Minister himself in Committee a few minutes ago; that is, that in some areas such as gas there simply is no current market. Given the variability of the world energy scene and so on, and given Australia's need to go on discovering oil and so on, I believe it would be an extremely good thing if explorers felt that if, in the course of exploring for oil, or indeed in the course of exploring specifically for gas, they were to find deposits they would be putting themselves in a position from which at some future time they would get some commercial advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: The second discrete matter which I raise with the Minister relates to these appropriations and perhaps to Treasury appropriations. I refer to the question of prices surveillance of petroleum products. The Government has, as I understand it, indicated its intention to establish a prices surveillance authority which will, as part of its functions, establish justified petroleum product prices on an Australia-wide basis. I ask the Minister whether that authority would be looking at wholesale or retail prices, or both?

I also raise with the Minister a matter which I raised in the adjournment debate some time ago. I have not had any response, so perhaps it was never drawn to his attention. I refer to the dual authorities which at present exist with respect to prices in this area. We have around Australia a series of State authorities which fix the price of petrol. In some cases they fix wholesale prices and in others they fix both wholesale and retail prices. We have the authority which was established under the previous Government which also sets a price and there is, I think, a very real problem for the industry in this duplication of authorities. A lot of politics is involved in fixing the price of petrol. It is quite good politics in the short term to restrict the price of such a basic commodity. I think Senator Walsh would, in his economic rationalist role, agree that the unreasonable squeezing of profits to a point where investment becomes unrealistic is not sensible in the long term. At the moment this problem is masked in Australia by the energy situation, by the fact that there is a surplus of product around and there is a lot of competition and a lot of people are trading, at least intermittently, below the prices which are set by these various authorities. But I do think that in the longer term we have an unhealthy duality of bodies interfering in this area and I should like to know whether the Government's new proposal is one which will endeavour to come to grips with that and to remove some of the duplication which at present exists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had all but completed my contribution on the Sex Discrimination Bill. This is my third attempt at completing the speech. When I last spoke, on 21 October, I was making the point that really there is nothing particularly novel in this Bill. I mentioned the fact that in South Australia we have had sex discrimination legislation since 1975. That Act was, in fact, modelled on the United Kingdom Sex Discrimination Act of the same year. I was about to remind the Senate that New South Wales also has had, since 1977, anti-discrimination legislation, including provisions which make unlawful discrimination on the grounds of sex or marital status. Victoria has had its Equal Opportunity Act since 1977. That Act also outlaws discrimination on the grounds of sex or marital status. So there is nothing new in the concept of this Bill. It is true that the Bill includes outlawing discrimination on the ground of pregnancy although, in South Australia, the Sex Discrimination Tribunal has been including pregnancy under the heading of indirect discrimination, so even that concept is not novel. So rather than argue, as some have, that this Bill introduces a new type of legislation, I see it as a logical progression towards the goal of ensuring for all Australian women the right not to be discriminated against in certain specified areas critical to their well-being, on grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, it was said by a delegate from a developing country to a conference in Copenhagen about which I spoke on the last occasion, that to talk feminism to a woman who has no water, no food and no home is to talk nonsense. It has been said by some that to talk sex discrimination legislation with so many already unemployed in our society is to talk nonsense. I suggest to the Senate that we must develop all facets of our society. It is not possible to package neatly different areas of social and economic development. There is a need to progress on many fronts, of which this is one. Full justice and equality for women in Australia is a right not yet fully realised. This Bill makes a contribution to that goal. I attempted, when my speech was being broadcast, to allay some of the fears that had been expressed and put very seriously and genuinely by some Australians about the purpose and policy of a sex discrimination Act. I hope I was successful on that occasion. Matters concerning the deficiencies in this Bill, of which we see a number, will of course be the subject of Opposition amendments at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would simply like to address a few remarks in reply to a comment made by Senator Harradine in his speech on the Sex Discrimination Bill. He quoted an article from the Canberra Times of 7 October in which a statement that arguments against the Sex Discrimination Bill circulated by the New South Wales Right to Life Association were not considered plausible by officers of the Attorney-General's Department was attributed to a spokeswoman from Senator Ryan's office. Senator Harradine produced a letter from the Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department to the effect that the Department had not considered the arguments put forward by the New South Wales Right to Life Association. In fact, the inquiries came to Senator Susan Ryan's office and had been checked by lawyers in the Office of the Status of Women. They gave the opinion that was reported. The report, which appeared in the Canberra Times of 7 October, that advice relating to claims by the New South Wales Right to Life Association had come from the Attorney-General 's Department was an assumption on the part of the journalist and an incorrect one.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very proud to be here today to debate this very important Bill. As no doubt honourable senators know, I am the first woman member of the Australian Labor Party from South Australia to come to Canberra. I come, as Senator Hill said, from the State that introduced the first sex discrimination legislation in Australia. As a matter of interest, South Australia has a long list of firsts for women. The University of Adelaide was the first university in Australia to admit women to degrees. The South Australian Government passed the first parliamentary Bill for the enfranchisement of women. In 1894 all South Australian women over the age of 21 became entitled to vote and stand for election. It was the first State in Australia to so allow. In 1896 the first election in Australia in which women voted was held. The first woman political candidate for federal election, Catherine Helen Spence, came from South Australia. (Quorum formed)

South Australia was the first State to have a female inspector of schools, a woman called Blanch McNamara. We had the first woman factory inspector. We had the first woman elected to the council of the University of Adelaide. Helen Mayo was elected to that position in 1914 and served on the council for 46 years. In 1919 the first Australian woman local government councillor was elected. In 1965 the Hon. Justice Roma Mitchell, who had been the first female Queen's Counsel in this country, was the first woman in Australia to be appointed a judge. She was appointed to the South Australian Supreme Court. In 1975 the sex discrimination Act of South Australia was the first such Act to be introduced in Australia. We had the first Commissioner for Equal Opportunity. In 1982 the South Australian Health Commission became Australia's first major statutory authority with equal numbers of men and women appointed as commissioners. This year the University of Adelaide established Australia's first research centre for women's studies with a full time director. In fact last Sunday but two the South Australian Minister for Health, Mr Cornwall, appointed the first women's adviser in health in Australia. Whilst it is a matter of considerable pride that I am here and whilst it is a matter of distinction that I can list those achievements for women in South Australia, I am drawing the attention of the Senate to the fact that despite those achievements for women we still need this legislation. It is necessary for both men and women in Australia. I will quote from the preamble to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. It states:

Discrimination against women violates the principles of equality of rights and respect for human dignity. It is an obstacle to the participation of women, on equal terms with men, in the political, social, economic and cultural life of their communities. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of their countries and of humanity.

The program of action adopted at the Conference of the Decade for Women in Copenhagen in 1980 puts it another way. I am sure I remember Senator Hill quoting this too. The Conference pointed out that women are 50 per cent of the world adult population; one-third of the official labour force; perform nearly two-thirds of all working hours; receive only one-tenth of the world's income; and own less than one per cent of world property. This legislation is not designed to redress all these inequities as they relate to Australian women. It is, if one likes, a precondition for the establishment of some sort of equality.

As an example of the inequality of women's representation generally in jobs perhaps some statistics about this Federal Parliament and about women in parliaments in Australia are illustrative. Since federation only 20 women have served in this place, and that includes those women here today. In both Houses there has been a total of 29 women. For all the governments of Australia since their formation a total of only 110 women have served. However, there are some heartening signs that those numbers are increasing, albeit slowly. In 1980 there were 550 women out of a total of 8,845 persons serving in local government in Australia. Since June 1982 there have been 62 sitting women members of parliament in Australia-a mere 8 per cent. However, following the Queensland election those figures would have increased slightly.

The purpose of this legislation, briefly, is to give effect to certain provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women and to make unlawful discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy in certain areas, most particularly in employment, education, matters of finance and accommodation.

The Bill also provides for a prohibition on sexual harassment in the work place and in educational institutions; and very importantly it promotes recognition and acceptance of the principle of equality of men and women. The Bill is designed to complement existing State legislation and it allows for the concurrent operation of State and Federal laws. It will make a number of very practical changes to assist women who have been the victims of discrimination. The Federal Government legislation will apply across all States, and where there is no State legislation it will apply to all people in that State except State government employees. It is a hope of myself, and the majority of people in this Senate, certainly honourable senators on this side, that those States and Territories currently without sex discrimination legislation will introduce it in the future. In the case of Queensland we may have to wait some time.

It has been claimed that there is widespread antagonism and opposition to this Bill. I would like to list some support for the matter of balance in the record. I have a number of quotes. One from a recent Women's Electoral Lobby newsletter in South Australia, dated September 1980, states:

The Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women, the National Council of Women of Australia; the United Nations Association of Australia, the Union of Australian Women, Women and Development Network, the Women's Electoral Lobby and the Young Women's Christian Association of Australia, congratulate the Government on its recent action in ratifying the Convention . . .

We have perused the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983, with some care and, in general, are pleased with the provision it contains. We believe that every person in Australia should have the right to pursue their occupations and interest uninhibited by arbitrary discrimination based solely on their sex. Therefore we-
that is, all those above listed women's groups-
