strongly urge you to support the immediate passage of the Bill during this session of Parliament.
The Catholic Church, in a recent newspaper called the Southern Cross in South Australia, on 1 October had this to say:
The Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace strongly supported the Government 's initiative in preparing legislation to eliminate discrimination against women .
The Age, in its editorial on 13 July, stated:

At the philosophical level, there were those who wondered whether human values should be expressed in legislation, or whether the cause of anti-discrimination would be better served by strong educative campaigns. While there is some appeal in this idea, the fact remains that not every member of the community is fair- minded. Some, in fact, are brutishly intolerant. In such cases, there is a real, as well as symbolic, value in having the country's chosen values spelt out in legislation. Like a Bill of Rights it establishes a code of conduct to which the community is expected to adhere.
It went on:
. . . Sexual Discrimination Act is no guarantee that in every case women's rights would be respected and equality recognised.

. . . Nonetheless, the Government's Bill does set an ideal against which the achievements of women can be measured, as well as a mechanism for bringing complaints and resolving disputes. On those grounds, it is a marked advance.

Discrimination against women exists in many forms and it is especially the case for migrant and aboriginal women. It has been estimated that 53,000 outworkers in the clothing industry make up sweatshop labour and produce about 70 per cent of all the clothes made in Australia. These women, mostly migrants, earn about $ 108 for a 40-hour week. The award for factory machinists is $210 per week and includes sick and holiday pay, workers' compensation cover, penalty rates and long service leave-all of which these sweatshop women miss out on. Pat O'Shane, a person well placed to describe the situation for Aboriginal women, reports that it is actually very difficult to have any reliable or coherent facts and figures about Aboriginal people. In large part that was due to the fact that what was meant by the word 'Aboriginal'-how Aboriginal people should describe themselves-was not cleared up or established until the 1976 census. Even then Aboriginal people preferred to describe themselves as Aboriginal, so estimates may still be suspect in terms of the figures given. In the 1976 census 13,778 Aboriginal women were listed as being in the labour force, comprising 30 per cent of the total Aboriginal labour force. The unemployment rate as at 1976 was 25 per cent. One thing is certain, Aboriginals are concentrated in the lowest status, lowest paid jobs.

I think it is important to mention in passing that discrimination does exist against men and any of us can remember examples. From my own experience I know the battle male nurses had in being allowed to participate in midwifery. I do not believe, as some of the knockers of this Bill do, that the legislation will threaten or undermine women. Rather it will enable them to make a choice about whether they want to stay at home an rear children or go to work. The United Nations Convention and this Bill do not denigrate men or women in any way. Rather they give men and women the opportunity to take advantage of avenues open to them if they should desire. I disagree entirely with Senator Shirley Walters, who was reported in the Age on 10 August this year as having said:
The Convention is a formidable threat to freedom of religion and the protection of women and the family in this country.

In fact, by legislating for the rights of women and opposing any discrimination against women, this Bill celebrates women and acknowledges their right to personhood, to dignity, to respect, and to freedom from discrimination. It enshrines their place in our society and it enforces their worth. In fact it does all the things that the Opposition-Senator Walters in particular-claims that it wants. But it is the Opposition which presents women as stuck in stereotyped roles. It keeps women locked into those roles. It keeps women locked into poverty. It keeps women locked into dependence, all justified by its argument of preserving and persevering with the family. It really seems to be arguing, I think, for preserving the status quo and the existing power structures in our society. But I think it is important also to say that many men do not like being stuck in stereotyped roles. The perpetual position of breadwinner is a very unfreeing situation for many men.

It is no dignity to be bound into stereotypes of poverty and dependence. Dignity, I may say to Senator Walters, is consequent on freedom, and very particularly, the freedom to choose. The tragedy of handicapped or retarded people, I would argue, is their reduced option for choice. Other people make their choices for them. That is their loss of particular dignity. Perhaps, too, it is argued that people will make wrong choices, therefore we should not allow them to make any. I disagree entirely with this position too. I do not believe that because people make wrong choices we have any case to deny them their right to make a choice-their right to choose. Education, information and support are what people need-not restriction.

This Government actually acknowledges the people of Australia as adult. It is legislating to protect their right to be free of discrimination, to be free to choose. The antagonists have based their criticisms on sweeping generalisations. There will be no foreign control or intervention in our laws, as has been claimed by many and certainly the misinformation of the many letters sent to me and, I am sure, to other honourable senators, conveys a remarkable misunderstanding of this Bill. In fact, their attitudes, I think, are well captured by a splendid line in a play. (Quorum formed) I think there is one gain from a quorum having been called. I will be able to read this great quotation to the whole Senate, or at least to a quorum of it. A recent play by Steven Sewell called The Blind Giant is Dancing contains a line which captures exactly the attitudes of some of the Opposition senators. Sewell described what he referred to as, 'a voodoo bag of misogyny and sado-masochism'. There will be no forcing of people to adopt prescribed roles. Unfortunately, the roles of women have been stereotyped. Women are still to a great degree seen as home-makers, secretaries, nurses and nothing more. That is not to say that those positions are limited. In fact, they are splendid, especially for women who choose to be in them-or men, for that matter. I quote from the Boyer Lecture given in 1979 by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke):

If a woman sees her happiness and complete fulfilment in terms of the family home, this should be thoroughly respected; we should abhor any perverse discrimination which attributes any inferior status to such women, who will continue to constitute a significant proportion of our community.

For those women who wish, or feel it necessary, to engage in paid employment outside the home, we should regard it as an obligation upon society to ensure, either at the workplace or other acceptable locations, completely adequate child -care facilities as a matter of justice to the mother and child.

I think there are a number of areas on which this legislation will have particular impact. In regard to the area of educational institutions, while we may wonder whether changes will have an effect out into the community, I think it is quite clear that they will, although there may be some time lag between the changes in the educational institutions, particularly tertiary institutions, and the impact in the community. But anybody who is looking for increased access to educational opportunities for women and girls, will be heartened by the provisions of this Bill. Of course, the other educational role that is very important to consider here is the educative role of the legislation per se. Whatever else we can say about it, there has been to date a considerable community debate; at least, I think, there has been a debate on one side and a slanging match on the other.

In the past, girls have been discouraged away from science, engineering and such areas of secondary and tertiary education, including mathematics. This is really in large part due to a subtle socialising of women and young girls. If we eliminate the participation of women the equality of the employment pool is reduced. This will and has deprived employers of at least half their potential employees. Recently the Government introduced two new programs to redress this imbalance. They are the New Opportunities for Women Program and the Technically Speaking Program.

The other area that is important to look at is employment. Two thirds of Australia's working women are confined to three major occupational groups, clerical, sales and service-jobs which have a low status and low pay. It is in these very areas that employment prospects have diminished as a result of technological change. Women, if they are to have access to employment, will have to look at preparation for areas of technology. Australia's industrial future is intimately tied up with those areas in which technical development is happening, so women need to be attending to those prospects while they are in secondary and tertiary education areas. It should also be mentioned that the traditional areas of work for women tend to be tedious and monotonous. I presume that that is a description of much work but, in fact, there is little opportunity for promotion in many women's jobs. Women, of course, as a consequence have suffered more fatigue and health hazards, and reduced job satisfaction.

The other area, I think, that is particularly horrific if we look at the figures is the area of the consequences of women being denied work and/or education. That means that women finish up very largely among the poor. They are very much more represented among the poor in our society than are men. This is partly due to the reduced options for women to work. It is due to the limited areas where women can apply for work. It is also due to the effects of unemployment over the last couple of years. In large part, women belong in the part time employment areas. Some 36.4 per cent of all employed females, compared with 6.2 per cent of males, are in part time employment. According to recent figures, only 5 per cent of apprentices are women. Only a small percentage of women acually work full time. In 1981 those women received on average 76 cents for every dollar earned by men. Even if we adjust that figure to take into account women being on a reduced income because of part time work, the average woman's wage is still only 80 cents, as compared to the male earning a dollar.

Yet many more families would be in poverty if women were not in paid employment . Data from the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty of 1975 shows that the number of poor families would have doubled if married women had not had paid work. Women's incomes are, in fact, a very important part in the consumption patterns and income distribution. Yet discrimination against women in education, training, employment, tax and social security systems have combined with domestic division of labour to perpetuate the occupational segregation which keeps women in that lowest paid bracket. Lower income and part time women workers too are also in a poor bargaining position. Consequently their wages lag behind those of men.

The present economic recession has severely affected women. Whilst part time employment opportunities for women have grown, this has been at the expense of full time work. Where part time work is casual, those workers are denied such things as fringe benefits, sickness benefits, holiday pay, et cetera. Certainly in South Australia and in some other places in Australia we have permanent part time work with some of those rights attached to part time work. But it still is reaching only a small percentage of the women who are involved in part time work . During the recession, the first group of people to be blamed has been married women. It has been said that if married women get out of the work force there will be jobs for everybody. As a matter of fact, the work done by women is never the work for which men apply. Married women tend to do the lowest paid and the meanest work. In fact, men and young people do not wish to compete for those jobs.

This Party in government has the only and the only true policy for women. This legislation is one part of that policy. The Liberal members on the other side of the House do not have a defined policy and, as reported in the Press recently, divisions have surfaced on the question of women's rights. They have even left it to a man to be the shadow Minister in charge of women's affairs. The President of the Young Liberal movement was reported in the Australian Financial Review of 7 June 1983 as saying:

He had been shocked by the vigorous campaign being conducted by some Liberal parliamentarians, and stating that there was clear evidence that the Liberal Party was out of touch with the attitudes of young women who in recent years have swung strongly to Labor.

I would like to add that I think they are out of touch with more than that. Judith Roberts, the former South Australian Chairman of the Liberal Party was reported in the Advertiser of 6 October 1983 as saying:
The attitude of the parliamentary wing of the Liberal Party to this proposed legislation 'demonstrates a lack of conviction about equality . . . for women', . . .
She went on to say:
This is a fundamental issue of human rights and must be supported if the Liberal Party is to have any credibility at all.

Even more exciting than the division amongst the Liberals is the extraordinary exercise that Mr Doug Anthony indulged in when explaining the position of the National Party of Australia on this Bill. He actually said all the right things and then worked out why he was against it. The Leader of the National Party, Mr Anthony, in his statement, said:
The Party acknowledges that discrimination against women does exist in certain areas and must be eliminated . . .
Much of the criticism of the Bill has been uninformed, emotional and misleading .
He went on to say:

The result of provisions in the Bill may encourage women into the workforce, and will require the further growth of child-care facilities to enable parents to combine family and work responsibilities. We support freedom of choice for women , and the need for adequate child-care facilities to meet the specific needs of the community.

However, the National Party does not wish to hasten the institutionalisation of society. We seek to strengthen and encourage the family unit, and help women faced with the choice between home making and involvement in the work force . . .
The National Party, on balance, opposes this legislation.

That balancing act I think is nothing short of farce. I will not speak about affirmative action other than to say that a Green Paper will be tabled shortly by the Government and further discussion about affirmative action will take place then. We do need this law. The Office of the Status of Women, in a paper of July this year, said:
People sometimes argue that the law has no role in solving problems based on attitudes . . .

While laws alone will never be enough . . . they are in many respects very important. Laws stand as a clear statement of public policy and have an effect on conduct by protecting people against discrimination and giving redress to those discriminated against.

Anti-discrimination laws also offer support . . . give reasons to change behaviour . . ., think about what they have been doing and, perhaps, change their attitudes. Laws based on conscience are likely to be obeyed-even if they are not they still establish a standard of behaviour . . .
Finally a law offers to those who are discriminated against a source of courage and an awareness of rights . . .
This Bill, I think, should be viewed with pride in the opportunities it will encourage for women, rather than a fear that changes might occur. I commend the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983. I wish to say that I completely and utterly support the anti- discrimination attitude. I believe in it. I practise it. I am appalled at this nonsense before us that purports to be a Bill to cover it. I am both affronted and disappointed by this rather poor effort to legislate on this issue. I find that people who believe that it is possible to legislate against what is normally covered by the hearts and minds of people always fail. Who really believes that this piece of legislation does anything more than try to appease a tiny minority of motivated people? I have been the recipient of a considerable number of representations on this subject. I have had many letters, petitions and telephone calls. I have had no petitions in support of the legislation; I have had four letters in support of it; and I have not had one caller at my office in support of it. All the other representations made to me have been opposed to it. I have had masses of those sorts of representations.

SPEECH.PARA: I have never found it desirable to speak on one of these types of debates in the Senate before. Several aspects of the legislation have encouraged me to do so on this occasion. Firstly, without any doubt this is the worst presented Bill that has ever come before the Parliament in the last eight years. I think that on that account it needs to be given some consideration. With 53 Government amendments already, it is still rotten legislation. There are nearly as many amendments to come from the Opposition. We have had the view expressed that the Bill should be passed in whatever form it is in. That has been said even before the Government's first 53 amendments were produced. At that stage I suppose it would have been fair to say that it was 53 amendments worse than it is now.

The other point is that I am sure that many of those who are promoting the Bill as a great advance for women are not really in the position where they can make those claims any more than I can. I do not believe that the people who are supporting it so strongly are by any means what one could call average women in society. I would be foolish if I took no notice of the enormous number of letters and contacts I have been getting on this subject. They have put a far more plausible case against this particular legislation and the way it is to deal with the subject than I have heard from anybody speaking in support of it.

Many people-I am one-have a genuine desire to support genuine equality but the only people whom I have heard speaking so loudly about this legislation are people who I believe, in most cases, have already achieved what they seek to claim for others. In some ways they exude pity for women with non-similar goals. I do not think, for instance, that the previous speaker in this debate, Senator Crowley, could really say that she had been discriminated against because she is not adopting the traditional role and things like that. I have heard other speakers in similar positions. Frankly, I do not think any of us here are typical people in the community. I believe that most members of parliament are people who have set certain goals and seek to achieve certain ends. As such, that makes us quite different in the average person's point of view. Not one Bill or even dozens of Bills are going to change the natural characteristics of men and women. I do not think we would really want to do that. It may be an annoyance to some that we cannot legislate to cover that. But I do not think any amount of legislation will change the fact that most ordinary, natural women are homely and caring, that they are not wildly ambitious, that they are not naturally dominating and that they are mostly inclined to avoid authority. They are, by nature, more cautious and more considerate. It strikes me that clause 5 (1) of the Bill makes it an offence for those characteristics to be taken into account.

Men, by nature, are more likely to be leaders, providers and protectors. We can legislate all we like, but we will not change that. But it is to be an offence to discriminate by reason of a characteristic that appertains generally to persons of the sex of the aggrieved person, or a characteristic that is generally imputed to persons of the sex of the aggrieved person. I find that absolutely extraordinary. Why do women want to be like men, or men want to be like women?

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not.

—I should think not. What has become wrong with being what nature provides? Surely, I do not want to see women become so equal with men in Australia that they are out digging drains, shearing sheep, slaughtering beasts or occupied as undertakers, sawmill operators and so on. Do we want equality, or do we want just the bit off the top? Most of the people I have heard have all sorts of aspirations for being the managing director but do not see that they should make the cups of tea or clean the waste paper baskets.

SPEECH.PARA: I have seen equality in various places, and I have learned a certain amount about it in various places. I have seen equality in China. I have not seen it in Ethiopia or in Vietnam, but I understand that it exists there. I am not sure that we want that sort of equality. But if we established that, at least we would be in good company. Looking at the list of the countries involved in this sort of legislation-not the countries that have signed the original document but those that have actually legislated-I find that it runs: Austria, Barbados, Bhutan, Bulgaria, the Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic, Canada, Cape Verde , China, Colombia, Congo, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Dominica, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, El Salvador, Ethiopia, Gabon, the German Democratic Republic, Guatemala, Guinea, Guyana, Haiti, Honduras, Hungary, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, Mexico, Mongolia, Nicaragua, Norway, Panama, Peru, the Philippines, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Rwanda, St Lucia, Sri Lanka, St Vincent and the Grenadines, Sweden, the Ukrainian Soviet Republic, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Uruguay, Vietnam, and Yugoslavia. That is the list of those that have legislated in support of ratification. There are 49 countries there-19 communist countries, 24 developing countries and six others.

Countries not appearing on the list include the United Kingdom, New Zealand, the United States of America, the Federal Republic of Germany, or France, for instance, and all the others of which we know. But we are in amongst all the communists and most of the developing countries, and I guess that puts us in the right place! I wonder why the good news has not yet reached the countries I have just mentioned. This is the list that was in operation as at 26 September 1983, as I was told by the Department of Foreign Affairs.

I appreciate that this Bill grants rights. But in my experience, rights can best be described as something one seeks to obtain by getting it from someone else. The Bill covers sex discrimination but it does not cover, say, employer discrimination. Employers only provide the jobs. How can the average small business hope to cope with these very poorly defined and even less understood provisions? In my opinion, people in that situation will take the only action that is open to them and they just simply will not employ. When I look at this sort of discrimination, I think it is just as much out of order to discriminate against older people, or left-handed people, or large people, or younger people- as it now is. Who will look after them? Shall we have new Bills for all those as well? What about accommodation discrimination? Letting agents, for instance, usually vet prospective tenants and they do not let to known unsatisfactory, inappropriate or unfinancial applicants. If they do and the property is wrecked or the rent is unpaid, the agent may be sued. Now, if he does not let, he probably will be sued. So that is the only difference this Bill will make.

All sorts of groups have written in about this matter. One that I noticed recently was the Institute of Public Affairs. It is not like that Institute to become involved in matters of this nature, but I was interested to find that it had invited Dr Clair Isbister along and had made a very substantial statement which I found quite interesting. I shall wait on the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), who is in charge of the Bill, to tell us in due course where the information in that submission is wrong. I also got a copy of the information that Dr Chipman produced. Again, I should like to know where Dr Chipman is completely wrong. The Bill also is a clear attack on our federal system. I believe in that system. The strength of the country is our federal system. For the Government to have to take recourse to both foreign affairs powers and corporation powers to try to achieve something like this is absolute nonsense. I do not know why we have to go on in this way to achieve something that is substantially in force anyway, but which should exist for everyone.

I am concerned about the question of intimidation, which may even turn into blackmail in many cases. There is no provision in the Bill for the people who are actually accused. With the sort of publicity that such a charge would provide, I do not overlook the fact that it will be very common for employers of labour, in particular, to be blackmailed and certainly to be even paying, whether or not the charge is genuine or can even be demonstrated to look as though it is genuine. I am somewhat surprised about the scale of the penalties. The Bill provides enormous penalties. There is no doubt that a penalty of $5,000 is enormous. In New South Wales these days one can even plead guilty to stealing $60,000 and get fined only $4,000, so one can see the relativity and the magnitude that is involved in this matter. We have heard much talk here about civil liberties and about a crimes commission. All I can say is that one can get far greater protection from the law if one is a suspected crook of great magnitude or a drug dealer than one can get if one comes under the provisions of this legislation.

I find the pregnancy question very interesting. The discrimination that it creates is every bit as great as the discrimination that it avoids. If we are going to look at the question of providing pregnant women with time off, of considerable duration, what about the temporary employees? What happens to them? I presume that they have no rights at all. Pregnancy leave is clearly the first step towards family leave. What happens when we reach the stage at which all women in the work force become entitled to, say, seven years of family leave?

TALK.START.PARA: —It affects fathers, too.

—Many have laughed at this proposition besides the honourable senator, but it may have escaped her attention that the Press has stated that one group has already been granted, or has bought, as the case may be, seven years' family leave. I quote from the Age of 13 October. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Victoria's teachers are entitled to seven years' family leave without losing their jobs or rights under a new agreement between the State Government and the three main teacher unions.
Under the agreement, seven years' leave without pay can be taken by all teachers to look after their children. They were previously entitled to 18 months.

How could anyone, apart from the Government, run a business in which people were allowed to have seven years off? I believe that someone who had had a job as a temporary employee for seven years would feel a bit upset if somebody came in and said: 'Look, that is my job, move over'. But what will be next? We know what will be next, I think, because Senator Ryan has made it adequately clear that she is really after affirmative action and that, in those areas where women may clearly be superior or successful, half of them should be moved out for men. I do not see why, in certain occupations, women should have to move out to make room for men, any more than the other way round. But I would certainly feel quite embarrassed if it was a fact that Senator Ryan, for instance, had to retire from the Senate because the people of Canberra were already represented by Senator Reid.

Will there be burning of books and that type of thing? The people who are talking about sex discrimination are not leaving any stone unturned in enunciating their aims and ambitions. For instance, a document has been circulated widely in Tasmania by a gentleman who was a former Minister for Education in Tasmania and Secretary of the Australian Labor Party in that State. I understand that he now works for one of the unions there. The document, entitled 'What can you do about sexist material in schools?', says in part:
Burn it!
Lose it!
Glue the pages together!
Hide it!
Take it out on permanent (eternal) loan!

It continues in this vein. Is this what we are after? I recall that in Nazi Germany and places like that it was found to be highly satisfactory to burn books. Most of such enterprises start in such a way. At Winnaleah School in Tasmania they burnt the Bibles because they claimed they were sexist. According to a recent correspondent in the Press, this type of anti-discrimination teaching is being circulated. The item in the Hobart Mercury of 1 November 1983 is one of the sickest things I have ever read. It is headed 'Removal of books' and states:

I feel that the public should be made aware that there is more to the removal of books from the Winnaleah School library than generally realised, and I quote from the so-called literature recommended for non-sexist teachers and their pupils.

From the 'Combat Sexism Kit' Book I for teachers: '. . . the marriage law is the most damnable outrage upon women that was ever conceived.' From the same kit -Book II for students, the story is told of the breast-people and the breastless ones-the only difference being that the breast-people gave birth. And I quote '. . . one day the breastless ones noticed that breast-people were getting strong and skilful . . . The difference and the progress of the breast-people, so startled and frightened the breastless ones. . . . So the breastless ones committed the first crime-they took possession of the lives of the breast-people and their little ones, robbed them of all they created and produced, took away their freedom and made them slaves. Their crime was known as ''marriage'' . . . With no excuse for their behaviour, the males invented a lie to justify their crime . . . When resistance continued, the males wrote their lies in books, and these books were The Bible, The Koran and the texts of Hinduism. To be assured of power, what was written became law and those who broke the law were punished, so the right of males to enslave females became legal and from then on the males were men and the females women.'

What sort of sickness is it that leads to such garbage being put out in the name of sex discrimination? I was appalled at the comments made on this matter by one of the female senators of this chamber. This sort of thing is just revolting, especially when perpetrated in the name of what is supposed to be progress. I find this Bill terribly verbose. I cannot see any reason why, at the time it was formulated, it did not in an educative way provide a framework which could be added to. Instead, we all have to go through this exercise. We will then spend years, I trust, going over it trying to tidy it up in some way.

I say that the vast majority of reasonable, sensible and practical issues are well and truly already in place. So much of the Bill is untidy and unclear. Many concerned people have asked advice of me. It does not really matter much, but if I ask three people I usually get about four answers. Everything in the Bill is so woolly and imprecise. I do not see why, out of this absolute fuzz, we should put people in the position of running the risk of being convicted of offences. All the amendments that we have ahead of us now tend only to make it all that much more difficult to sort out.

As honourable senators will be aware, the Senate has already been the subject of considerable influence. A considerable number of petitions have been presented. This afternoon I had the numbers of petitions for both sides of this question taken out so that I could cite them here and enable honourable senators to see the relative desirability or undersirability of the sex discrimination legislation, as it is seen by the people who have bothered to do something about it. Between 3 May 1983 and 8 November 1983 the United Nation Convention, which has now been ratified, produced 161 petitions, with a total of 56,810 signatures , that it be not ratified, and 24 petitions, with 1,314 signatures asking for ratification. There were three petitions with 116 signatures in favour of the Bill itself and six petitions with 365 signatures against it. Petitions asking for amendment amount to 110, with 20,542 signatures, and petitions asking for referral to a committee amounted to seven, with 452 signatures. Those are the numbers to date. Those people have seen fit to have their feelings noted, to make sure that they could be considered in the chamber and the Parliament of this country could see the amount of consideration that should be involved.

I support anti-discrimination. The Bill in no way makes it possible to achieve that. In fact, I cannot imagine many ways in which it could be more counter- productive. I find that very sad indeed. I appeal to the Minister to reconsider the mish-mash that we have and to withdraw it now and start again with the value of the experience that we have been able to put together so far. I oppose the Bill totally and utterly in its present form, but I still support the concept, if properly presented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The object of the Sex Discrimination Bill is to give effect to certain provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women-to eliminate so far as possible discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy in certain areas, to eliminate so far as possible discrimination involving sexual harrassment in the work place and in educational institutions, and to promote recognition and acceptance of the principle of the equality of men and women. The Bill before us is one stage in a process of political struggle and activism stretching back many years. In spite of those struggles, sexual inequality in our society has persisted and in some areas, especially during a recession such as that we are in at present, the problems that people face have sharpened.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to speak at great length because Senator Walters has already displayed tonight part of a tactic of a section of the Opposition-deliberately to delay this Bill becoming law, deliberately to try to filibuster and prevent its passage. I prefer to take the world view and repeat, a bit like a commercial , what Senator Crowley and other honourable senators have said-that at the United Nations Conference on the Decade for Women, held in Copenhagen in 1980, it was pointed out that women make up 50 per cent of the adult population and one-third of the official labour force; that they perform two-thirds of all working hours; that they receive one-tenth of the world income and that they own less than one per cent of property.

That is what this Bill is about. It is the beginning of an attempt to redress a world phenomenon. Australia is playing its part in trying to change the situation under which women have been discriminated against. In Australia, the female average wage is about 78 per cent of the male average wage. Surveys carried out by the Australian Council of Trade Unions indicate that there are significant differences between the incomes of males and females, particularly in over award payments and superannuation. I speak with some experience because I was secretary of a printers union in New South Wales which amalgamated with another printing union. I discovered that women in the other union had had their male rate taken from them in 1937. Significantly, this happened because of the threat of cheap Japanese imports at that time. Those women had far lower over award payments than men. That is one of the most insidious ways in which women in this country are exploited. In the late 1960s we were able to sustain a political and industrial campaign so that those women could redress their situation. The significant thing is-it is true of this legislation-that we were able to use consciousness raising techniques and get people to see that women were being unfairly treated.

My colleagues, the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, and Senator Zakharov have drawn attention during this debate to some of the other inequalities that exist. I refer to just some of them. Nearly two-thirds of women are employed in only three occupational groupings-clerical, sales and service, and sport and recreation. Women are seldom found in key decision making positions. In 1983 women filled only 14 per cent of administrative, executive and managerial positions. Only 5 per cent of all apprentices were female. If we take out the hairdressing industry, that figure becomes 2 per cent. Women are more vulnerable to unemployment than men because they tend to be concentrated in those industries I have described, and particularly in unskilled and part time jobs. In times of recession like we are experiencing at the moment this vulnerability is reinforced by the attitude that women's jobs are of secondary importance. The fact that such an attitude is still prelevant demonstrates how fragile and superficial is the concept of equal opportunity. This points to the urgent need for this sex discrimination legislation. A British study shows that fewer than one in five male workers now conform to the traditional stereotype of being the sole financial support for a wife and dependent children. An article by Yvonne Preston in today's edition of the Sydney Morning Herald refers to the Australian figures and states:
In practice, less than 20 per cent of all Australian families now fit the ' ideal' mould of working father, fully dependent wife and dependent children.

So it can be seen that this idealised version of the perfect family that has so often been promoted is not based on fact. A growing number of women make a crucial contribution to family support. According to the ACTU figures, 42 per cent of all married women are in the labour force. A complete reappraisal of the way in which jobs and incomes are allocated between men and women is needed on the grounds of family needs as well as equal opportunity. (Quorum formed) Mr Deputy President, I was about to refer to the need of working women to have child care facilities available when Senator Walters began competing for the title of Tasmanian backwoodsperson of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —A point of order, Mr Deputy President. It should be pointed out to the honourable senator that it is in order to draw attention to the state of the House, that there is an obligation to keep the House, and that no Ministers were present. In view of the priority the Government has given--
—What is your point of order, Senator Martin?
—My point of order is that the honourable senator has no right to cast aspersions on Senator Walters's right to call quorums.
—There is no point of order.
—On the point of order--
—I have ruled on that and need no further assistance. There is no point of order.
—I think it is worth while pointing out that there was an agreement, which, of course, Senator Walters refused to have anything to do with .
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President.
—Is this a new point of order? I have dealt with the previous one.

—I want to make it quite clear that there was no agreement with respect to quorums. I made it clear to Senator Button that I was in no position to commit my Party on that, and I did not commit it on that. If this Government wants the Senate to sit, it has to sit subject to the normal conditions which require the Senate to be kept if any senator draws attention to the state of the House.
—These matters are not points of order and should not be debated. Senator Childs has the call.

—This Labor Government recognises that Australian women do not yet experience total equality with men, nor full participation in all aspects of our society. I read that from the platform of the Australian Labor Party. The Sex Discrimination Bill indicates that the Government is committed to redressing these inequalities. I contrast this with the attitudes of members of the conservative parties.
—Do you support the 53 amendments?

—We could not have an example of more extreme behaviour. If we look at the Liberal Party, although I am inclined to call it a Tory party, considering the way people have been behaving, we can see that it has been torn apart. On the one hand we have the anti-feminist fringe. People to the left, right and centre are taking different positions on this legislation. There is also the hard core of people who are resisting this elementary change. On the other hand, in the same political party, of which Senator Walters is a member, we have enlightened people. I remind you, Mr Deputy President, that the Hon. Ian Macphee wrote to all Opposition back benchers saying that the campaign against the Convention and the Bill 'has been led by women from privileged backgrounds who seem intent on preventing less privileged women from achieving a similar equality'. That is what Ian Macphee said. We are all aware that the New South Wales Young Liberal movement, at its State Conference in June, condemned the opposition to the Sex Discrimination Bill as being spearheaded at the Federal level by Senator Walters. Those are the voices of other people within the Liberal Party. I add the voice of Dame Beryl Beaurepaire who stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Australians of true Liberal principles have no alternative but to support it.

That is, the Sex Discrimination Bill. I pay tribute to Senator Hill who spoke earlier tonight. He reflected the better traditions of liberalism in this country. The opposition to the Bill is being mounted by a small minority, a particularly vocal minority, sometimes getting down to one or two people. These are the people who, with their twisted interpretations of the Bill, are seeking to mislead people in Australia. Indeed, they are frightening people in Australia with their misconceptions, deliberate or otherwise, of the Bill. Of course, Senator Walters was joined recently in her opposition to the Bill by the Leader of the National Party in Australia, Mr Doug Anthony. I again quote from today's Sydney Morning Herald. In that same article Yvonne Preston stated:

Doug Anthony is the latest vocal exponent of the line. He appealed at a recent National Party Federal Council meeting to the silent majority whose voices, he said, had been drowned out by trendies who threaten the Family . . .

So now Doug Anthony is on the band-wagon of trying to frighten people. Another group in this conservative reactionary organisation is the Australian Festival of Light. A resource paper circulated by the Festival of Light claims that Australia should not ratify the United Nations Convention because those countries which have ratified it include most communist regimes, many totalitarian dictatorships, but few democracies and only one English-speaking country. Of course, Senator Archer repeated that. He ignored Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Austria and all the other countries which have taken that stand. If no other country were doing this Australia, because of our traditions, should be going forward. As was demonstrated earlier tonight by Senator Crowley, we have been first before and there is no reason, if a thing is principled and correct, why we should tail behind other countries. Unfortunately, this is scaremongering of the lowest order. It is racist and bigoted.

The Festival of Light also argued that the definition of discrimination in the United Nations Convention is so broad that the end result could be mixed public toilets, mixed hospital wards and mixed prisons. That sort of way-out statement should be treated with ridicule. Unfortunately, we are talking about a world wide movement; it is part of the conservative movement in the world. The illiberal movement in the world uses the fears and knowledge of people facing a world recession. It uses their fear that the family is being undermined by the economic crisis which we are facing in order to frighten them and in order to use their fear for its own political purposes. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an article in the International Herald Tribune dated 5 October which is about Senator Edward Kennedy. It is headed 'Kennedy Enters Moral Majority's Den' . The article draws attention to the fact that Senator Kennedy went to a meeting of the Moral Majority and contested the point of view of the conservatives in America, the people who tried to use the mailing out of documents to three million people to try to frighten them and to involve them in political issues in their concerns about religious or moral questions. I seek leave to have that article incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
KENNEDY ENTERS MORAL MAJORITY'S DEN
Liberal Senator Lectures on Church and State at Fundamentalist Campus
By Celestine Bohlen
Washington Post Service

LYNCHBURG, Virginia-Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, a favorite foil of the Moral Majority in its crusade against liberals and big government, came to the bastion of the Rev. Jerry Falwell's conservative fundamentalist empire to warn of the dangers of mixing religion and politics.

In remarks Monday night that his staff billed as his most significant since he spoke to the 1980 Democratic National Convention, Mr Kennedy advised that ' people of conscience should be careful how they deal in the word of their Lord.'

'I respectfully suggest,' he said in a pointed reference to the lobbying efforts of the Moral Majority and other conservative groups, 'that God has taken no position on the Department of Education-and that a balanced-budget constitutional amendment is a matter for economic analysis, not heavenly appeals .'
Conservative groups favor abolishing the Department of Education and support a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution.

Mr Kennedy said there is a temptation for men and women of faith 'to misuse government in order to impose a value which they cannot persuade others to accept. But once we succumb to that temptation, we step onto a slippery slope where everyone's freedom is at risk.'

'The real transgression occurs when religion wants government to tell citizens how to live uniquely personal parts of their lives,' he said, citing abortion and prohibition as examples where 'the proper role of religion is to appeal to the conscience of the individual, not the coercive power of the state.'

The Senator homed in on several issues, including abortion, the Equal Rights Amendment and, most prominently, the nuclear freeze, all frequent targets of Mr Falwell's sermons and mailings to the three million members of the Moral Majority.

On the nuclear freeze, which he supports and whose supporters have been branded by Mr Falwell as 'freezeniks,' Mr Kennedy stressed the importance of public debate. 'What the opponents have no right to do, is to assume that they are infallible, and so any argument against the freeze will do, whether it is true or false.'
'There is no morality in the mushroom cloud,' he said.
Mr Kennedy spoke at Liberty Baptist College, the education arm of the Thomas Road Baptist Church, where Mr Falwell preaches.

The college's chapter of the Young Americans for Freedom, which claims to be the largest in the country with 270 students, this week distributed 600 leaflets outlining Mr Kennedy's record on such issues as abortion, the nuclear freeze and homosexual rights.

'Kennedy represents everything that is wrong with American society,' said the group's president, John Pyle, 22. 'He is the antithesis of good government, constitutional government and the Judeo-Christian ethic. He is everything people look to when they point to the liberal label.'
Mr Kennedy's appearance at Liberty Baptist College was somewhat of a fluke. Several months ago, it was reported that the senator had mistakenly received a Moral Majority membership card in the mail.

That prompted a letter to the senator from Cal Thomas a vice president of Moral Majority, urging him to keep the card and to stop by for a '50 cent tour' of the college if he was ever in the area, according to Mr Kennedy's aides. 'It was a very breezy, light letter,' said Melody Miller, assistant press secretary to the senator, who she said 'wrote back that he would be delighted, and while he was there would like to speak. They fell off their chairs, gulped and said okay.'

Mr Kennedy was brought to Lynchburg in Mr Falwell's private plane and dined at this home before the speech. The senator's appearance was billed as the first half of a 'liberal-conservative' debate, with Representative Jack Kemp, Republican of New York, invited to speak for the conservative side. His address will not be until next month, however.

Laying out his standards for dividing religious beliefs and public policy, Mr Kennedy took a jab at President Ronald Reagan, who, Mr Kennedy said, told an evangelical gathering in Dallas that he endorsed their efforts. 'To many Americans, that pledge was a sign and a symbol of a dangerous breakdown in the separation of church and state.' Mr Kennedy said.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill which is before us today is not about the spread of communism or the provision of mixed toilets. The Bill is about eliminating discrimination, about ensuring equality of opportunity. It extends the right of individuals. It does not entail any measures of compulsion or conscription. The aim of the Bill is not to force any profession or trade to employ 50 per cent men and 50 per cent women, as some opponents have claimed. The Bill does not force women to go out to work. It implies that women should have the option to work and the option to have economic independence. The Bill does nothing to undermine the traditional role of women as child bearers and homecarers. What it recognises is that women should have alternative lifestyles and social roles from which to choose. That is what it is all about. The Bill's efforts to promote equality of opportunity and to extend the right of all individuals can only serve to improve family relations, not undermine them.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not over-idealise traditional family life. I agree with the information provided by Senator Tate when he spoke in this debate on 21 October that studies undertaken by the Institute of Family Studies in Melbourne show that the stereotype roles of husbands and wives can cause marital breakdown. Relationships between partners will be much healthier if they are based on equality and individual fulfilment. I suspect that some of the conservative opponents such as Senator Walters are living with the concepts of their grandparents as far as relationships are concerned and do not realise that young people are much more into sharing problems and roles. I am afraid the reason the Liberal Party lost the last election was that its policies and attitudes, as articulated by people such as Senator Walters and Senator Archer, were incompatible with the experience of young people today.

The need for federal sex discrimination legislation is supported by evidence from my own State. I do not think that Senator Archer could comprehend that there has been legislation, as Senator Crowley pointed out, in South Australia. I draw attention to that fact that anti-discimination legislation has been in effect in New South Wales since 1977. In the year 1981-82-the latest year for which figures are available-437 complaints of discrimination on the grounds of sex were lodged with the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Board. This represented 47 per cent of all complaints lodged. Ninety-four per cent of complainants were female and most of the complaints concerned employment. The number of complaints concerning sexual harassment doubled from the year 1980-81 to the year 1981-82. I could spend the next 10 minutes, having been involved in industry, describing the examples of sexual harassment of which I am aware. Unless we identify and challenge the problem we will not get an attitude change. It is not something that will go away overnight. We must get an attitude change by drawing people's attention to the fact that sexual harassment itself is absolutely untenable. This legislation is a major step in raising the consciousness of people and showing them that discrimination is just not on, from now on, in this modern society in which we live.

The New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Board is currently conducting a research project and is investigating the problems of women being denied credit because of their sex or marital status. An analysis of complaints already received indicates that marital status and sex do affect lending decisions. The assumption that a male head of a household is needed to make financial decisions is still widespread. The New South Wales experience indicates the volume of discriminatory practices that occur. It also demonstrates the importance of having appropriate legislation and machinery to redress this discrimination.

I had an interjection earlier tonight about my attitude in regard to the 53 amendments. I think that some of the amendments are unfortunate, but this legislation has to become law so we have to accept them. The Bill represents a genuine attempt by this Government to meet criticism of the legislation. Every person other than the lunatic fringe in this society accepts that the amendments have to be put in place on that basis. The legislation has a dual role. It must remedy particular abuses; it must also draw attention to the general nature of discrimination. It must make the community aware of its existence and make this an issue. This Bill is one step in the process of attempting to achieve full equality for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the second reading of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983. I indicate that I will be supporting this Bill through all stages of its passage. I hope that some improvements will be made to it at the Committee stage. However, I regard this as an extremely important piece of legislation and I hope it will soon be passed by this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened to a number of speeches that were made on this Bill and in particular to the worries which Senator Archer, for example, had tonight. I note that he objects to many other forms of discrimination. I do not know what he has done about it. I say in regard to discrimination covered by this legislation in regard to sex, harassment and so forth that it is high time that legislation was put down, enforced and made effective.

One must realise that the Bill before us seeks to implement, in part, the terms of a convention-the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. I think that honourable senators ought to be reminded that this Convention was signed in 1976 by a delegation of very distinguished women from this country led by the then Attorney-General, Bob Ellicott. It was important that the Convention should be signed and ratified. I regret there was a delay in the ratification while we endeavoured to get States and other organisations to comply with the provisions of the Convention so that we would not be embarrassed when it came to ratification. I think this Bill has had the support of the Liberal Party of Australia generally. I am proud of the fact that legislation of this type has been supported by the Liberal Party for many years. Although there are some in my Party who now appear to want to slide away from that support, I believe it is important that we have opposed discrimination which women in the community have suffered for many years. It is important that we do all we can in that regard.

I want to draw attention to the fact that there are four objects in this Bill. I think the Bill reasonably implements them. The first object is to give effect to certain provisions of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. It is important to point out that the Bill does not implement all the terms of the Convention; only some parts of the Convention are being implemented. Yet one would not get that impression from the nonsense which is talked in the community about how the Convention has been signed by a number of communist countries and therefore the Convention must be very wicked. I believe that the Convention is an admirable document which sets out very fairly the objects we should seek to remove discrimination against women.

The second object is to eliminate so far as possible discrimination against persons on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy in the areas of work, accomodation, education, the provision of goods, facilities and services, the disposal of land, the activities of clubs and the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs. It does not cover all the areas of discrimination. It covers areas in which the Commonwealth has jurisdiction and in that regard I think it is important that the Commonwealth should do its very best to ensure that those discriminations are removed.

The third object is to eliminate so far as possible discrimination involving sexual harassment in the work place and in educational institutions. I think the terms of the Bill set out quite fairly the ways in which that is to be done. The amendments which the Government has already indicated it is including are designed to ensure that that does not become an exaggerated objective, an objective by which unfair actions would be taken under the guise of removing such harassment.

The fourth object is to promote recognition and acceptance within the community of the principle of the equality of men and women. I shall say more about that towards the end of my speech because I believe this Bill not only makes provision and legal arrangements to enforce this but also is a great educational opportunity for us to try to change the views of many men who over the years have believed that they have some God given right to dominate women.

One has to face the fact that this country is very spotty so far as our actions are concerned in removing discrimination. Three States already have legislation. The Bill contemplates the marrying and working together of Federal and State legislation in this area. But there is no such legislation in the States of Tasmania, Western Australia and Queensland. It is to our eternal disgrace that there is not yet legislation in those States. I believe it is coming fairly quickly in Western Australia but I see very little signs of it in the other two States. I believe that Australia stands to be condemned, and is condemned and criticised, in instances where States show no sign of imposing laws to stop this discrimination.

When this debate commenced Senator Durack said that this was the first opportunity to legislate and that we, in the Opposition, when in Government, would have in due course legislated. I am sorry that we took so long about it. I think we should have moved much more quickly. I think that our legislation would have been timid. I think that this Bill, while not the last word on the subject, is one which goes a considerable distance. One must remember that this Bill does not include affirmative action. Yet one would never believe that from some of the representations we receive. This provision has been temporarily dropped from the Bill. Of course, the situation is that many women will continue to suffer some discrimination and lack of equal opportunity for some years.

There has been a great deal of hysteria in the course of this general debate. One has received all kinds of representations. Senator Archer very happily gave us the number of petitions that have been signed and sent to this place. There is no doubt that in regard to the organisation of that sort of influence, the anti-sex discrimination people have had the major effect. They have made representations and they are well organised. For example, I have a file of correspondence which has come to, I think, all members of the Parliament in the last week or two. The file is very interesting. It is made up of photostat letters; none of them has been personally signed. Nobody was prepared to sign a letter. Letters have been written and in many cases obviously photostated on the same photostat machine. The envelopes were addressed by different hands from those which wrote the letters. All of the letters were delivered to the Parliament last Monday and again this Monday, thereby saving the postage. All members were given a rather stereotyped letter indicating how fearful people were of how they were going to be changed from women into men, how they were going to be forced into the workshop and how the family was going to be ruined. There are minor differences between the letters. However, this is a crude form of propaganda. I am sure that many of these people are quite sincere in their belief that the Bill might do what they think it will do. However, when one reads the letters one realises that they are all out of date. They have not taken into account the amendments which have already been put down by the Government and by other honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there is no guarantee that they will be passed.

—That is what Senator Walters might think; I think that they will be. Clearly, there is a great deal of nonsense in these letters which we are expected to read because they are photostated and given to us. I do not intend to waste postage by writing replies. I make now my statement that I believe that they do not show any real argument whatsoever against the Bill. What they show is that a number of people have been grossly misled into thinking that the Bill says things which it does not, and that it will do things to the family which it will not. A fog of deception has been raised by many of the people who have objected to it. Some of these people, of course, are in the group which I would call--
—Most of that fog comes from a fog horn too, Senator.

—Well, I suppose it does. There is one noted lady in Victoria, Mrs Babette Francis, well named, who has been bashing away and insulting our shadow Minister for some time. She went to the remarkable extreme of getting her husband, who happens to be a Queen's Counsel-of course that impresses members of parliament-to write a legal opinion saying how right she was. I wonder what would have happened if he had not written that opinion. Unfortunately, many of these women who want to be doormats have not been given information about the Bill. They are told stories about the Bill and they have written letters dutifully. I regret that they are so misled and so misunderstanding of the vital needs which women have. This Bill does not take away rights of women. It gives greater rights to women. It means that those who want to go out into the work force, those who want to have education, those who want to join clubs, those who want to be active in different ways, can do so. It does not take away from anybody the rights which they already have.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, of course, reasonable criticisms of the Bill. They have been raised and they are raised by, among others, my colleagues on this side who have amendments which they wish to move. I hope that the Government will be sensible enough to accept the genuineness of that action. It will not come from the photostated letters, the crudities that we had years ago when we had the Family Law Bill first before the Senate and when we had the amending Bill before the Senate recently. They have learned not to have everybody using the same envelope and putting several petitions into it, but they have not learned very much about how to put to members of parliament in a reasoned way their personal views.

As I said, the Bill has Liberal support. Senator Walters laughs. She might not be a Liberal. I do not know. But the Bill has general Liberal support. It is supported by the Liberal Party and I am proud of that fact. The Government and its Ministers have already foreshadowed many amendments in the Bill. I think in some respects they have probably gone too far insofar as they will put in amendments to satisfy the predilictions of some honourable senators to say that it is not about abortion, it is not about this and it is not about that. I do not think it matters, though it clutters up the Bill to put into it various provisions which perhaps are not strictly necessary. But if it removes the possibility of people making this criticism, I suppose that is all to the good.

In regard to our Party, I pay tribute to the shadow Minister responsible for this matter, the Hon. Ian Macphee, for the way in which he has handled this Bill over a long period. I believe that he has been the subject of a completely unnecessary and completely scandalous campaign of denigration because of the way in which he has handled this matter. He is obviously a man who sincerely believes in the elimination of discrimination. I know personally that he has been of this opinion for many years. He has fought strenuously for it and he has been unfailing in listening to criticisms and in trying to accommodate views of people, very often unreasonable people, in regard to this Bill. I pay an enormous tribute to Ian Macphee, who I believe is something of a hero insofar as the handling of this Bill is concerned.

I cannot say altogether the same of my National Party of Australia colleagues. I see that they will ultimately oppose provisions. They will vote with us, I think, on the second reading of this Bill, but obviously after that they will slope off in various directions. I believe it might have been better if we had not bothered to try too many compromises with them and we had gone our separate ways from the beginning. However, my colleagues have tried to keep a unity of purpose in this regard and I suppose I have to some extent been one of the unfortunate victims of this because I will vote for an amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill-what we often call a pious amendment-part of which I do not agree with at all. But I am assured that it will not succeed, so I can do that with a fairly clear conscience.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you cross the floor? You have the opportunity.
—Opportunity is not what I want. I do not want the opportunity of doing things. No, to keep the National Party honest I am prepared to stay with even a nonsensical amendment.
—How could you keep the National Party honest?

—We can always try. I turn to the proposed amendment. I think one ought to make one's attitude clear. The amendment, which is to be moved to the motion that the Bill be now read a second time, seeks to include:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . , but the Senate, whilst welcoming the intention of the Bill to remove discrimination against people on the basis of their sex, marital status or pregnancy, is of the opinion that:
(a) the Bill should not rely on the external affairs power as a head of power;

Quite frankly, I think the Bill does need a reliance on the external affairs power. I think it is important that we should not be relying merely upon the question of whether it comes within other powers that are not comprehensive, for example, and that we go to education. In regard to the reliance upon the trading corporations power, if someone is in a trading corporation, of course that person comes within Commonwealth jurisdiction. But if that person is a single trader, he might otherwise be able to discriminate to his heart's content. I think that is unfortunate. I think it is therefore important that we rely upon the external affairs power. I am not frightened of the powers of the Commonwealth. Where the courts have said that they exist and they are dealt with reasonably, I believe that the Commonwealth is under a duty to exercise its powers. The second part of this proposed amendment, which I also find strange, states:
(b) Australia's signature to the United Nations Convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women should not be used to extend the powers of the Commonwealth;

Of course it is not being used to extend the powers of the Commonwealth. It is either within the power or it is not and it is clear, from recent cases, that it is within the power. The third part of our pious amendment states:

(c) the removal of discrimination against people on the basis of sex should be recognised as not obliging anyone to enter the paid work force or alter their view of their responsibility towards their spouses or children;
I quite agree with that. I do not think it does, but it is practical, I think, to make that clear. The fourth provision states:

(d) no decision or action by any educational or child care or other body established for the education of students or the care of children in accordance with the doctrines of a religion or creed or in accordance with stated principles shall be affected where that decision or action has been taken in good faith to enable the body to conform with those doctrines or principles;
The foreshadowed amendments to the Bill possibly already cover that, but I think it is probably wise to make it clear that it is not intended to do that. In the last case:
(e) nothing in the Bill should be taken as approving those articles of the Convention which are not implemented by the Bill.

Of course it does not do that and it cannot be implied that it should do so. But if it saves the worries of some person by stating that, I have not objection. So I will vote for that motion of principle or pious amendment, as I said, but I make it very clear that if I thought the first parts of it were to be adopted that would be a different matter and I would have to reconsider.

I do not intend to make a long speech in this second reading debate. I think the important thing is to go into the Committee stage and to ensure that there the best provisions are made. I think important machinery provisions of the Bill are somewhat defective and I regret that the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills has not previously picked these up and really concentrated on them. I hope it will.

Some provisions in the Bill are dubious from a civil liberties point of view. There are reversals of the onus of proof. There are provisions which state that the rules of evidence shall not apply. This legislation will be enforced by the Human Rights Commission, a commission of laymen, which will make decisions that will not necessarily be based on rules of law. Those decisions will then be prima facie evidence before the court which hears the appeal. The court will be bound to accept that evidence unless rebutted. So the onus would be very much on someone who wanted to prove to the contrary. I think there has been an oversight in this Bill in that we are not just dealing with an organisation that will inquire into sex discrimination. We are making provision for people actually to make judgments, and award thousands of dollars in damages and are binding courts in regard to evidence which may be based merely upon the view taken of a person by such people. The court will not be able to look at the real evidence. Certainly, I think there are still in the Bill problems relating to the machinery provisions that need to be solved. I look forward to doing that at the Committee stage.

This Bill is an important educative measure. I think it will make people realise that if they have discriminated in the past, if they have taken the arrogant view which many men have taken, their ways may well be changed. The conciliatory provisions of this Bill may be very important. But I think it is important to realise that we live in a society which, for 150 years, has been male dominated. We live in a society which has denied to women education and equal opportunity in business. That is obvious from the very few women who hold high positions in society compared with the situation in some other countries. Women have been afflicted with this discrimination and it is essential that something be done.

The position in relation to clubs also is very important. I know that the Bill deals only with situations in clubs where women are accepted. It does not deal with the situation that exists in one sex clubs. On the other hand, it seems to be important that business women should be able to go and hear about day to day affairs and what is going on. They are restricted in life in many ways. Many able women in this community with high qualifications cannot get the sort of decent jobs which they ought to have.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is degrading discrimination, isn't it?

—It is degrading discrimination, I agree. No doubt many women have gone to their graves without ever having overcome the problem. It is degrading for our country not to have used the facilities and abilities which women have. It is all right for some people who have written to me to say that women like living with their husbands and being homemakers. But we know there is a great variety of women in positions in society these days. We know of the problems of single women with families. We know that there are women in this society who have never had the chance to get married and who are left, after their parents die, without the opportunity to retrain and go into the work force if they so wish.
—Those who do not have the support of husbands.

—Yes, the percentage of women, as Senator Martin said, who do not have the support of husbands is very considerable. We can no longer say that the family unit comprising a wife, husband and children is typical. There are many other varieties of life style and women should be able to take up each opportunity that comes their way. I am, therefore, very pleased to see this Bill come forward. I realise that it contains defects. I regret the pettifogging way it has been approached by many people in the community and the way in which many people have deceitfully tried to dissemble the Bill and the great purpose which it will serve. I will certainly support it with every effort, to ensure that we have excellent legislation which will be enforced by the Commonwealth and of which we can be proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — First and foremost, I wish to congratulate Senator Missen upon his constructive and fair approach to our sex discrimination legislation. It was a contribution which, along with that of Senator Robert Hill would, I feel quite confident, make J. S. Mills proud to have them call themselves liberals. I am also relieved to hear Senator Missen, as a legal man, give his opinion of the Bill. I was much happier to hear that opinion than I was to accept those of Dr Isbister, Professor Chipman and Charles Francis, Queen's Counsel. I had some doubts about the integrity of an opinion that came from the husband of Mrs Babette Francis, the leader of Women who Want to be Women. It occurred to me that it was about as valuable as would be the opinion of Mrs Eileen Bond, shall we say, if asked what she thought of the ethics of the New York Yacht Club. We would get an interesting opinion but not necessarily an unbiased one.
—But a superior one-from Mrs Bond, I mean.

—No doubt. Very briefly I wish to respond to some of Senator Archer's reservations because I join Senator Missen in feeling that he has been grossly misguided. One of his problems with the convention-I have heard this from a number of other sources also-is that countries with which Australian commonly compares itself, such as the United States of America, the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand, have not yet ratified the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. People who make this criticism fail to understand that all four countries have had in place, for many years, laws of one sort or another which seek to do exactly what our Sex Discrimination Bill seeks to do. In many cases those laws are much stronger, have much wider application and attract much more severe penalties. For example, in the United States, which has a Bill of Rights, a number of pieces of legislation-I am thinking specifically of that applying to education-contain sections which prohibit completely and explicitly all disrcrimination on the grounds of sex. The United Kingdom has had sex discrimination legislation-I think it is called equal opportunity legislation-since 1975.
—Plus the European Court of Justice.

—Exactly. In Canada, which also has a Bill of Rights which protects, to a degree, the rights of women as well as of everybody else, a number of the provinces have also very strong and comprehensive sex discrimination legislation. New Zealand has its Human Rights Commission. Another misapprehension of Senator Archer related to what he described as affirmative action. This is not the affirmative action which we hope one day to introduce in this Parliament, because what he was describing was the notion of quotas, a concept which is accepted in very few parts of the world. Scandinavian countries have come to grips with it in some respects, but we are talking about the type of affirmative action that will be very thoroughly discussed and presented to us , we hope, within the next 12 months. It is along the lines of what was being discussed by the previous Liberal Government, which produced, as fruit of the endeavours of the National Labour Consultative Council in 1980, guidelines for employers entitled 'Equal Employment Opportunities for Women'. Substantially, what is being advocated in that document, which was put together by the Women's Employment Committee of the National Labour Consultative Council, a committee consisting of employers-the Confederation of Australian Industry-employees-the Australian Council of Trade Unions-and the Federal Government, is what we will be advocating. Mr Acting Deputy President, I request leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
—Which government was that, Senator?
—Well, it was whatever government was in power in November 1980.
—That would have been a Fraser Government.
—I think that would be correct, yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The booklet read as follows-
SECTION I
INTRODUCTION

Employers, trade unions and Governments agree that discrimination against women in employment is unacceptable in Australia today. All are becoming increasingly aware of the need to demonstrate their commitment to non-discrimination by introducing positive procedures to promote Equal Employment Opportunities.

This paper suggests possible action for those wishing to encourage Equal Employment Opportunities in their enterprise. It is not meant to be a complete prescription for every enterprise or work situation, given the wide variations which exist in circumstances and conditions.
