In particular, the degree to which an enterprise will be able to implement the guidelines will to a large extent depend on the size of the enterprise and the number of its employees.
The paper should therefore be seen as providing a set of guidelines from which policies and procedures suited to the needs of the individual enterprise can be developed.
While recognising this practical limitation, the NLCC believes that the use of the guidelines will make an effective contribution to the achievement of equal opportunity in Australia.
International Standards

International labour standards condemn unjustified discrimination. In 1973 the Commonwealth Government with the full support of major employer organisations, trade unions and State Governments ratified International Labour Organisation Convention No. 111, Discrimination (Employment and Occupation) 1958, which prohibits discrimination in employment and occupation on seven grounds including sex. National and State Committees on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation were set up to investigate complaints of discrimination in all aspects of employment. The Committees do not have a statutory basis but are able to report the matter to the Minister who may name discriminatory employers or organisations in Parliament.

In 1975, the United Nations International Women's Year, the ILO adopted the Declaration of Equality of Opportunity and Treatment for Women Workers and a Plan of Action which provides guidelines on measures which might be taken to meet the objectives of the Declaration.

The National Labour Consultative Council (NLCC) has prepared these Guidelines for Employers on Equal Employment Opportunities for Women as a contribution towards implementation of the ILO Plan of Action in Australia.
Legislation

Several Governments in Australia have introduced anti-discrimination legislation to lend force to their policies of equality of opportunity and non- discrimination in the workplace. The various Acts provide sanctions against those who infringe the law, and resulting newspaper accounts of discrimination cases often attract publicity which may adversely affect the discriminatory enterprise or organisation.

In the industrial sphere the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission accepts that it has a role to play in the elimination of discriminatory practices. The NLCC has endorsed the inclusion in Federal awards of anti-discrimination clauses .
Trade Unions

The trade unions' peak council, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), has adopted a Charter for Working Women. This Charter emphasises the unions' policies of elimination of employment discrimination and promotion of equal employment opportunity. Many unions have also established committees to examine the particular employment problems of their women members.
Management

A well planned Equal Opportunity policy for women employees not only results in equitable treatment of individuals but has advantages for employers. It allows optimum use of all human skills and talents available both inside and outside the enterprise. It may help to reduce recruitment and training costs by assisting in the retention of skilled women. It could also encourage women to seek employment with the enterprise as, by adopting Equal Opportunity policies, it will be seen to be responding to social change. This may also improve the image of the enterprise in the eyes of customers, clients and associates.
SECTION II
ESTABLISHING AN EEO PROGRAM
Responsibility
Management should be responsible for, and totally committed to, the implementation of the EEO program, Unless such a commitment exists at all levels of management the program is unlikely to succeed.
The oversight of the Implementation and development of the program will normally be the function of the personnel department, and those responsible should pay regard to the need for:
The preparation of an EEO policy statement, and a program, for its implementation.
Circulation of information to employees on the operation and progress of the EEO program in the enterprise.
The collection and analysis of relevant employment data (eg. employee numbers, length of employment, duties, work skills of employees etc) (see Section III).
Preparation of EEO plans embracing specific EEO tasks (Section IV and V).
The development and implementation of evaluation procedures for determining the effectiveness of EEO program and plans (See Section VI).
EEO Policy Statement
The first step in the introduction of an EEO program is for the employer to decide on broad goals for introducing Equal Employment Opportunities into the enterprise.

A brief policy statement should be prepared for circulation to employees. This statement, expressing the employer's commitment to EEO, should also explain the policy and the intention to introduce an EEO program to implement that policy.
Employee Meetings
Meetings between the employer, manager and employees should be arranged. Employees should be encouraged to accept and enter into the spirit of the policy .

It is important to encourage employees to make suggestions and ask questions about EEO. This participation will help all employees to understand the implications of the Policy in terms of hiring; employer advertising; promotion; training; employment conditions; and opportunities for women and men to take up work previously restricted to one sex.
Publicity

The policy should be publicised within the enterprise. Information can be placed on notice boards or articles placed in work newsletters or journals where these exist. This can be a continuous arrangement as policies and programs are developed.
Unions

It is essential that unions be consulted during the development and implementation of EEO policies which affect their members. SECTION V
INTERVIEWING APPLICANTS

Women and men applicants should be interviewed in the same way, using the same objective selection criteria. These, combined with common-sense and courtesy, create a favourable impression of an organisation.

Interviewers should be most careful to ensure that there is no suggestion in any remarks made at the interview that married women are less entitled or less deserving of employment or promotion than other applicants.
Assumptions about Women Workers
Some interviewers may need to revise their own assumptions about the working patterns and lifestyle of women, because many common assumptions about working women today don't fit the facts.
These assumptions may include:
Women only work for a few years between school and marriage;
Women wouldn't want to travel;
Women with family responsibilities wouldn't/shouldn't work overtime;
Women wouldn't want to work in an all male environment.
The facts show otherwise:
Many women in the community now continue in employment after marriage;
Two-thirds of all working women are married;
The ACTU Maternity Leave test case has opened the way for provisions allowing many women to return to work after child bearing;
Most of the 160,000 sole parents in charge of families are women;
Some women with family responsibilities are prepared to make arrangements to cope with absences from home to allow them to work overtime or travel for their employer;
Many women are now working in jobs regarded traditionally as men's work.
Shortlisting
All applicants should be shortlisted according to the selection criteria for the job and not on false assumptions about women's working patterns.

A lack of facilities should not be used to eliminate women from consideration when shortlisting applicants for positions in traditional male areas. Organisations may already have separate facilities for female staff located nearby or it may be possible to make alterations to existing facilities at comparatively low cost to provide for women.
Any barriers, attitudinal or otherwise, to the employment of women in any area should be discussed with persons responsible for the Equal Employment Opportunity program in the organisation.
Preparation
Beforehand, the interviewer needs to determine selection criteria and list the special requirements for the job. Such requirements might include:
Working overtime (How long? How often?);
Travelling for the organisation (How long? How often?);
Lifting heavy weights (continuously or occasionally?);
Shift work (continuously or occasionally?);
Driving and maintenance of a vehicle.
At the Interview

The questions asked at the interview should focus on the job criteria and special requirements of the position. Generally interviewers should put the same questions and offer the same information about the job to men and women applicants.
Often interviewers ask women such questions as:
''Are you married?'';
''When are you going to start a family?'';
''What child care arrangements do you have?''.
What they really want to know is:
Whether an applicant will stay in the position;
Whether they will be able to fulfil the requirements of the job;
Whether they will be able to work regular overtime; or
Whether they will be frequently absent from work.
Questions should be framed to discover the applicant's willingness to comply with the job requirements:
''Would you be able to see the project through to its completion in September?' '.
''Are you prepared to work overtime twice a week and spend three days travelling each month?''.
Another legitimate source of information on an applicant's work pattern and attendance record will be the reports provided by referees.

The terms used at interview require sensitivity on the part of the interviewer. A women feels patronised if she is addressed as ''dear'' or ''girlie'' or ''lass '' or if she finds she will be ''joining the other girls'' in the organisation, no matter how kindly the words are meant.
The drawbacks of the job should not be overstated to women applicants. The positive side as well as the disadvantages should be covered.
Temporary transfers to other locations need not be described as unrelieved harshness;

The problems that may arise if lifting heavy weights is required should not be exaggerated given that there may be other people to help with lifting, or mechanical aids to be used, and employees can be taught the correct way to lift.
Application of Equal Employment Opportunity principles in selection interviewing will assist you choose the best person for the job.
Interview Summary
Interview men and women in the same way with objective selection criteria.
Prepare objective selection guides and questions.
Don't use inappropriate criteria.
Avoid using marital status as a criterion.
Do not use assumptions when establishing the criteria for a shortlist.
Don't make assumptions about applicants.
Avoid questions unrelated to job requirements.
Avoid using patronising phrases.
Don't overstate to women the drawbacks of the position.
SECTION VI
MONITORING AND EVALUATION OF EEO PLANS

At least once a year there should be a review of the total EEO plans for the preceding year and the overall progress of the EEO program. In small enterprises this could take the form of a staff meeting at which EEO achievements and results are discussed and original objectives and tasks reviewed in the light of experience. In large organisations there should be a detailed review of the EEO program, focusing on achievements and results. Whether progress has been adequate or not, and whether the objectives are ambitious enough, is essentially a decision for top management.
In the light of the annual review existing EEO plans may need to be revised, new objectives formulated and new tasks devised to overcome the specific problems encountered in the past year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think much of the criticism of our Bill, about its drafting, about its ambiguity and all the rest, is very familiar to those of us who have been aware of delaying tactics which are being used. Once again, I was extremely relieved to have Senator Missen's opinion that although the Bill is not an unqualified technical success, at least it comes close. The history of anti- discrimination legislation in Australia is quite long. I do not think many people would be aware of the fact that in 1923 the Western Australian State Government adopted a Bill on the Status of Women. It is a one clause Act and it is still on the books. It set out originally to eliminate discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status in relation to vocation and occupation. During the Committee stage debate the marital status qualification was taken out, as was the reference to occupation. The effect of that Act ultimately was to allow women in Western Australia to be admitted to the Bar.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1973, when the Whitlam Government ratified the International Labour Organisation Convention on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation, State committees were set up to deal with complaints of discrimination on the grounds of sex, race, colour, religion, political opinion, national extraction and social origin. These committees worked on the basis of education and conciliation. I note that earlier in this debate conciliation was being advocated as the way in which complaints of discrimination should be dealt with. In fact that is the way they have been dealt with for the last 10 years in Australia, more or less with success. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that conciliation is still a very large part of our Bill. The committees had not been functioning for very long; in fact it was only in December 1974, at a meeting of those who chaired the State committees-at that time I was chairing the Western Australian committee-that it was obvious to all of us that there must be legislation to back up the committees if we were at any time in the near future to be able to eradicate the systemic discrimination which was so pervasive in Australia. In 1975-of course this is history-the Racial Discrimination Act became law. This was intended by the Whitlam Government to be the forerunner of what was to be a national Act to prevent discrimination on the grounds of sex. That opportunity was not available to us, but in 1979, at a meeting convened by the National Women's Advisory Council, which had been set up by the Fraser Government, the question of sex discrimination legislation was very thoroughly discussed. The consensus at that meeting was that Australia needed sex discrimination legislation, and the sooner the better. In 1980 the Fraser Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. I have described previously in an adjournment debate in this place how that Convention was preceded by a Declaration of the United Nations which, by 1980, had been in existence for 35 years. In 1983 the Australian Labor Government ratified that Convention.

Mr Acting Deputy President, like Senator Missen and Senator Archer I have received a great many letters which fortell doom and gloom for the family and for Australian society if and when this legislation becomes law. As has been pointed out on a number of occasions, legislation very similar to that which we propose has been in existence since 1975 in South Australia, since 1976 in New South Wales and since 1976 in Victoria. I would like to quote Carmel Niland, President of the New South Wales State Anti-Discrimination Board, who said:
There is no evidence in New South Wales, Victoria or South Australia of devastation of the family through anti-discrimination legislation.

If we are to believe the dire prognostications of those who oppose the legislation on the ground of galloping moral terpitude, the effects should surely be obvious by now. I have conscientiously searched all the material sent to me over the last few months, some of it from genuine although misguided people, for evidence of the catastrophies that have been predicted. Unlike one of my correspondents, I am delighted, not dismayed, to find that 'mothers' rooms ' in some airports have been renamed 'parents' rooms', thus catering for the many fathers travelling with young children. Yet this fact is held out as evidence of South Australia becoming the Sodom or Gomorrah of the South. I believe that the introduction of this legislation and the other initiatives of this and various State governments, far from weakening, will lead to a greatly enhanced quality of relationships within that very resilient institution, the family. Some of the less palatable aspects of the family-its nuclear structure and its patriachial dominance-are already in the process of modification. This does not mean that the majority of Australians will not continue to seek the comfort and companionship of everyday existence within the more or less conventional family structure.

A brief look at Australian demographic changes since Federation demonstrates how drastically the family has changed and also how the family shows no sign of diminishing as the primary domestic organisational focus of the majority of Australians. It is a family which in many cases would amaze but probably delight our grandmothers who, around the turn of the century, would expect to spend most of their lives bearing and rearing children. The average age at marriage at the turn of the century was quite high by today's standards, about 25 years of age. The average number of births per marriage was six or seven, and most families would experience the loss of at least two children during infancy. The youngest child, born when the mother was well into her forties, maintained her in her child-rearing role well into her fifties-and the average age at death in 1910 was 63. Our grandmothers expected nothing but an adult lifetime devoted to child bearing and rearing.

In the most recent decade 90 per cent of women are shown to be married by the age of 35, and of those women who are now 30, 77 per cent married in their early twenties. Child bearing is postponed for a range of reasons, but predominately because of financial constraints and expectations, and the average two to three children of most marriages are at school by the time the mother is 35-still young, with another 35 years of active life ahead of her. The perceptive woman of the 1980s sees her life in stages in a way which would have been impossible for her great grandmother, for whom mothering was a life sentence, often with hard labour. This human rights legislation gives official recognition to the limitations which have been imposed upon Australians-particularly women but not only women-educationally, industrially and socially. In calculating the Australian award earnings every three months, the Australian Statistician looks at 2,500 common awards for males and 500 common awards for females. It has already been pointed out tonight that the work force in Australia is the most concentrated of all the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development as far as women's occupations are concerned. The average woman earns only 67 per cent of average male earnings.

Although equal pay for equal work is largely an industrial fact, equal work is still a long way off. The typical Australian woman seeking a job after some years out of the work force and lacking formal qualifications, as most Australian women do, is at an enormous disadvantage. This legislation is just one step-although a very important one-in the gigantic task of equalising the opportunities of average women and average men. For too long the achievements of women have been described in terms of the achievements of the gifted, the outstanding and the survivors in the jungle of socio-sexual Darwinism.

For those who insist that Australian women experience very little in the way of discrimination, I would like to include a few examples of the cases that have come to me continuously over the years. Just recently we have had extreme difficulty in persuading the defence forces to accept two young gifted women musicians into the Fifth Military District band. They were rejected on the grounds that women musicians in military bands may be required during time of war to become stretcher bearers. Arguments of this nature are never used to prevent women from becoming nurses. A shire council in Western Australia followed the rather regrettable lead of the Rockhampton City Council and decided that its young women employees should resign on marriage. In Western Australia women are not permitted to work underground in the mining industry. Males are not allowed to train as dental therapists. In one mining district trade apprentices are provided with married accommodation, so long as they are male. Women trade apprentices are not. The excuse that is being used for this is that accommodation is provided only for the recognised breadwinner. It is obviously too much for this mining company to recognise women as breadwinners. Women bus drivers have been restricted to two routes on both occasions a long way away from where those women live, on the grounds that there were no facilities-the euphemism for toilets-in the other depots.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this Western Australia you are talking about?

—It is Western Australia. Things will change there very soon. At a country golf club where women have recently been allowed to become full members, they are still not permitted to play on Sundays. For many women that is quite a penance because that is their only day off.
—Are these working women you are talking about?

—I am talking about working women. Yes, working women do play golf . Very recently I have had complaints of women applying to become, in one case, a surveyor and, in another case, a draughtswoman. In each case they were refused interviews on the ground that males only were required to apply for such jobs.
—How long ago was this?

—It was quite recently, within the last year. One of the more cheerful stories that I have to tell honourable senators is that women who had been banned from the two-up schools in Western Australia when they were illegal are now allowed to play. Since 1 August regulations have legalised two-up, whether it is played by males or females.
—When did that happen?

—Very recently. In closing, I would like to deal very briefly with a particular demonology which seems to have developed recently around the word ' feminism'. There are two reasons why I believe this needs to be dealt with, one of them being that the word itself is being misused in a quite scandalous fashion. The other reason is that, following from that misuse, good, strong, sensitive and independent women are denying their feminism because of lack of understanding. I went to a number of dictionaries and found that they all agreed that feminism is the theory that women should have political, economic and social rights equal to those of men. The second definition is that feminism describes the movement to win such rights for women.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many things that a feminist can be. A feminist may be male or female; hetero, homo, or bi-sexual; Christian, Jewish, Moslem or humanist; man-hating or loving; loving women and loving children; black, yellow or discoloured; active, passive or closet; radical, moderate, subversive or overt. Like any 'ism', feminism is a state of mind. Rebecca West, I think, wrapped it up very well when she said:
I am not too sure exactly what feminism means but I do know that I am called a feminist every time I make a statement which differentiates me from a doormat.
I am also happy to be able to report that Women Who Want To Be Women have been superseded by Women without Wettexes.

Nor does it cover anything to do with the exploitation of prostitutes by men. There is nothing in the Bill about that sort of discrimination-nothing in it about really exploiting women; not a word.

There is a difficulty of interpretation in this sort of legislation and a difficulty in trying to legislate against discrimination. All I can say is that we have to look at some of the proposed amendments to find out just how difficult that is. As I said when we debated the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Againt Women, the interpretation is the very difficult part. I did not interpret the Convention in the way in which some women did, some of the more conservative groups, such as Women Who Want to be Women, who have been denigrated in this place tonight by several remarks from the Government side of the chamber. But as it turns out, they were right, because what we must understand here is that this legislation goes to all sorts and all types of women.

Whilst I did not interpret-and I give credit to Senator Ryan, too; she probably did not interpret it so-the sexist books and education sections in the Convention as meaning getting rid of the Bible, some people did interpret it in that way. They were told that they were mad, that they were ratbags and that that was not the interpretation. However, in one school in a small country town we find that people interpreted it in that way. Seventy books, including the New Testament and the Old Testament, other religious stories and animal books, were removed from a Tasmanian school library and destroyed on the ground of their being sexist. Is that not an appalling indictment of the Bill? Is that not an appalling indictment of this international Convention? Is that not just what I said when I debated the subject? I said that the interpretation was so difficult and so broad that the Convention could mean anything that anyone wanted it to mean. Indeed, that is how that Headmistress in the Winnaleah District High School interpreted it, and she burnt the Bible, the New Testament and the Old Testament. She said that it was a sexist book. She took it out of the school library and burnt it.

When we were told of that by some of the more conservative groups, Senator Ryan laughed and said: 'What rubbish; that could not possibly happen'. All I am saying is that this Convention, on which the Bill relies, is so difficult to interpret and is so wide that anyone can interpret it in any way that he likes. It has been misinterpreted. Nevertheless, the radical feminist who took out the Bible and burnt it, and other radical feminists, will interpret it in the way that is wished. This has proved beyond any doubt that that is so. With the problems of interpretation we come to consider who will be the Sex Discrimination Commissioner. I wonder who it will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly not you.

—It certainly will not be me, but I would bet my bottom dollar that it will be another woman. If we have to put up with one of the Wendy McCarthys of this world, who could well end up as the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, imagine the sorts of interpretations of which we shall have to beware. I am really concerned about this Bill. I have great concerns about the freedoms that we have known in this country previously. I have great concerns that, whoever is appointed Sex Discrimination Commissioner, we shall have to worry about how she interprets the legislation along with how the Human Rights Commission then gets it. We have had figures thrown at us by Senator Ryan, Senator Giles and Senator Crowley, telling us how women do not attain managerial positions. One can do anything one likes with figures. Those honourable senators can give us the figures on how little women in the work force earn compared with men. But I have some figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics that I would like to cite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can remember that when I was a young psychology student I was mildly amused at the response that the renowned psychologist, Carl Jung, made to an interviewer's question. Having declined to answer some personal details about disagreements that he had with Sigmund Freud, he was asked whether he would mind if the details became known after his death. Jung replied that he would not mind. My mild amusement was due to the ambiguity of Jung's reply. He did not indicate whether he did not mind then, or would not mind after his death. Of course, after death none of us can mind what is said about us. However, we would prefer that anything said about us would not be embarrassing or hurtful to those whom we have left behind. My days as a student of Latin are far behind me, but I can remember reading: 'De mortuis nil nisi bonum', that is, 'Do not speak ill of the dead'. I would commend that approach to Brigadier P. J. Greville. I would also commend it to the editor of the Pacific Defence Reporter. Both Brigadier Greville and the Pacific Defence Reporter are guilty of a disgraceful exhibition, of condemning a person who cannot speak in his own defence.

SPEECH.PARA: In the latest issue of the Pacific Defence Reporter an article appeared with the title, 'Wilfred Burchett'. Wilfred Burchett died on 27 September this year. Despite what Brigadier Greville thought about Wilfred Burchett, he would have retained much more respect if he had said nothing about him, rather than write about him in the style of an embittered old man. I shall quote from that article shortly, but I firstly point out that Greville erred when referring to a former senator in this place. In the article, he said:
Burchett made the mistake of suing Senator Keane . . .

Senator Keane died in 1946, so I presume that the Brigadier meant Senator Kane. However, these are some of the matters stated by Greville in the article in the Pacific Defence Reporter. I will quote a few of them. The article opened in this way:
When I heard over the radio of Wilfred Burchett's death I confess to feeling a little satisfaction.
What a way to open an article about a person who has died! The article goes on in a worse fashion:
Burchett had talent and without doubt could act bravely; but he was a very dishonest man. There is evidence that at times he even believed his own lies.
If we think that is bad, worse is still to come. Later on in this article, Greville says:
The Australian Government should have charged him with treason . . .
Even further on, he said:

Wilfred Burchett was a traitor. The support he received from the Australian Journalists' Association disgusted me, not because he was a communist, but because these journalists cannot understand the enormity of his treason.
In another part of the article, referring to how Burchett left Australia, he said:
. . . he slunk out of the country as befitted a traitor, to die in exile.

In his article Greville stated that he was disgusted with the support that Burchett received from the Australian Journalists Association. I am disgusted at the attitude of Greville and the Pacific Defence Reporter in attacking a person no longer able to defend himself. Many people do not agree with Greville's assessment, but this is not the point that I am making. If Greville felt so strongly about Mr Burchett, he should have said these things while Burchett was alive. It seems uncharacteristically cowardly for Greville to wait until a person has died to launch a vitriolic attack on him. Both the Brigadier and the Pacific Defence Reporter should be aware that often there is dignity in silence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — Today I received an invitation from Senator Ryan inviting me to come to morning tea to meet and consult with some women and women's organisations. In the invitation, Senator Ryan said that she was meeting with leaders of some 30 key organisations for discussion on a consultation mechanism at Parliament House on 9 November. I was invited to morning tea with these representatives and Senator Ryan. Attached to that invitation was a list of the groups invited. As background, I will quote from an answer given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to Mr Macphee on 6 October. In relation to consultation with women, he said that it would be effective for:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . women members of Caucus to constitute a group which would have the responsibility for this process of consultation.

Such consultation was to be with women and women's organisations. That answer was given in response to a question by Mr Macphee about what the Prime Minister intended to do now that he had abolished the National Women's Advisory Council. I perused the list of women invited by Senator Ryan and, I gather, by the women in Caucus. I find it quite fascinating that the women of Caucus have not seen fit to ask so many of the women's organisations with which they have nothing in common. If the women of Caucus are to form a committee composed only of those women with whom they hold close views, or a committee with only one or two representatives of groups with which they do not altogether agree, such as Judith Cooper of the Catholic Women's League-who is probably the only such representative; there might be one or two others depending on the representation from the particular group-I do not think it will be a very representative committee.

The women of Caucus have deliberately left out all the women represented by the Women's Action Alliance. They obviously do not believe that the Alliance, which represents thousands upon thousands of women throughout Australia, has anything to contribute. They do not want to have anything to do with the group calling itself 'Women Who Want to be Women'. They have derided that group tonight in the Senate and have called it 'Woman Who Want to be Doormats', just because those women happen to be the sort who want to stay at home and bring up their children . They have not invited any of the hard working women from the various pregnancy support groups around Australia. They have nothing in common with them either and do not think that those women have anything to contribute in the way of advice to the Government. They have not invited any of the women from the Right to Life Association, because, in the view of the women from Caucus, those groups have nothing to contribute to this Government.

They have, of course, included such groups as the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, the Federation of University Women, the Union of Australian Women, the Australian Women's Education Coalition, the Australian Federation of Family Planning Associations through its representative Wendy McCarthy, the Australian Council of Trade Unions Women's Committee, and the National Council for Single Mother and Her Child. Two women from the Beryl Women 's Refuge are representatives. The women's refuges are very well represented thoughout the groups. There are two from that refuge. However, the Government has not seen fit to invite any of the other groups I have mentioned. I would be most interested if Senator Ryan could give us some explanation as to why this Government is willing to hear only the views of a certain section of Australian women. I ask her to respond to my request.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add a few words to what Senator Walters said this evening about the invitation that we received from the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Ryan, to go and meet with some of the women tomorrow. I just want to say that I also felt rather sorry that other women's organisations which would be in a position to speak for quite a lot of women throughout Australia had not been invited. Women Who Want to be Women had a meeting in the Brisbane City Hall which attracted 3, 000 women. That is a fairly strong organisation throughout Australia. Senator Walters mentioned some other organisations, including the Women's Action Alliance, Pregnancy Help and Right to Life. I also noticed that the Mothers' Union, the Anglican Women's Organisation, was not asked to go, although I was pleased to see that the Catholic Women's Organisation was invited. I think, too, that perhaps women from some of the other political women's organisations, such as Liberal Party and National Party women, could have attended to give a consensus of ideas. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) likes to talk about a consensus of ideas and when he is talking about doing away with the National Women's Advisory Council it would have been very good for a meeting such as that being held tomorrow to have heard the points of view of differing political shades of opinion. The Prime Minister always seems to need people to advise him. He had to have a lot of people advise him at the National Economic Summit Conference and now he has the Economic Planning Advisory Council. From the number of jobs that have been provided so far, I do not think that these groups have been able to advise him too well. All I hope is that the women's organisations that come to advise him do a better job. I am sorry that the Minister has not seen fit to invite some of these other women's organisations to come to morning tea tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add briefly on behalf of the Opposition to comments made on the subject of the meeting of women here tomorrow . I know that the Opposition's spokesman on the status of women has very strong views on this and will state them in another place. I received a letter from the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Ryan, inviting me to morning tea tomorrow. It referred to a list of the women's organisations invited and an agenda, although I did not receive them; I received them from another woman who was invited. I want to make sincerely a couple of comments to the Minister which I may not be able to make tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been invited to a morning tea at 10 a.m. when the Senate will be sitting. At that time Appropriation Bills will be at the Committee stage and I have an interest in some of the departments with which we will be dealing. As you know, Mr President, there is no way we can anticipate at what time departments will be called on. I have particular responsibilities for the Opposition in relation to certain departments and, whilst I have accepted Senator Ryan's invitation, I have indicated to her office that it is subject to the Senate's program, which is unpredictable when it comes to the subject of Appropriation Bills. I say to Senator Ryan, as a Senate Minister, that it is unfortunate that we have been invited to a function that coincides with a sitting of the Senate and at a time when Senate business will be considered. It may be necessary for us to be here. It is less important for members of the Government to be present for debate on the Appropriation Bills in the Committee of the Whole than it is for Opposition members. If it happens that Opposition senators such as Senator Walters, Senator Bjelke-Petersen or I have to be here in order to carry out our own senatorial duties-particularly our Opposition senatorial duties-I hope that will not be misconstrued as a lack of interest in the proceedings tomorrow.

A second comment I have to make is that I am disappointed by the program. I addressed a question to Senator Ryan in the Senate some time ago-before the question addressed to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that has been referred to earlier in this debate this evening-on the subject of the abolition of the National Women's Advisory Council. I believe that Senator Ryan's answer to my question was the first statement made by a Government member on the Government's intentions in relation to the National Women's Advisory Council. Senator Ryan said in her answer that it was the intention of the Government not to proceed with the National Women's Advisory Council and that in its place a broadly based women's group would be set up. No further elaboration was given. The matter was pursued by Mr Macphee, the Opposition spokesman on the status of women, in the House of Representatives. There were questions and answers and additional information was given by the Prime Minister, as was referred to earlier. That was again of a general nature, but not of a mollifying nature.

I say in all sincerity to the Government that I believe the Liberal and National Parties in government, through the National Women's Advisory Council, tried very sincerely to get a very broad cross section of opinion from Australian women. The National Women's Advisory Council had ten members but always we strove to have a divergence of opinion. Certainly there were women on that council whose liberal inclination in politics was well known. Dame Beryl Beaurepaire was such a women. I would like to pay tribute to Dame Beryl and say that it is thanks to her and the respect she commanded within the Liberal Party, and particularly with the former Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, that great progress was made on issues related to women and also the acceptance of the National Women's Advisory Council as a body that had a real status and a real role as a special body advising government on matters relating to women. I think Dame Beryl did a quite outstanding job. Some expected that she would be a very conservative women, but I think those people who expected that would have been very surprised by her attitude to women's issues. She made a very real contribution, both in a personal way and as Chairman of the National Women's Advisory Council. There were other women on the Council from time to time whose politics were clearly not Liberal and they were chosen for that reason. There were Aboriginal women, women with trade union backgrounds and women from isolated areas. There was a very broad range of backgrounds. The most recent chairman, Mrs Quentin Bryce, had no political affiliations as far as I am aware. Nobody could claim in relation to her public activities that she has done anything other than try to advance the cause of women. She has certainly not been a sycophant to the previous Government, the present Government or to the Queensland Government. She made a very valuable contribution in her declaration of support for issues of importance to women, including anti-discrimination legislation. She played a major role on this subject, particularly in the State of Queensland.

I therefore would like to add a plea which has been made in other areas. Whilst I note that the National Women's Advisory Council will be represented tomorrow, and the name Quentin Bryce appears on the list of those invited, the contribution that has been made by individuals and various chairpeople on the National Women's Advisory Council should be considered in this broadly based group that the Government is setting up to advise it. A point of view put forward at one stage was that the women of Caucus would advise the Government on matters relating to women. Of course the women of Caucus will play a role in relation to policy because they are in government but one of the things that I fear most, whether in government or in opposition, in relation to policies for women is that easy divisions can be made. I believe it is important that whatever group, or whoever, is advising the Government in addition to its parliamentary party be clearly seen to be broadly based, be drawn broadly from the community. Therefore, the advisory group will have a status and an acceptance in the community which will enable some bipartisanship in approach to these issues.

I do have some feelings about the actual personnel who have been invited to attend tomorrow's meeting. I am pleased to see certain people on the group, such as Quentin Bryce and Joyce McConnell from the National Women's Advisory Council and previously from the National Council of Women. Mrs McConnell has played a very prominent part in relation to women's issues. I reiterate-I say it with as much heartfelt sincerity as I can-that it is important that we not look at numbers on this issue but at what can be contributed.

I am not happy about the agenda, of which I now have a copy. There does not seem to me to be much scope for contribution between the hours of 10 a.m. and 3. 30 p.m., 10 a.m. until 10.30 being set down for an informal coffee break. At 3. 30 p.m. there is to be afternoon tea and at 4 p.m. the delegates are to depart for Canberra Airport, according to this agenda. There will not be much opportunity for a real thrashing over of issues. I note that speeches will be made by Senator Ryan, the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, by Senator Giles and by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Government is in government and it can set the agenda, but in the time that is available for discussion, under the heading of items such as 'outline of options', I hope there will be real options.

I am sure that Senator Ryan, as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, appreciates the seriousness of the issues that I address. The thing that upsets me more than anything is not the personalities of the personnel who end up advising the Government, but that an opportunity is being provided for extremist groups to claim that this organisation, whatever it is, is not broadly representative of the women of Australia, that it leaves out a significant point of view among women which the Minister, I am sure, would be the first to agree is not easily generalised on. I hope that the proceedings tomorrow will be very brief when it comes to speeches from politicians. I hope that the women of Australia who have been invited to proceed in these discussions will be given a very real, searching and in depth opportunity to make a real contribution to the direction of government policy in relation to women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of contributions to the adjournment debate tonight. I will comment briefly on those contributions by Senator Walters, Senator Bjelke -Petersen and Senator Martin. I think it is predictable, but unfortunate nonetheless, that Senator Walters chose, characteristically, to be totally negative about a very constructive exercise in which the Government is involved. She chose to focus on her criticisms of the very wide ranging group of women's organisations that will participate in tomorrow's exercise and chose not to address herself to the real purpose of tomorrow's exercise. Senator Bjelke- Petersen repeated some of the negative comments of Senator Walters, although I think she did add a more positive note to her contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Martin made some constructive suggestions in a spirit of co-operation about the management of tomorrow's affairs. I simply say that the purpose of tomorrow's exercise is to devise a consultation procedure that will satisfy our policy of having broadly based consultations with all women's groups throughout Australia. At the conclusion of my comments tonight at the end of the adjournment debate I will table the list of delegates because the claim that the range of organisations which is to be involved in tomorrow's meeting is not broadly based is absolutely ludicrous. It is an extremely wide ranging organisation covering Aboriginal women's groups, working women's groups, defence forces wives associations, the major ethnic women's organisations and church women's organisations. It does not, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen pointed out, include political organisations. That was a decision that I took in consultation with my colleagues after some discussion, because we decided that there would be perhaps some anomaly in inviting women from other political groups to advise the Government on specific matters of policy although, of course, they are free to make their views available to us, and often do, by way of written comment and submission on particular items. The Australian Labor Party is not included in the list of invitees tomorrow for the same reason. These are community women's organisations. They are major women's organisations. They are organisations which have shown themselves over a number of years to be prepared to be constructive and co-operative with governments which are prepared to improve the status of women. I do not think there is any point in consulting women's organisations if those organisations have a record of negative participation in public debate.

In response to Senator Martin's comment about the incomplete nature of my answer to her and also an answer given to the honourable member for Balaclava, Mr Macphee, on our intentions with regard to the new women's consultation process, I simply point out that the whole point of the exercise tomorrow is to hear the views of this very large and diverse range of women's organisations on what sorts of consultation mechanisms they believe would make government aware of the views of women throughout the community. A final form for the new consultative mechanism will not be decided until after tomorrow's exercise. I am very confident about the worthwhile nature of tomorrow's exercise. It is an exercise of consultation on a much wider scope then anything that the previous Government ever attempted, although is is unfortunate that Senator Martin will be otherwise engaged at the time that Opposition women have been invited to meet the representatives of women's organisations. It is a fact of parliamentary life that whenever we decided to have such a meeting it would have been the case that some or other woman senator would have had some conflicting duty. Nonetheless, I hope that Senator Martin, who has a very strong record in support of women's rights, will meet with the representatives of women's organisations. Of course, many of them will be known to her.

I am very confident that the exercise tomorrow will be very valuable, in the first place, to the Government and, secondly, of course ultimately-this is our intention-to women of Australia generally. I will be very happy to report to the Senate on the adjournment debate or on any other appropriate occasion the results of those consultations and deliberations. To complete the adjournment tonight, I table the list of delegates. In doing so I point out that the particular delegates coming from organisations were nominated by those organisations themselves.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 3 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is Trans Australia Airlines purchasing freight space from the Interstate Parcel Express Company and utilising their aircraft at a time when TAA has excess aircraft and crews, in view of Government's recent capitalisation of TAA by a further $130m and their recent reported trading loss for the 1981-82 financial year.
(2) Why did TAA contribute in the order of $5m in revenue a year to IPEC for the freight space to Launceston and to the eastern seaboard capitals.
(3) Why has TAA recently entered into an agreement to charter a Boeing 727-100 freighter from Bloodstock Air Services at a cost of some $5m per annum, part of which has been paid in advance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The honourable senator will be aware that the principal demand for air freight services involves the carriage of freight between centres overnight. Because of curfew requirements at Sydney, Brisbane and Adelaide, such services between the major eastern State capitals can only be provided by non-jet aircraft. The only non-jet aircraft in TAA's fleet are F27s which are now being phased out of service by TAA due to their inefficiency.

TAA has advised that its options were to retain some F27s, purchase specialised non-jet aircraft or charter suitable aircraft from other operators. Of course, the choice of aircraft used by TAA to provide its air freight services is a matter for the commercial judgment of the airline.

TAA has also advised that the arrangement which TAA has with IPEC is cost effective, allows use of suitable non-jet aircraft (IPEC's Argosy pure freighter aircraft) and is consistent with TAA's on-going fleet rationalisation program which is effecting considerable economies.

(3) TAA has entered into an agreement with Bloodstock Air Services to utilise its pure freighter B727-100 aircraft instead of TAA's B727-200 passenger aircraft which have been operating freight services between Perth and Melbourne. The Bloodstock Air Services aircraft is flown by TAA crews and is specially fitted out as a pure freighter. TAA has advised that the aircraft has significant advantages over TAA's passenger aircraft for cargo operations. In this regard, TAA has advised that the pure freighter aircraft requires 70 per cent less ground handling effort, can carry a greater range of commodities, provides a 15 per cent increase in weight payload and a 50 per cent increase in available cubic space.

TAA considers the arrangement with Bloodstock Air Services allows an evaluation of pure jet freighter operations which will be of considerable assistance in assessing TAA's future needs in the cargo area.

In relation to financial aspects, I am advised that the charter rates for IPEC' s operations and for the use of Bloodstock Air Services aircraft were struck using normal commercial negotiating procedures. The agreement reached by TAA on these financial arrangements was a matter for decision by TAA.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 23 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the curfew requirements at Brisbane Airport.
(2) How many times was this curfew broken for each month from January to August 1983.
(3) For each occasion: (a) What airline was involved
(b) What was the time of departure or arrival, and
(c) Why was permission given to land or take-off in the curfew period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The curfew at Brisbane Airport prohibits the operation of turbo-jet aircraft in the period between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m., subject to the following operational contingency provisions: 1. An aircraft bound for a curfewed airport shall depart only if the estimated time of arrival will be at, or before, the start of the curfew. However, if the aircraft is subsequently delayed en-route by unforecast headwinds, thunderstorms, operational conditions, traffic, et cetera, it may continue and land.

2. An aircraft shall not depart from a curfewed airport unless air traffic control has been advised that the aircraft doors are closed, or the aircraft has requested a push back or taxi clearance at, or before, the start of the curfew.

3. The curfew does not apply to an aircraft when operational safety is involved or when it is engaged upon a flight for urgent medical, flood or fire relief purposes, to an evacuation flight undertaken to save some person from grave or imminent danger, or to a flight which has an in-flight medical emergency.

4. Except for Essendon, all curfewed airports may be nominated and used as planned or unplanned alternates. An aircraft diverting to a curfewed airport may not land during the curfew if it has sufficient fuel to hold until the end of the curfew. Once it has landed at a curfewed airpot, a diverted aircraft shall not depart again during the curfew.

Dispensations from the conditions of the curfew require the approval of the Minister for Aviation. The Minister may, at his discretion, approve operations in the following situations: (a) when exceptional passenger hardship is involved ;
(b) for humanitarian reasons;
(c) for delayed flights by visiting Heads of State, the Governor-General and the Prime Minister;
(d) when the aircraft involved is assessed by the Department of Aviation as a ' low noise' aircraft (except at Avalon and Essendon).

(2) Records of all flights in curfew hours at Brisbane Airport by jet aircraft classified as low noise by the Department of Aviation are not kept beyond a period of one month. However, flights in curfew by airline jet aircraft occurred in the months of January (1), May (1) and August (1). These flights were in accordance with dispensations given from the conditions of the curfew and as such did not 'break' the curfew.

(3) 26 January: (a) Qantas (b) Takeoff 11.30 p.m. (c) To avoid hardship to 100 passengers which would have resulted from delay due to mechanical problems. 27 May: (a) TAA (b) Land 11.14 p.m. (c) To avoid hardship to 78 schoolboy passengers which would have resulted from delay due to weather caused refuelling stop en route. 31 August: (a) Qantas (b) Takeoff 11.31 p.m. (c) To avoid hardship to 232 passengers which would have resulted from delay due to mechanical problems.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 14 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the National Health and Medical Research Council recently adopted new standards for wines and spirits.

(2) Is the effect of the change such that wine and brandy can now be made from a number of substances which were previously assessed as of 'inferior quality' that is skins, stalks, seeds, dried grapes and grape essences in fact without any grape juice at all.
(3) Will the new standards also lead to a higher permissible content of methyl alcohol in spirits, an ingredient which attacks the optic nerve.
(4) Will the effect of this change mean that hitherto banned imported brandy will be allowed into Australia, with consequent effects on the local industry.
(5) Will the Government review the new standards, with special regard to the health of Australians and that of the local industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The standards were reviewed over a period of three years with the involvement of Federal and State health authorities, other Federal departments, an academic food technologist and representatives of the liquor industry.
(2) No. The question fails to recognise that traditional wine making practices have always used skins, stalks and seeds in order to produce characteristic products.
For example, skins, seeds and stalks are used to supply colour, tannin and flavour in wine and they provide much of the flavour and almost all of the colour in red wines.
By allowing contact for a lesser period of time ros'e wines are produced.
White wines may also benefit in flavour from limited periods of contact with seeds and skins.

Thus, far from being substances of 'inferior quality', skins, seeds and stalks are essential to many traditional wine making processes and their exclusion would materially change the nature of these products and could well lead to attempts to reproduce colour and flavour by chemical manipulation.

The addition of excess quantities of dried grapes for wine production is prevented by the requirement in the Standard which limits the total addition of water to 30 millilitre per litre of the finished wine.

I would point out that the wine making industry was well represented on the working party which drew up the revised standard and they would certainly not have agreed to proposals which would have affected the quality of their products or jeopardised the viability of the industry's domestic markets or export potential.

(3) No. In fact, the reverse is the case. The previous standard set no limits for methyl alcohol content of spirits. The revised standard breaks new ground in establishing control limits. However very little scientific data are available on which to base a level of chronic methyl alcohol ingestion which would saturate the body's normal detoxification system. The figure of eight grams of methanol per litre of ethanol was arrived at by consideration of world wide regulatory figures and what data are available as a maximum permitted figure for use until a more definitive schedule of values could be developed. It is entirely in accord with current regulations in those countries which do set limits. Methanol limits are kept under continuing review by the food committees of the NHMRC and will be modified as new data become available.

(4) No. Contrary to recent statements concerning this matter, the importation of grappa has been permitted for many years. Under the new standard, the methanol content of such products will be regulated for the first time. This can hardly be considered a weakening of regulation or a relaxation of control on imports. Highly ethical associations representing both the wine and spirit industries were involved in the revision of the standards and were in full accord with the decision reached on these matters. These representatives saw no danger to their industry arising from the new standard.

(5) All standards are kept under continuing review and modified as new information of significance becomes available. When information of substance is obtained on this issue it will be specifically reviewed. The health of Australians is always the first consideration in such issues. The best interest of the industry involved is a major secondary consideration. Neither is threatened by the revised standards for wines and spirits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it desirable for Australia to create a closer relationship with South East Asian countries; if so, in what way does the Government see this being achieved.
(2) Will the Government be considering in the long term, seeking membership of the Association of South East Asian Nations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Labor Party came into government with a firm commitment to further Australia's relationship with its South East Asian neighbours. It is this Government's belief that Australia should enjoy close relations with South East Asia. We have sought to achieve this, in particular, by consolidating and strengthening our existing dialogue relationship with ASEAN. The ASEAN-Australia Economic Co-operation Program-(AAECP), the ASEAN-Australia forum, the ASEAN- Australia consultative meetings, and the ASEAN-plus foreign Ministers' meetings, are all important aspects of our dialogue relationship. Australia's friendship with ASEAN, however, does not preclude it from developing mature and productive relationships with the other countries in South East Asia. We look forward to peace and stability for all nations of South East Asia, and we support ASEAN's concept of a zone of peace, freedom and neutrality for the region.

(2) In view of the economic and social dissimilarities between Australia and ASEAN, we believe that at present the ASEAN-Australia dialogue outlined above is a more appropriate and mutually profitable relationship than would be Australian membership of ASEAN. I believe that the present dialogue enjoyed by Australia has satisfied many of the needs which first caused this question to be raised in the 1970s and has proven mutually beneficial to both sides.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 4 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister examining the ramifications of the decision by the Full Bench of the Federal Court to allow a Sydney dealer, Zyfert and Muller Automotive Services, to circumvent the motor vehicle plan.
(2) Will the Government take immediate action to plug the loophole in the law to prevent such circumvention occurring again; if so, when; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) From my examination of the Federal Court decisions in this matter there does not appear to be created any opportunity for the circumvention of the motor vehicle plan.
(2) Future importations of this class of vehicle will be kept under review to ensure that the Government's assistance measures for the motor vehicle industry are not undermined.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 4 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government considering relocating the parcels post section of the Customs Service from Maffra Street to Customs House, William Street, Melbourne, so dividing the points of customs entry and parcel delivery involving importers in calling to two widely separated points for one item.
(2) Why is the proposed relocation being undertaken.

(3) Has the Government considered the effect of any such move on the costs imposed on small importing companies; if so what are the effects in terms of additional costs; if not, why not, and will the Government now undertake such an assessment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no proposal to move the Melbourne Parcels Post Customs Section from the Maffra Street Mail Exchange. However, I understand that the Collector of Customs for Victoria has announced his intention that the checking of import entries for commercial consignments imported by mail be carried out in the invoice room at the Customs House rather than at the Maffra Street sub-office. This change will not take place until the move of the Customs Service to the World Trade Centre is finalised.

(2) The proposed change aims to help maintain the level of service for all importers by combining the resources of the invoice rooms of the small Maffra Street office with the larger office at the Customs House. It is expected that the merging of the staff will give productivity gains that will benefit the whole of the importing community.

(3) I am aware that several importers who import only through the mails have expressed concern that the changes would create additional costs to them-I have in fact received representations along these lines and the Collector of Customs has been asked to consider this aspect of the proposal. I am advised that the Collector believes that many importers will find that the new procedures will offer cost advantages. To enable importers to fairly judge this he has arranged for Customs entries, for goods imported by mail, to now be accepted at the Customs House. The Collector is also maintaining an invoice checking facility at Maffra Street until the move to the World Trade Centre takes place by which time all importers will have had the opportunity to assess the costs and benefits of the proposed change. Importers are being encouraged to discuss their particular problems with responsible officers and to personally try the alternative procedures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Aboriginal land rights applications have been received by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.
(2) What claims are currently being heard.
(3) What claims are still outstanding.
(4) What claims are in the hands of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs or awaiting ministerial action.
(5) When is it anticipated a decision will be made on these claims.
(6) How many Aboriginal land claims have not yet been made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The net number of Aboriginal land claims lodged since the Aboriginal Land Rights Act (Northern Territory) 1976 came into effect is 60. This total takes account of claims which were later replaced, withdrawn, or amalgamated with others. A listing of all applications, with their current status, is contained in the following schedule.

(2) The Jawoyn (Katherine area), Murranji, Warumungu, Kenbi (Cox Peninsula), Beetaloo and Upper Daly River claims have been partly heard. A High Court decision is awaited before the Warumungu and Beetaloo hearings may proceed.

(3) Thirty-one claims, which are listed in the schedule have yet to be heard. The hearings of nine of these are scheduled to commence in 1984. The Cox River, Mt Allen, Nicholson River, Mt Barkly and Ngadi Warlpiri claims have been heard, and the Minister is waiting for the Aboriginal Land Commissioner's reports.
(4) The Finniss River and Daly River (Malak Malak) claims are awaiting ministerial decisions.

(5) The Finniss River and Daly River claims involve complex issues of potential detriment to other parties, and it will be some months before decisions can be made. A working party of Northern Territory and Australian Government officers, and the Northern Land Council, is currently studying detriment issues involved in the Finniss River land claim.

(6) The number of future claims cannot be forecast. The rate at which applications have been lodged has slowed; only two new applications were received by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner in the year ended 30 June 1983.
